headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to KeyCorp's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Beth Mooney, Chairman and CEO. Please go ahead, ma'am.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to KeyCorp's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Beth Mooney, Chairman and CEO. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, and welcome to KeyCorp Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me for today's presentation is Don Kimble, our Chief Financial Officer; and available for the Q&A portion of the call is Chris Gorman, Presiden
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning, and welcome to KeyCorp Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me for today's presentation is Don Kimble, our Chief Financial Officer; and available for the Q&A portion of the call is Chris Gorman, President of our Corporate Bank; E.J. Burke; and Dennis Devine, co- presidents of our Community Bank; and Bill Hartmann, our Chief Risk Officer. Slide 2 is our statement on forward-looking disclosure and non-GAAP financial measures. It covers our presentation materials and comments, as well as the question and answer segment of our call. 
I'm now turning to Slide 3. Our fourth quarter closes out what has been a very significant year for our company. We improved our operating performance, continued our credit discipline, maintained our strong capital position and made investments that will drive future growth and profitability. For the year, Key generated positive operating leverage that we believe was among the strongest in our peer group. Our revenues were up 3% and our pre-provision net revenue was up 5%, both compared to the prior year. These results reflect our success in continuing to grow and expand client relationships in both the Community Bank and the Corporate Bank, and these new clients contributed to our 5% growth in average loans and 12% growth in CF&A balances. We also increased our core fee-based income including investment banking and debt placement fees, which were up 12%, another record year for us. Corporate services and cards and payments were both up over 10%. And I think it's worth noting that these are areas where we have made recent investments that are generating growth and positive returns. 
Expense management also remained an area of focus. During the year, we continue to execute on opportunities to rightsize our business, reduce occupancy costs and improve operational efficiency. Expense trends reflect our investments to drive future growth and profitability as well as merger-related charges and those related to our continuous improvement and efficiency effort. Investments during the year included remixing our headcount to increase client facing roles in both the Corporate Bank and the Community Bank. We also enhanced our payments capability, which have driven strong growth in purchase and prepaid card as well as a 13% increase year-over-year in credit card sales. And we continue to invest in our digital and mobile offerings as well as ongoing enhancements to our compliance and regulatory processes. These were good investments that help drive our revenue growth in 2015 and they will make an even larger contribution in the future as they fully mature. While these investments, including the addition of 60 senior bankers in our Corporate and Community Bank, as well as Pacific Crest Securities, position us for growth, they offset some of the efficiency improvements made in other areas of our company last year. Importantly, we remain committed to further improvement in the targets that we have established. 
Credit quality remained a good story in 2015 but nonperforming loans down for the year and net charge-offs of 24 basis points which is below our targeted range. We remain committed to strong risk management practices and staying true to our relationship focus. The final item on the slide is capital. Our common equity Tier 1 ratio remains strong at 11% which we believe positions us well for the 2016 CCAR process and we expect both share repurchases and a dividend increase to be part of the capital plan we will submit. 
I'm now moving to Slide 4 which provides some highlights of our announced acquisition of First Niagara. We continue to make good progress as we move toward our anticipated closing in the third quarter of this year. Under the leadership of Chris Gorman, we have established integration teams with some of the top talent from both Key and First Niagara and these teams have been focused on developing detailed assessments and moving forward with our integration plan. As we move through these early stages, I'm even more confident in this be the right opportunity for Key and our ability to realize the cost-savings. The combined company will generate attractive financial returns and create value for our shareholders and accelerates our progress towards becoming a high-performing regional bank. And although not included in our financial projections, we will realize additional value from revenue synergies that will also add to the financial performance. We look forward to sharing more developments with you in the coming quarter as we move towards closing. 
Before I turn the call over to Don, I would like to close my remarks by saying that it was a good year for Key. We executed against our strategic and financial goals and took steps to accelerate our progress going forward. I'm proud of our team and of our performance and I'm excited about the opportunity that we have ahead. Now, I'll turn the call over to Don to discuss the details of our fourth quarter results. Don?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and I'm on Slide 6. That said, we had a good year finishing with fourth quarter net income from continuing operations of $0.27 per common share. This compared to $0.28 in the year-ago period and $0.26 in the third quarter. In the fourth quarter, K
componenttext:
Thanks, and I'm on Slide 6. That said, we had a good year finishing with fourth quarter net income from continuing operations of $0.27 per common share. This compared to $0.28 in the year-ago period and $0.26 in the third quarter. In the fourth quarter, Key incurred $10 million of charges related to pension settlement and the acquisition of First Niagara. The combined impact was $0.01 per common share. Excluding these items, net income from continuing operations was $0.28 per common share, the same as the year-ago quarter. However, it's worth noting in comparison with the year-ago period, that the current quarter includes $23 million in higher provision expense and $18 million of lower principal investing gains, given such strong finish to the year. Also, not on the slide is the revenue growth. For the quarter, revenue was up 2% from the prior year and up 3% from the prior quarter. For the full year, Key had a revenue growth of over 3%, reflecting the success we've had in growing our businesses. This revenue growth has allowed us to grow our pre-provision net revenues 5% year-over-year. I will cover the other items in the rest of my presentations. I'm now turning over to Slide 7. Average loan balances were up $3 billion or 5% compared to year ago quarter and up $295 million from third quarter. Our year-over-year growth was once again driven primarily by commercial, financial and agricultural loans and was broad-based across Key's business lending segments. Average CF&A loans were up $3.7 billion or 14% compared to the prior year, or $510 million or 2% on annualized from the third quarter. During the current quarter, we continued to generate strong customer growth that was muted by pay down of lines with existing customers. 
Continuing on to Slide 8. On the liability side of the balance sheet, average deposits, excluding deposits in foreign office totaled $71.5 million for the fourth quarter 2015, an increase of $2.3 billion compared to the year-ago quarter. The year-over-year increase is reflective of growth in our commercial mortgage servicing business and inflows from commercial and consumer clients. Compared to the third quarter 2015, average deposits excluding deposits in foreign office increased by $1.5 billion. The growth was driven by both seasonal and short-term deposit inflows from commercial clients along with growth in NOW and money market deposit accounts and certificate of. 
Turning to Slide 9. Taxable equivalent net interest income was $610 million for the fourth quarter 2015. Net interest margin was 2.87%. These results compared to taxable equivalent net interest income of $588 million and a net interest margin of 2.94% for the fourth quarter 2014. The increase in net interest income reflects higher earning asset balances partially offset by lower earning asset yields, which also drove the decline in net interest margin. Compared to the third quarter of 2015, taxable equivalent net interest income increased by $12 million and the net interest margin was unchanged. The increase in net interest income and the stable net interest margin were to attributable to higher earnings asset yields and loan fees and while net interest margin was stable, it was negatively impacted by higher levels of excess liquidity driven by short-term composite growth. 
Slide 10 shows the summary of noninterest income which accounted for 44% of our total revenue. Noninterest income in the fourth quarter was $485 million, down $5 million or 1% from the prior year and up $15 million or 3% from the prior quarter. The slight decrease from the prior year was attributed to lower net gains from principal investing of $18 million and $7 million of lower trust and investment services income reflecting market viability. These decreases were partially offset by a $12 million increase in other income gains in our real estate capital line of business along with growth in some of Key's other core fee base businesses including $4 million of higher cards of payments income and a $4 million increase in mortgage servicing fees. Compared to last quarter, noninterest income improved by $15 million. That was notably due to higher investment banking and debt placement fees, marking a strong finish to a record year. Additionally, other income was higher once again related to gains in real estate capital. And corporate owned life insurance increased reflecting normal seasonality. These items were offset by lower net gains from principal investing. 
Turning to Slide 11. As you can see on this slide, expense levels were elevated and reflected a number of moving pieces. I'll start with the current quarter. Noninterest expense was $736 million which included $20 million of charges consisting of $10 million of efficiency charges primarily related to branch closures and severance, $6 million of merger-related cost and $4 million of pension settlement income. Next, compared to the fourth quarter last year, our noninterest expense is up 5%. The increase was primarily attributed to $20 million of higher personnel costs, reflecting an $11 million increase in benefit cost. The investments in client fee and personnel cost across the company and higher severance expense. We also had a $6 million of merger-related costs. And finally, linked quarter expenses were up 2% related to $12 million of higher incentive compensation related to strong capital market performance and end-of-the-year accruals, $6 million of merger-related costs incurred in the fourth quarter and $6 million of higher efficiency related charges. These were partially offset by the lower pension settlement charge. Once again, the current quarter included elevated levels of expenses reflecting the cost noted above in normal seasonal trends. We would expect first quarter expense levels to be significantly lower than the fourth quarter. Also, we would expect the full year 2016 expenses to be relatively stable in 2015, adjusted for merger-related costs. 
Turning to slide 12, net charge-offs were $37 million or 25 basis points of average total loans in the fourth quarter which continued to be below our target range. In the fourth quarter, provision for credit losses of $45 million, slightly above the level of charge-offs, reflecting current trends in our portfolio. Nonperforming loans and nonperforming assets were both down relative to prior quarter and year ago period. At December 31, 2015, our reserve for total loan losses represented 1.33% of period and loans and 206% coverage of our nonperforming loans. It's also worth noting that our energy exposure is small, representing 2% of our total portfolio and has performed in line with our expectations. We built reserves throughout the year which currently represents 6% of outstanding loans. 
Turning to slide 13, our common equity Tier 1 ratio was strong at December 31, 2015 at 10.95%. There were no share repurchases in the fourth quarter. For the full year, we repurchased $460 million of common shares. We expect share repurchases and an increased dividend to be included in our upcoming 2015 CCAR submission. 
Now moving on to slide 14. For our 2016 outlook, we're providing guidance on our standalone Key operations. In 2016, we expect to continue to drive positive operating leverage. Average loans should grow in the mid-single digit range as we benefit from a strength of our commercial businesses. We anticipate that net interest income growth and the low single digit percentage range compared to 2015 without any benefit from higher interest rates. With the benefit of future rate increases, we would anticipate net interest income to be up in the mid-single digit rates. It's also important to note that we have assumed that deposit rates will increase with future rate increases. Noninterest income is expected to be up in mid-single percentage range for the year. This assumes continued strong improvement in investing banking and debt placement fees as well as continued growth in cards and payment income. We're also assuming very modest levels of principal investing gains for 2016. Full year reported expenses should be relatively stable in 2015. We would expect to see normal seasonal trends and expenses with first quarter expenses down significantly from the fourth quarter level. Credit quality should remain a good story with net charge-offs below our targeted range of 40 to 60 basis points. We also expect provision levels to maintain a stable level of allowance of total loans. And finally, we expect our dividend to increase in the second quarter to $0.085 per share and the 2016 CCAR plan to include both common share repurchases and an increased dividend. Our guidance explicitly impact our merger-related charges as well as the acquisition of First Niagara. If the acquisition closes in the third quarter as planned, we would expect EPS impact with a slight dilution of 1% to 2% in 2016 and accretive in 2017. With that, I'll close and turn the call back over to the operator for instructions for the Q&A portion of our call. Operator?

componenttext: Sure, Josh. It's Chris. As we look at our pipeline kind of across the Corporate Bank, our pipelines are very much in line with where they were a year ago and as Don mentioned, we had a record year last year. So we actually, feel very good about our pipelines.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next we'll go to Erika Najarian with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And next we'll go to Erika Najarian with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask a question on something you mentioned during your prepared remarks. You mentioned that you're even more confident about the First Niagara deal after in terms of extracting cost-savings. Could you give us a little bit of color in terms
componenttext: I just wanted to ask a question on something you mentioned during your prepared remarks. You mentioned that you're even more confident about the First Niagara deal after in terms of extracting cost-savings. Could you give us a little bit of color in terms of the conversations or the progress that you have made after announcing the deal in terms of thinking about the future impact and also with the progresses in terms of getting First Niagara ready to be embedded into your CCAR process?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Erika, I'd be glad to discuss that and I'd let Don address the CCAR portion because he is closer to that work than I am. And you're correct that I'm even more confident. We feel even stronger about the path and quality of what will be the value of th
componenttext: Yes, Erika, I'd be glad to discuss that and I'd let Don address the CCAR portion because he is closer to that work than I am. And you're correct that I'm even more confident. We feel even stronger about the path and quality of what will be the value of this combined company. The cost-savings, as you know, we had targeted $400 million or approximately 40% of their cost and while it is early days, the integration teams have been identified and are working 2 by 2 to map out those plans and as we really understand the underlying cost structure, particularly in technology, operations, vendor expense, there are significant savings in all of those areas that probably contribute to over 40% of that $400 million. So out of the gate as we look for the path, while nothing is ever easy, we also see very real savings that are easy to garner and will also be realize fairly early within the time after our acquisition. We're also looking complementary  business capabilities and revenue synergies that we continue to gain confidence about the value that will be created there. So in all, I do think you hear a continued tone of confidence as well as a path forward that we feel strongly about.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the CCAR process that we'll be including First Niagara with an assumed acquisition date in the third quarter as we talked about before for the CCAR submission. We'll be relying primarily on Key models in the past and using the First Niagara info
componenttext: As far as the CCAR process that we'll be including First Niagara with an assumed acquisition date in the third quarter as we talked about before for the CCAR submission. We'll be relying primarily on Key models in the past and using the First Niagara information where we can to run through our existing models as well. And so we will show within the plan a separated amount for both First Niagara and Key on a standalone basis but the full CCAR plan will include the assumption that First Niagara is a part of the third quarter.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And really appreciate the color, and look forward on the 2016 CCAR submission and as we think about the amount of common share repurchases, should we assume that given that First Niagara is part of your two-year plan that the 2016 buyback ask woul
componenttext: Got it. And really appreciate the color, and look forward on the 2016 CCAR submission and as we think about the amount of common share repurchases, should we assume that given that First Niagara is part of your two-year plan that the 2016 buyback ask would be later than the up to $725 million that you would approved for '15?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's too early to assume that the absolute dollar amount. What we do believe and expect to see a significant portion of share buybacks as well as an increase in our dividend for the 2016 CCAR but we will have to work through that over the next sev
componenttext: I think it's too early to assume that the absolute dollar amount. What we do believe and expect to see a significant portion of share buybacks as well as an increase in our dividend for the 2016 CCAR but we will have to work through that over the next several months and finalize those remaining details.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to Scott Siefers with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to Scott Siefers with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask a question on overall loan growth. Based on the guide for '16, it looks like there are no hiccups or anything but I was just a little caught off guard by the slowdown in a few categories and then the overall loan growth of the fourth qu
componenttext: Just wanted to ask a question on overall loan growth. Based on the guide for '16, it looks like there are no hiccups or anything but I was just a little caught off guard by the slowdown in a few categories and then the overall loan growth of the fourth quarter. So either Don or Beth, I was just hoping you could update us on your thoughts on overall loan demand, interest rate, et cetera.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far as the overall loan growth, if you look at the average balances, I would say on a year-over-year basis, we're up 5%. We're saying for next year mid-single-digits. Pipelines remain strong we have a very strong third quarter and so if you're ju
componenttext: Sure. As far as the overall loan growth, if you look at the average balances, I would say on a year-over-year basis, we're up 5%. We're saying for next year mid-single-digits. Pipelines remain strong we have a very strong third quarter and so if you're just looking of a period of imbalances, there clearly was some slowdown and period imbalance because of some temporary flows in and out during that subsequent periods. But I would say that we're continuing to see very strong growth in our commercial business. You will probably see some slower growth from Key in our commercial real estate area and that's intentional as far some of the credit disciplines we're maintaining and backing off of some of the higher growth areas from a multifamily perspective and also adjusting our outlook as far as doing housing in a few areas like that. You could see a lot less construction loan activity from Key than you might be seeing from some of our peers.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Scott, I would just follow on with the notion that Don did say we had an extremely strong third quarter and there are some variability quarter-to-quarter but I think it was a good quarter and obviously, a good year. When you look to our guidance for 2
componenttext: And Scott, I would just follow on with the notion that Don did say we had an extremely strong third quarter and there are some variability quarter-to-quarter but I think it was a good quarter and obviously, a good year. When you look to our guidance for 2016 with mid-single digits and continued strength in our commercial businesses, I look at that across the spectrum and continue to say this is an area of strength and where we have been investing in our senior bankers in order to drive growth through client acquisition.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from John Pancari with Evercore.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The marks that will be taken will be done as of the closed date and so I would say that what we're experiencing, I don't think there's any outsize risk from the marks on the First Niagara portfolio from the loan book or others that would suggest any overa
componenttext: The marks that will be taken will be done as of the closed date and so I would say that what we're experiencing, I don't think there's any outsize risk from the marks on the First Niagara portfolio from the loan book or others that would suggest any overall concerns there but again, we'll finalize those towards the acquisition date and make sure that we have the appropriate valuations at that time.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, separately, I wanted to get your -- I'm sorry, if I missed this but I wanted to get your updated thoughts on the manufacturing sector as it pertains to impacting loan growth as well as credit. I know we've seen some the industrial space se
componenttext: Okay. And then, separately, I wanted to get your -- I'm sorry, if I missed this but I wanted to get your updated thoughts on the manufacturing sector as it pertains to impacting loan growth as well as credit. I know we've seen some the industrial space seeing some pressure here and some banks are flagged. Some incremental concerned there but I wanted to get your updated thoughts.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, it's Chris. Clearly as we're out talking with customers everyday, a 2% growth in the economy, coupled with the strong dollar, it's not without challenges. Having said that, our clients are sitting on more cash than ever. We're having more strategic
componenttext: John, it's Chris. Clearly as we're out talking with customers everyday, a 2% growth in the economy, coupled with the strong dollar, it's not without challenges. Having said that, our clients are sitting on more cash than ever. We're having more strategic discussions than we ever had with our clients and in a 2% loan growth, they have the same challenges we do. You have to either figure out how you can take share or how you can grow externally. And so in a way, that's a bit of a catalyst for our business. So it certainly, isn't rosy. The growth is, as I said, probably 2% but the companies are in good shape. They have a lot of cash and they're looking to do things strategically. Broadly, when you have sales of $17.5 million cards and trucks at retail, that has a positive impact on a lot of business banking clients, middle-market clients and other clients because a lot of the folks obviously, are part of the supply chain.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, lastly, just going back to the strong 3Q, you said you saw in loan growth. So is it fair to think -- fair to focus more on the end of period balance this year as well as we model out in terms of the real trends you're seeing in loan growth
componenttext: Okay. And then, lastly, just going back to the strong 3Q, you said you saw in loan growth. So is it fair to think -- fair to focus more on the end of period balance this year as well as we model out in terms of the real trends you're seeing in loan growth?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know I'd ever want to stay on the period of balances but half of the work out this quarter, if you look at our average balances in the fourth quarter, they're lower than the period and if we continue that kind of momentum going forward, it would i
componenttext: I don't know I'd ever want to stay on the period of balances but half of the work out this quarter, if you look at our average balances in the fourth quarter, they're lower than the period and if we continue that kind of momentum going forward, it would imply a mid-single digit kind of year-over-year growth. I would say that's reflected this quarter but not necessarily every quarter.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: And we'll go to David Eads with UBS.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys might have on what you're seeing in the energy vertical in your aftermarket business in terms of where people are going for capital, where discussions are, where people -- you guys are involving restructuring discussions or asset sales discussion
componenttext: You guys might have on what you're seeing in the energy vertical in your aftermarket business in terms of where people are going for capital, where discussions are, where people -- you guys are involving restructuring discussions or asset sales discussions, just kind of what's the state of play from where you stand there?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, this is Chris. I think the answer is all the above. I think depending on where on sort of the capital stack companies are. Clearly, the amount of high yield debt that was raised when the cycle first started to turnover. That has dissipated. The amount
componenttext: So, this is Chris. I think the answer is all the above. I think depending on where on sort of the capital stack companies are. Clearly, the amount of high yield debt that was raised when the cycle first started to turnover. That has dissipated. The amount of private equity that has come in, I think that has started to dissipate and I do think people are looking at asset sales, whole company sales and other forms of restructuring. So I think with oil trading, $26 or $27 a barrel, I think people are looking at all options and we are part of those discussions.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Bob Ramsey with FBR.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Credit trends looked good and all the numbers I see our there. I'm just curious as you guys think about credit, if you're incrementally more or less cautious than maybe a quarter or year ago?
componenttext: Credit trends looked good and all the numbers I see our there. I'm just curious as you guys think about credit, if you're incrementally more or less cautious than maybe a quarter or year ago?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, this Bill Hartmann. I think as we look at credit in our portfolio, we have a very, very granular portfolio which is one of the ways we like to balance things out. I would pick up on Chris's comments about the general overall trend in a low growth eco
componenttext: Bob, this Bill Hartmann. I think as we look at credit in our portfolio, we have a very, very granular portfolio which is one of the ways we like to balance things out. I would pick up on Chris's comments about the general overall trend in a low growth economy. We're being diligent to look for any signs of weakness and what we're seeing is really reflective in Chris's comments, which is there are certain sectors where we're seeing weakness. But overall, the trends that we're showing in our numbers say that the overall portfolio quality remains high.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, sectors where you are seeing weakness, I know you mentioned manufacturing a little bit but beyond that and maybe energy, where else we be seeing some weakness?
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, sectors where you are seeing weakness, I know you mentioned manufacturing a little bit but beyond that and maybe energy, where else we be seeing some weakness?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not seeing weakness per se but we have been cautious for a while now in talking about multifamily and being cautious about where we invest and how we do that and then, student housing was another area.
componenttext: We're not seeing weakness per se but we have been cautious for a while now in talking about multifamily and being cautious about where we invest and how we do that and then, student housing was another area.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll go to Gerard Cassidy with RBC.
componenttext: And next, we'll go to Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, you mentioned that on the other commercial lending areas balances obviously, you're down and you guys are sticking to your credit disciplines as Chris talked about the multifamily end student loan housing markets that you're seeing some weakness. Can
componenttext: Don, you mentioned that on the other commercial lending areas balances obviously, you're down and you guys are sticking to your credit disciplines as Chris talked about the multifamily end student loan housing markets that you're seeing some weakness. Can you share with us some of the underwriting crits that you're seeing out there that makes you hesitant to get involved or is it just over building that as you concerned in these markets?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gerard, it's Chris. We look at a lot of metrics. You can start with some of the cap rates and they range from large gateway cities, 5% in some instances, even 4% and those are sort of priced to perfection. We spent a lot of time looking at what the rent t
componenttext: Gerard, it's Chris. We look at a lot of metrics. You can start with some of the cap rates and they range from large gateway cities, 5% in some instances, even 4% and those are sort of priced to perfection. We spent a lot of time looking at what the rent to wage ratio is, i.e. the affordability of these Class A multifamily apartment buildings. Those are some of the metrics we look at and then, we also spend a lot of time looking at what people are doing out in the market. How far out are they going? Are they doing nonrecourse loans? What percent of our book, for example is not stabilized? We're now down to 13% of our total commitments in real estate are non-stabilized. So those are some of the metrics were looking at.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Chris, when you mentioned the cap rates of 4% to 5% price to perfection, what do you guys more comfortable with even  with that specific metric of cap rate?
componenttext: And Chris, when you mentioned the cap rates of 4% to 5% price to perfection, what do you guys more comfortable with even  with that specific metric of cap rate?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really -- you have to look at market by market and really what the opportunity is but I can tell you when you get to a 4% cap rate, that has built in it into those assumptions that it will lease up quickly and you'll be able to get rent increases goi
componenttext: It's really -- you have to look at market by market and really what the opportunity is but I can tell you when you get to a 4% cap rate, that has built in it into those assumptions that it will lease up quickly and you'll be able to get rent increases going forward and we just think that those are a lot of variables.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Just finally on this commercial real estate. Have you guys seen any evidence the regulators came out late last year with concerns about the commercial real estate market underwriting? Is there any evidence yet that, that's sinking into banks to kind b
componenttext: And Just finally on this commercial real estate. Have you guys seen any evidence the regulators came out late last year with concerns about the commercial real estate market underwriting? Is there any evidence yet that, that's sinking into banks to kind be a little more conservative?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are seeing that in the marketplace. Of course, we're familiar with this sort of prudent lending that came out. I think in the fourth quarter. E.J. is sitting next to me, I think the last time the regulator sent out such a memo in real estate it was whe
componenttext: We are seeing that in the marketplace. Of course, we're familiar with this sort of prudent lending that came out. I think in the fourth quarter. E.J. is sitting next to me, I think the last time the regulator sent out such a memo in real estate it was when?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: '05. I think -- we actually think the regulators are right. We think the market is a little hot in certain areas and that's why by strategy, we've been really toggling more agent per principle.
componenttext: '05. I think -- we actually think the regulators are right. We think the market is a little hot in certain areas and that's why by strategy, we've been really toggling more agent per principle.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And my final question is in the community bank, you guys showed the assets and the management dropped, I think 13% maybe year-over-year. Can you just give some color on what's going on in that part of the business?
componenttext: Great. And my final question is in the community bank, you guys showed the assets and the management dropped, I think 13% maybe year-over-year. Can you just give some color on what's going on in that part of the business?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is E.J. Burke. Included in that number -- in the $39 billion from '14 is a sub-line business that we call institutional asset services and in that business, they do -- there's a securities lending function which has been -- is not something we've bee
componenttext: This is E.J. Burke. Included in that number -- in the $39 billion from '14 is a sub-line business that we call institutional asset services and in that business, they do -- there's a securities lending function which has been -- is not something we've been growing. We had a couple of clients so about $4 billion of that drop where to clients that left that we're doing securities lending for. Not much -- you'll note that our -- the drop in our -- or the difference in our trust and investment services revenue wasn't nearly that big.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And next, we'll go to Terry McEvoy with Stephens.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And next, we'll go to Terry McEvoy with Stephens.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, you talked about higher deposit rates in your NIM outlook. Could you provide may be you deposit beta assumption? Do they differ at all by region and do you know how that would compare the past cycles?
componenttext: Don, you talked about higher deposit rates in your NIM outlook. Could you provide may be you deposit beta assumption? Do they differ at all by region and do you know how that would compare the past cycles?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our base assumption is about a 55% deposit beta and there isn't a whole lot of fluctuation by region other than more of a general assumption. It does get more granular at the product level, and we would use that. And essentially what we included in our gu
componenttext: Our base assumption is about a 55% deposit beta and there isn't a whole lot of fluctuation by region other than more of a general assumption. It does get more granular at the product level, and we would use that. And essentially what we included in our guidance is our assumptions here include the outlook that our deposit rates would increase the same deposit beta level for future rate increase. So there is some potential opportunities there but that would lag initially.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a follow up for Beth. Every time I read my hometown newspaper at Western New York, it seems like a politician or a business leader is saying something against the First Niagara deal. I guess my question is, is this type or was this expected is a
componenttext: And just a follow up for Beth. Every time I read my hometown newspaper at Western New York, it seems like a politician or a business leader is saying something against the First Niagara deal. I guess my question is, is this type or was this expected is a little bit more than you expected and could there be any additional costs or concessions that you have to make to get the deal done in terms of expenses and/or divestitures or branches and deposits?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Terry. It is clearly an area where it is a large acquisition in an environment where there has not been many significant acquisitions in the last several years, so it has garnered a fair amount of attention but we have been very diligent and consiste
componenttext: Yes, Terry. It is clearly an area where it is a large acquisition in an environment where there has not been many significant acquisitions in the last several years, so it has garnered a fair amount of attention but we have been very diligent and consistent in our outreach to community leaders and public officials and I believe we're having very, very constructive dialogue. In part, Key is a very good partner for this franchise and as we look at the story, we have the tale and our long-standing track record and community investments, community development, eighth straight CRE outstanding ratings which no other top banking company has ever received, I think we've gone a long way to setting a very constructive tone for the kind of neighbor, the kind of bank and the kind of partner we will be. So we made a lot of commitments, not only about achieving our financial targets but also about doing the right things for clients, employees, communities and shareholders and I believe that there obviously in the process with the much process with the Department of Justice which will make the determination on the divestitures numbers and working through our plan and our process and I think we have good and significant partner and good for those communities and those customers.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we think about the expense progression throughout the year, should we expect any meaningful lumpiness? So stable for the full year but first half on a year-over-year basis or second half on a year-over-year basis should be relatively stable I guess, in
componenttext: As we think about the expense progression throughout the year, should we expect any meaningful lumpiness? So stable for the full year but first half on a year-over-year basis or second half on a year-over-year basis should be relatively stable I guess, in those periods?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, from a seasonal trend, our first quarter tends to be our lowest point as far as expense levels and so we would expect a meaningful or was it significant reduction from our fourth quarter level and you would typically expect the fourth quarter to be o
componenttext: Yes, from a seasonal trend, our first quarter tends to be our lowest point as far as expense levels and so we would expect a meaningful or was it significant reduction from our fourth quarter level and you would typically expect the fourth quarter to be one of the higher quarters as far as the expenses. So I think you would see a similar trend overall as far as the expense levels. Keep in mind that first quarter last year, our investment banking debt placement fees were low, and so our incentive compensation would have been low last year compared to probably what you would expect in the first quarter of next year as we would expect to have a nice increase in investment banking debt placement fees for the  first quarter a year ago.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, you're partially answer the question I think what I'm trying to get at is as we think about keeping expenses flat, do we see some increase on a year-over-year basis in the first half of the year and then the efficiencies kick in, in the back half of
componenttext: Okay, you're partially answer the question I think what I'm trying to get at is as we think about keeping expenses flat, do we see some increase on a year-over-year basis in the first half of the year and then the efficiencies kick in, in the back half of the year? You kind of said 1Q might be up on a year-over-year basis because of the incentives just conceptually kind of first half, second half?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say that our expense initiatives are continues throughout the year, so I don't think there could be any lumpiness there. I think as you repeated, we would expect first quarter expenses in 2016 to be higher than '15 reflecting the overall perf
componenttext: Yes, I would say that our expense initiatives are continues throughout the year, so I don't think there could be any lumpiness there. I think as you repeated, we would expect first quarter expenses in 2016 to be higher than '15 reflecting the overall performance outlook expectation, higher revenue during that quarter from those business lines.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from David Darst with Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is from David Darst with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you speak to the continuous improvement program and probably where you think you are in percentage completion and what the expenses could be for the year?
componenttext: Could you speak to the continuous improvement program and probably where you think you are in percentage completion and what the expenses could be for the year?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: For continues improvement, I hope we're never done. So this is something we believe is part of our culture. We will continue to focus on that and we've just implemented a number of areas which created some of the charges we've had in the fourth quarter as
componenttext: For continues improvement, I hope we're never done. So this is something we believe is part of our culture. We will continue to focus on that and we've just implemented a number of areas which created some of the charges we've had in the fourth quarter as it relates to our private banking area and restructuring and so that's just 1 example of where we do deeper dives in the specific areas looking from everything from the customer interface all the way through the back office and making sure that we designed that in a way that can be more effective for that customer interaction but also more efficient from a cost perspective. So we would expect to see ongoing opportunities at a similar size from what we've been experiencing this year.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, from a private investing gains, what's your outlook for those and what's the balance of that portfolio?
componenttext: Okay. And then, from a private investing gains, what's your outlook for those and what's the balance of that portfolio?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: the principle investing gains as we've showed was 0 for the current quarter. Our outlook doesn't show very modest levels of gains for next year, so it will be a smaller level than clearly what we had throughout this year and the current balance is around
componenttext: the principle investing gains as we've showed was 0 for the current quarter. Our outlook doesn't show very modest levels of gains for next year, so it will be a smaller level than clearly what we had throughout this year and the current balance is around $300 million of investments and so we would see reductions from that balance just because we're about $450 million starting the year, so we're down about 2/3 the level we were a year ago.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to Marty Mosby with Vining Sparks.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to Marty Mosby with Vining Sparks.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, I wanted to ask you, you did a really good job with debt placement investment backing this quarter given all the disruptions in the marketplace, didn't really expect you to be kind of just blow through that like it had no impact. Are there any thin
componenttext: Chris, I wanted to ask you, you did a really good job with debt placement investment backing this quarter given all the disruptions in the marketplace, didn't really expect you to be kind of just blow through that like it had no impact. Are there any things using the horizon or anything that been happening that would put any pressure on the sense of being able to pull those deals through?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Marty. Obviously, we, like everybody else, are subjected to the markets and to the extent that the markets will continue as they have been in the last 2 or 3 weeks, our ability to pull through our pipeline, the yield through our pipeline would be le
componenttext: Sure, Marty. Obviously, we, like everybody else, are subjected to the markets and to the extent that the markets will continue as they have been in the last 2 or 3 weeks, our ability to pull through our pipeline, the yield through our pipeline would be less. We are really proud of the way we navigated what was a very choppy fourth quarter in the debt markets, we're really pleased that we've been able to distribute all the paper that we had. But to your point, if we were to face a very, very choppy markets going forward, that would have an impact and the first places you would see the impact would be in the M&A area and also you'd see obviously the related area in the financing areas.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: While the investment banking debt placement was good, trust and your investment was down in what typically would be an upturn in the back end of the year, Don. I was just curious, was that all market value related and would we see further impact as we mov
componenttext: While the investment banking debt placement was good, trust and your investment was down in what typically would be an upturn in the back end of the year, Don. I was just curious, was that all market value related and would we see further impact as we move into the first quarter given the first couple of weeks and compression we've seen in the market valuations?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The impact there was in 2 areas, 1 was some of that was commission revenue and that revenue was down this quarter, reflecting, some of the market related activities and the other piece was we did see some pressure on asset value which created some pressur
componenttext: The impact there was in 2 areas, 1 was some of that was commission revenue and that revenue was down this quarter, reflecting, some of the market related activities and the other piece was we did see some pressure on asset value which created some pressure on the revenues there. First quarter is not off to a great start as far as asset values and so I think that's an area that would continue to have some pressure throughout 2016 with our guidance mid-single-digit kind of growth reflected seeing some pressure in that area.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Geoffrey Elliott with Autonomous.
componenttext: And we'll go to Geoffrey Elliott with Autonomous.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doesn't it feel like some companies are starting to get a bit more nervous on the credit outlook. So what are the early indicators you typically look at to get a sense of what the credit might be turning a few quarters out and how they're performing?
componenttext: Doesn't it feel like some companies are starting to get a bit more nervous on the credit outlook. So what are the early indicators you typically look at to get a sense of what the credit might be turning a few quarters out and how they're performing?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Geoffrey, this is Bill Hartmann. So in our portfolio monitoring activities, we have a number of different metrics that we look at that we referred to as early warning indicators. Some of them are macro and we take a look at how those macro indicators migh
componenttext: Geoffrey, this is Bill Hartmann. So in our portfolio monitoring activities, we have a number of different metrics that we look at that we referred to as early warning indicators. Some of them are macro and we take a look at how those macro indicators might impact our portfolios by industry and by region and then, we also look at the performance of the companies themselves and in the conversations that our bankers are having about the way that the companies prepare themselves for changes in the economic environment. As Chris mentioned, one of the things that we're noticing and have noticed for a while is that many of these companies are being very conservative by carrying larger amounts of cash, would show up in the deposits that we have and they're also the growth in loans is not necessarily been with the customers that we have because they're not going at it investing in an environment that's only going at 2% to 3%.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I understand, you're saying that you think that higher cash balances give you more protection -- higher cash balances in the corporates give you more protection than you would have in prior corporate cycles? That's the message you're trying to get acro
componenttext: So I understand, you're saying that you think that higher cash balances give you more protection -- higher cash balances in the corporates give you more protection than you would have in prior corporate cycles? That's the message you're trying to get across?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think what we're seeing is that the customers themselves still a member of the last cycle and liquidity became extremely important in the way in which they manage themselves through a cycle and so by carrying larger cash balances, it gives them mor
componenttext: Yes, I think what we're seeing is that the customers themselves still a member of the last cycle and liquidity became extremely important in the way in which they manage themselves through a cycle and so by carrying larger cash balances, it gives them more of an ability to manage their companies successfully through the cycle which benefits us in their ability to survive.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to Peter Winter with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to Peter Winter with Sterne Agee.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Don, just 1 housekeeping item. The FDIC deposit insurance surcharge, just wondering I know it's proposed but what the impact could be for you guys?

componenttextpreview: There would be a slight impact. There wouldn't be significant to the overall expense base.
componenttext: There would be a slight impact. There wouldn't be significant to the overall expense base.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, is that included in the 4Q.
componenttext: Okay, is that included in the 4Q.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It will be included in our guidance, yes.
componenttext: It will be included in our guidance, yes.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question for E.J. Just on the community bank, just wondering if you could talk about the loan trends and what you're in small business loan demand?
componenttext: Just a question for E.J. Just on the community bank, just wondering if you could talk about the loan trends and what you're in small business loan demand?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: For small business? I would turn that to my partner, Dennis Devine. He has small business. I could talk to commercial banking which is kind of our lower end and middle market.
componenttext: For small business? I would turn that to my partner, Dennis Devine. He has small business. I could talk to commercial banking which is kind of our lower end and middle market.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll take both.
componenttext: Okay, I'll take both.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, both? First of all, in the commercial banking segment, we had a very good quarter from a loan production standpoint and then for the year, we've had good loan growth. We did see some clients pay us down in the quarter. They didn't pay us off, they j
componenttext: Okay, both? First of all, in the commercial banking segment, we had a very good quarter from a loan production standpoint and then for the year, we've had good loan growth. We did see some clients pay us down in the quarter. They didn't pay us off, they just paid us down and digging beneath those numbers and talking to clients we found as Bill alluded to earlier, they're carrying higher cash balances paying us down. So we feel pretty good going into the year around our pipelines. And then finally, the last thing I'd say is we talked for the past couple of quarters about the fact that we've hired a number of bankers across the franchise. Those bankers are ramping up and we're starting to see good production and new client acquisition from those bankers.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Small business would be comparable. The sentiment would be about the same. Our production has been up a little bit as much focused around our execution as anything else. The ability to deliver the small business clients is important and so both the capabi
componenttext: Small business would be comparable. The sentiment would be about the same. Our production has been up a little bit as much focused around our execution as anything else. The ability to deliver the small business clients is important and so both the capabilities, our branches, our business banking and some centralized capabilities we brought to market. So you see some year-over-year production increases against a relatively stable outlook as both E.J. and Chris have spoken to.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go to Matt Burnell with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go to Matt Burnell with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, just an administrative I guess, on the oil and gas portfolio. You mentioned what your outstanding exposures are. I'm curious what your commitments in that sector might be and whether or not they've changed much over the last quarter or last 12 mont
componenttext: Again, just an administrative I guess, on the oil and gas portfolio. You mentioned what your outstanding exposures are. I'm curious what your commitments in that sector might be and whether or not they've changed much over the last quarter or last 12 months?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Bill Hartmann. So our total commitments to the sector are approximately $3 billion. They have been coming down slightly over the last 12 months or so. I think that's your question.
componenttext: This is Bill Hartmann. So our total commitments to the sector are approximately $3 billion. They have been coming down slightly over the last 12 months or so. I think that's your question.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Beth, I noted your commentary about the initial days of the planning for the First Niagara acquisition and I guess, I'm just curious maybe as a matter of just a little bit of color. But are you suggesting that there could be, if not cost-savings
componenttext: And then, Beth, I noted your commentary about the initial days of the planning for the First Niagara acquisition and I guess, I'm just curious maybe as a matter of just a little bit of color. But are you suggesting that there could be, if not cost-savings above the $400 million that you've, targeted perhaps a fast ramp up of the cost-savings and are you suggesting that your level of confidence in terms of the potential revenue synergies is better than you guided when you went out the deal?

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt, I'll go ahead and talk about that. I do believe that our confidence in the cost-savings, both the path for some of the timing as I've talked about some of the third-party vendor contracts, other technology and operations largely being in and ou
componenttext: Yes, Matt, I'll go ahead and talk about that. I do believe that our confidence in the cost-savings, both the path for some of the timing as I've talked about some of the third-party vendor contracts, other technology and operations largely being in and outsource world gives us a fair amount of certainty around the cost as well as ability to realize savings in early days in the integration and as we look at our detailed planning which again is still early days but are planning would suggest we believe that there are more opportunities over and above the 400. So just in general as we firm up path and plans, I think we're feeling stronger and better and if we look at the revenue synergies, we quoted in our call that we had in late October around $300 million in revenue synergies was the number that we have put out there. Obviously with some offsetting costs on net numbers, less than that around 200. And I think what we're really seeing is more confidence around the places and the way that we would realize those revenue synergies. We see the complementary nature of our business model. They are accelerating plans within the mortgage space and as we look generally around the cultures and the product capability and their client base, we see -- are getting more confident about the path on revenue synergies.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: And we'll go to Kevin Barker with Piper Jaffray.

componenttext: And a follow up on some of her comments regarding commercial real estate and some of the regulatory concerns. componenttext: Sure, this is Chris. Specifically, Kevin, we're really focused on multifamily, class A multifamily. And some of the areas that we've identified are places like Houston, Raleigh, D.C., Boston, Denver, Seattle, just to name a few.

headline: KeyCorp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you seeing anything in regards to hotel sector or even retail?
componenttext: Are you seeing anything in regards to hotel sector or even retail?
