headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning and welcome to KeyCorp's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Beth Mooney, Chairman and CEO. Please go ahead, ma'am.
componenttext: Good morning and welcome to KeyCorp's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Beth Mooney, Chairman and CEO. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, and welcome to KeyCorp's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me for today's presentation is Don Kimble, our Chief Financial Officer; and available for our Q&A portion of the call is Bill Hartmann, our Ch
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning, and welcome to KeyCorp's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me for today's presentation is Don Kimble, our Chief Financial Officer; and available for our Q&A portion of the call is Bill Hartmann, our Chief Risk Officer.
Slide 2 is our statement on forward-looking disclosure and non-GAAP financial measures. It covers our presentation materials and comments as well as the question-and-answer segment of our call. 
I'm nor turning to Slide 3. Our first quarter results reflect momentum in our core businesses and continued progress on our strategic initiative despite a more challenging operating environment. Excluding merger-related expense, we generated positive operating leverage relative to the year-ago quarter and grew pre-provision net revenue by 6%. We also lowered our cash efficiency ratio for the first quarter to 64%. Revenue was up 3% from last year, driven by a 6% growth in net interest income. Average loans were up 5% from the year-ago period with the 12% increase in commercial, financial and agricultural loans. 
In our noninterest income, we saw year-over-year improvement in areas such as corporate services and cards and payments, reflecting investments that we had made in these businesses. Market sensitive businesses, such as investment banking and debt placement fees, were impacted by the weak Capital Market environment. Don will provide more detail and our outlook for our fee-based businesses in his comments. 
Credit quality measures this quarter were impacted by migration and our oil and gas portfolio, reflecting current market conditions, the rest of the loan portfolio continued to perform well and within our expectations with overall net charge-offs remaining below our targeted range. We maintained our strong capital position and subject to board approval, we struck an increase in a quarterly common stock dividend to $0.085 per share in May of this year. 
Slide 4  is an update on our First Niagara acquisition. We were very pleased that the shareholders of both companies approved the merger last month. This was an important step in the process and we appreciate the support of our shareholders. We also announced our community benefits plan, which is a comprehensive blueprint  for the community investments that we will be making over the next 5 years. This underscores our commitment to the areas we serve across our footprint. 
I have commented before about the cultural fit between Key and First Niagara and that continues to be evident in the way our 2 teams are working together. We have made significant progress in developing detailed business plans and our target environment, including talent assessment and selection. 
As we move forward, I'm even more confident in achieving our cost savings and revenue synergies and ultimately delivering on our commitment for valued creation for our shareholders. We continue to expect the acquisition to be accretive to earnings in 2017 and add 5% to EPS upon the full realization of cost savings. We also expect to increase our return on tangible common equity by 200 basis points, improve our cash efficiency ratio by 300 basis points and produce a solid return on invested capital. 
We look forward to completing the next stages of the approval process and continued to expect the acquisition to close in the third quarter of this year. Now I'll turn the call over to Don to discuss the details of our first quarter results. Don?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and I'm on Slide 6. First quarter net income from continuing operations was $0.24 per common share after adjusting for $24 million or $0.02 per common share with the expense related to the acquisition of First Niagara. This compared to $0.26 in
componenttext:
Thanks, and I'm on Slide 6. 
First quarter net income from continuing operations was $0.24 per common share after adjusting for $24 million or $0.02 per common share with the expense related to the acquisition of First Niagara. This compared to $0.26 in the year-ago period and $0.27 from the fourth quarter. As Beth mentioned, this quarter's results were negatively impacted by the migration in our oil and gas portfolio. The rest of our loan portfolio continued to perform well. 
Also worth noting is despite weak market conditions, our revenue was up 3% from the prior year. After excluding merger-related expense, pre-provision net revenue was up 6% and we generated positive operating leverage compared to the first quarter of last year. I will cover the other line items in the rest of my presentation so now, I'm turning over to Slide 7. 
Average loan balances were up $2.6 billion or 5% compared to the year-ago quarter and up $580 million from the fourth quarter. Our year-over-year growth was once again driven primarily by commercial, financial and agricultural loans and was broad-based across Key's business lending segments. 
Average CF&A loans were up $3.3 billion or 12% compared to the prior year and were up $706 million or 2% on annualized compared to the fourth quarter. 
Continued on to Slide 8. From the liability side of the balance sheet, average deposits, excluding deposits in foreign office, totaled $71.6 billion from the first quarter of 2016, an increase of $2.8 billion compared to the year-ago quarter. The year-over-year increase reflects growth in our commercial mortgage servicing business, inflows from commercial and consumer clients and growth in time deposits. Compared to the fourth quarter of 2015, average deposits excluding deposits in foreign office increased by $131 million. Growth in time deposits was largely offset by decline in the seasonal and short-term deposit inflows from commercial clients that we experienced during the fourth quarter. 
Turning to Slide 9. Taxable equivalent net interest income was $612 million for the first quarter of 2016 and the net interest margin was 2.89%. These results compared to the taxable equivalent net next income of $577 million and the net interest margin of 2.91% for the first quarter of 2015. The 6% increase in net interest income reflects higher earning asset balances and yields. The net interest margin remain relatively stable, benefiting from higher earning asset yields which were offset by higher levels of liquidity and various other items including lower loan fees. 
Compared to the fourth quarter of 2015, net interest income was relatively stable and the net interest margin increased by 2 basis points. The increase in the net interest margin was attributed to the higher earning asset balances and an increase in earning asset yields, which was largely the result of loan portfolio repricing to the higher short-term rates that resulted from the December rate price. The benefit of these items were partially offset by various other items including lower loan fees and lower yield on our Fed stocks. 
Slide 10 shows the summary of noninterest income, which accounted for 41% of total revenue. Noninterest income in the first quarter was $431 million, down $6 million or 1% from the prior year and $54 million or 11% from the prior quarter. The slight decrease from the prior year, which attributed to a lower net gains from principal investing of $29 million, which were offset by continued growth in several of our core fee-based businesses, reflecting our relationship strategy in the investments we have been making in our products and capabilities. 
Relative to a year-ago period, corporate services income was up 16%. Cards and payments was up 10% and service charges on deposit accounts increased by 7%. Compared to the last quarter, noninterest income was most notably impacted by weaker capital market activity, which resulted in $56 million on lower investment banking in debt placement fees. 
Turning to Slide 11. As you can see on the slide and as I mentioned earlier, reported noninterest expense of $703 million includes $24 million of expense related to the acquisition First Niagara. Excluding these costs, noninterest expense was $679 million for the quarter. We provided a detailed break out of our major-related expense in the appendix of the materials. 
Compared to the first quarter of last year and after adjusting for the merger-related expense, noninterest expense was up $10 million or 1%. The increase was primarily attributed to slight increases across various nonpersonnel areas. Excluding merger-related expense, link-quarter expenses were down $51 million or 7%. The decrease largely reflected lower performance-based compensation, marketing and business services and professional fees. 
Our cash efficiency ratio was 64% in the first quarter after adjusting for merger-related expense with results showing improvement from both the year-ago period and the linked quarter. 
Turning to Slide 12. As Beth mentioned earlier, credit quality measures were impacted by the migration in our oil and gas portfolio while the rest of the portfolio's continued to perform well. Our increased level of provision this quarter reflects the build in the reserves for oil  and gas credits to 8% of outstanding. 
Overall, net charge-offs were $46 million or 31 basis points of average loans in the first quarter. Which continues to be below our targeted range. First quarter provision for credit losses was $89 million, an increase of $54 million from the year-ago period and $44 million from the linked quarter. Nonperforming loans and nonperforming assets both increased relative to the prior quarter and year-ago period. 90% of the change was related to our oil and gas portfolio. 
At March 31, our reserves loan losses represented 1.37% of period end loans and 122% coverage of nonperforming loans. Despite this movement that we saw in the first quarter, our outlook for credit quality remains consistent for the remainder of the year with provision levels modestly exceeding that charge-offs which will support the continued loan growth. The allowance as a percentage of period in loans is anticipated to be relatively stable with our first quarter level. 
I'm turning to Slide 13. Our Common Equity Tier 1 ratio was strong at March 31, 2016, at 11.11%. We submitted our capital plan during the current quarter which included both common share repurchases and increased dividends. We look forward to sharing the results with you. 
As previously communicated, we plan to increase our common share dividend in the second quarter of this year by 13% subject to board approval. 
Moving on to Slide 14. Our 2016 outlook is for the stand-alone key operations and does not reflect the impact of First Niagara nor the merger-related expense. We have updated our guidance to reflect the first quarter results. Importantly, we continue to expect to drive positive operating leverage and our outlook for the remainder of the year has not changed. 
Average loans should grow in the mid-single digit range as we benefit from strength in our commercial businesses. We now anticipate net interest income growth in the low to mid-single digit percentage range compared to 2015 without any benefit from further rate increases. This increase in our outlook reflects the benefit from the December rate rise flowing through the bottom line. 
With the benefit of future rate increases, we would anticipate net interest income to be up in the mid-single digit range. It's important to note that we have assumed the deposit rates will increase with future rate increases. 
Noninterest income is expected to be up in the low to mid-single digit percentage range for the year, which primarily reflects weaker revenue from our market sensitive businesses in the first quarter. We continue to expect year-over-year growth in investment banking and debt placement fees as well as other core fee-based businesses where our investments are continuing to mature such as cards and payments. We are also assuming very modest levels of principal investing gains in 2016. Full year reported expenses, excluding merger-related expense, should be relatively stable in 2015. We continue to expect net charge-offs to remain below our target range of 40 to 60 basis points. We also expect provision levels to modestly exceed net charge-offs which will support our continued loan growth. The allowance of percentage of period end loans was anticipated to be relatively stable with our first quarter results. 
With that, I'll close and turn the call back over to the operator for instructions for the Q&A portion of our call. Shawn?

componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Matt. As far as the outlook for investment banking, the pipelines are strong for us and would expect to see significant increases going forward from that level that we experienced in the first quarter. And we have seen markets start to return to more normal levels and saw activities pick up and margin continuing to April. So we're optimistic that we'll see some strength going forward from that. As far as the other corporate services that includes FX, interest rate swaps, none loan fees that are not specific to the balance sheet and we would expect to see continued good activity in that category as well.

componenttext: If I could follow up on the expense side, Don, you're still holding out that guide for the stable year-over-year and positive operating leverage. Does anything change with regards to the progression of expenses given the slight change in mix that you're expecting now in terms of the kind of base outlook for revenue growth in terms of your ability to keep that operating leverage gap?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you look at the change in our outlook for revenues. It really is more reflective of what happened in the first quarter as opposed to what we would see prospectively. And so, we would expect to see the compensation related expenses go up in future quart
componenttext: If you look at the change in our outlook for revenues. It really is more reflective of what happened in the first quarter as opposed to what we would see prospectively. And so, we would expect to see the compensation related expenses go up in future quarter as we see those capital markets revenue start to return to the revenue generation for us, and so we would see increases there. We also typically would see marketing step up from the first quarter level in future periods as well. So we would think that we would see normal type of seasonal trends and expense levels will be consistent with the performance that we would be generating.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of John Pancari from Evercore.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of John Pancari from Evercore.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask a little bit more color around the margin. I appreciate the spread revenue guidance you gave us with and without rates. How would you think about the trajectory of the margin just given -- if you did not see any rate hikes and how shoul
componenttext: Just wanted to ask a little bit more color around the margin. I appreciate the spread revenue guidance you gave us with and without rates. How would you think about the trajectory of the margin just given -- if you did not see any rate hikes and how should we think about it through the year and going into '17?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just like last year, what we see is the major mover as far as our margin -- our relative liquidity that we have on our balance sheet and first quarter levels of liquidity were higher than what we would expect going into it and I'll tell you that right now
componenttext: Just like last year, what we see is the major mover as far as our margin -- our relative liquidity that we have on our balance sheet and first quarter levels of liquidity were higher than what we would expect going into it and I'll tell you that right now the second quarter is even higher than what we experienced in the first quarter. And so, where we see pressure on the margin, it's more from the ballooning up of that liquidity position on the balance sheet, that we are seeing poor performance in the other categories maintained and loan prices have stabilized across our footprint and -- so we would expect to have a relatively stable margin absent any changes in liquidity.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But is there a plan around that excess liquidity outside of just pure loan generation? Is there a plan around the loan book or anything?
componenttext: Okay. But is there a plan around that excess liquidity outside of just pure loan generation? Is there a plan around the loan book or anything?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, a lot of the excess liquidity comes from temporary funding from some of our commercial customers. And so, we continue to want to support those customers and will work through that. But right now, with interest rates being so low, it tends to be just
componenttext: Well, a lot of the excess liquidity comes from temporary funding from some of our commercial customers. And so, we continue to want to support those customers and will work through that. But right now, with interest rates being so low, it tends to be just more of a placement of that cash with us and we'll work through that over time. But right now, we're allowing that to come through and again, there really isn't much of a cost to us to maintain that. It's just that it does dilute the margin.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then one other question around the margin or really around revenue. Your expectation for mid-single digit growth if you do see higher interest rate, how would you define higher interest rates in that scenario?
componenttext: All right. And then one other question around the margin or really around revenue. Your expectation for mid-single digit growth if you do see higher interest rate, how would you define higher interest rates in that scenario?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That would include 2 rate increases throughout the rest of this year. So we're not expecting that to occur right now but that's what the best kind of assumption would be for that.
componenttext: That would include 2 rate increases throughout the rest of this year. So we're not expecting that to occur right now but that's what the best kind of assumption would be for that.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Ken Zerbe from Morgan Stanley.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the question is just in terms of the merger expenses. I see your guidance is excluding the merger expenses but could you just give us an update in terms of both the timing, throughout 2016 merger cost and the potential magnitude of these expenses?
componenttext: I guess the question is just in terms of the merger expenses. I see your guidance is excluding the merger expenses but could you just give us an update in terms of both the timing, throughout 2016 merger cost and the potential magnitude of these expenses?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Back in October when we announced the transaction, we said that we expected to see about $550 million of merger related expenses and that's still our current estimate, and we would expect that to accelerate between now and especially the systems con
componenttext: Sure. Back in October when we announced the transaction, we said that we expected to see about $550 million of merger related expenses and that's still our current estimate, and we would expect that to accelerate between now and especially the systems conversion and bank consolidations which would be -- we expect to occur later this calendar year. So sometime in the fourth quarter. So we would expect you to see increases again in the second quarter and then again in the third and then again in the fourth quarter. So the majority of them would be handled through, say middle of '17, but you will see an acceleration of those types of cost throughout the rest of the year.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from the line of Gerard Cassidy from RBC.
componenttext: The next question will come from the line of Gerard Cassidy from RBC.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Can you talk about the nonperforming assets. I understand the energy part you referenced like other banks, everybody had the big interest increase in the energy non-performers. Can you give us some color on the credit performance outside of energy because you indicated on Slide 12 that the nonperforming loan increase 90% of it was due to energy and the remaining obviously was due to other. Can you give some color on what the other was? I know it was relatively small, about $29 million but what do you guys are seeing outside of energy and delinquency trends?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Gerard. It's Bill Hartmann. What we've seen is a few what we call specific examples throughout the portfolio with no discernible trend in any area. So we talked in the past about when to start from the low base, any number kind of begins to look large
componenttext: Hi, Gerard. It's Bill Hartmann. What we've seen is a few what we call specific examples throughout the portfolio with no discernible trend in any area. So we talked in the past about when to start from the low base, any number kind of begins to look large. And so there's nothing that's any discernible trend and it's spread out.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow up to this, obviously the energy delinquency is a nonperforming should natural credit driven from what we're hearing from you and all your peers. Can you remind us how large is your traditional participation portfolio in SNCC with the
componenttext: And just as a follow up to this, obviously the energy delinquency is a nonperforming should natural credit driven from what we're hearing from you and all your peers. Can you remind us how large is your traditional participation portfolio in SNCC with the regular SNCC exam that's going on right now? How big of a portfolio's of SNCC do you have about?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gerard, I'll go ahead and take a first crack at this and let Bill provide additional color. But keep in mind as far as oil and gas, we applied the standards that came out from other regulators at the end of the quarter across our entire oil and gas portfo
componenttext: Gerard, I'll go ahead and take a first crack at this and let Bill provide additional color. But keep in mind as far as oil and gas, we applied the standards that came out from other regulators at the end of the quarter across our entire oil and gas portfolio. So even though our loans -- our agents haven't been subjected to the SNCC review, we do believe that we have applied this across the entire portfolio and as far as the oil and gas area that we do primarily just participate in facilities that are led by other agent banks but we do have broader relationships with those clients and still is consistent with our overall relationship strategy.

componenttext: This is actually Kyle [ph] Peterson speaking for Bob today. And kind of expand on the energy a little bit I notice the provision kind of picked up $89 million there to $89 million this quarter. Just to try to isolate what was kind of oil and gas first, the rest of the book is a good way to think about that as kind of the same ratios, the NPA uptick with 90% being related to oil and gas? Or it's kind of a another way we should get a handle around it?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: One way to think about it would be is that we maintain about 6% reserves at the end of the fourth quarter for total oil and gas. That's increased to 8% at the end of this quarter and we also had about $15 million worth of charge-offs in oil and gas in the
componenttext: One way to think about it would be is that we maintain about 6% reserves at the end of the fourth quarter for total oil and gas. That's increased to 8% at the end of this quarter and we also had about $15 million worth of charge-offs in oil and gas in the current quarter. And so that essentially provides a little bit more a follow up forward as to what drove the change there.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next question comes from the line of Mike Mayo from CLSA.
componenttext: And next question comes from the line of Mike Mayo from CLSA.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure if Chris Gorman is there to give us an update on First Niagara but on the downside, when you announced acquisition, there was a forecast from that rate hikes in First Niagara is asset sensitive, so I guess that's a negative. On the positive s
componenttext: I'm not sure if Chris Gorman is there to give us an update on First Niagara but on the downside, when you announced acquisition, there was a forecast from that rate hikes in First Niagara is asset sensitive, so I guess that's a negative. On the positive side, perhaps there's more of an expected cost savings there. Upstate New York has lower employment costs. So if you can talk about those ins and outs, please.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Don. You're right, Chris is met with us in a room and he is busy working through the integration of First Niagara. The rates have come down and you're absolutely right. We would have assessed that First Niagara's balance sheet position using our s
componenttext: This is Don. You're right, Chris is met with us in a room and he is busy working through the integration of First Niagara. The rates have come down and you're absolutely right. We would have assessed that First Niagara's balance sheet position using our same assumptions and balance sheet mix will be very comparable to where we work from asset sensitivity. So I don't know that it's disproportionate impact to First Niagara compared to what we would've thought before. As far as overall expense saves, as Beth mentioned earlier, we continue to be very confident in achieving our expense targets and us we talked before, our internal targets we've established are higher than what we said externally and that's what we're holding our teams accountable to and we'll provide more color as we play through that.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: How can you better capitalize on the lower cost employment base in Upstate New York? I mean, can you move jobs there? What are some of your options?
componenttext: How can you better capitalize on the lower cost employment base in Upstate New York? I mean, can you move jobs there? What are some of your options?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike. This is Beth and we are looking at the proximity of the 2 markets and how do we wear and how we perform work. And so there are moves afoot to look at leveraging both lower cost space, a very attractive workforce in terms of skills and tenure as
componenttext: Yes, Mike. This is Beth and we are looking at the proximity of the 2 markets and how do we wear and how we perform work. And so there are moves afoot to look at leveraging both lower cost space, a very attractive workforce in terms of skills and tenure as well as an attractive labor market from a cost point of you. So we are looking at balancing out where and how work is done as well as some of the efforts we had underway, for example, we were in the process of standing up our mortgage capabilities and giving that First Niagara had a full-fledged mortgage operation from origination through servicing. We will be building upon that in Buffalo. So we're doing a variety of things where we look at how to optimize the portfolio of locations, workforce, and skills in the way that I think would be beneficial to our cost synergy.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of David Eads from UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of David Eads from UBS.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can talk a little bit about what you're seeing in terms of deposit pricing and funding costs. We saw that kicked up a little bit this quarter, kind of across the board both on different deposit types and was that due to competition
componenttext: I was wondering if you can talk a little bit about what you're seeing in terms of deposit pricing and funding costs. We saw that kicked up a little bit this quarter, kind of across the board both on different deposit types and was that due to competition or how does that interplay with -- it does give you opportunities, I guess, to bring down funding cost given the strong deposit growth you guys are showing?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as our deposit funding cost, it really reflects from the mix change we saw on the current period and I would say that, that mix change is really driven by our efforts to make sure that we can continue to grow our core retail deposit base. And
componenttext: Yes, as far as our deposit funding cost, it really reflects from the mix change we saw on the current period and I would say that, that mix change is really driven by our efforts to make sure that we can continue to grow our core retail deposit base. And there's a lot of value for that not only from the LCR perspective but also from a core business perspective. And so during the past quarter to 2 quarters, we've been starting to implement some targeted programs to increase time deposits along with certain money markets type of products and had a lot of success and growing and keeping this year of all from those retail customers and when you expect to continue to do that. And so after those types of efforts, we would expect to see overall deposits remained relatively stable. I haven't seen much in the way of increased aggressive deposit pricing.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: I would say relatively stable and I think we were up 2 basis points linked quarter and so I would categorize that in that kind of almost relatively stable type of category.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Just on the commercial loan growth that's been a bit above some of your peers. I guess I'm curious where you're seeing the strongest growth and are there any areas where you might, within the portfolio, begin to think about pulling back over the course of this year?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as where we're seeing the growth, we've talked for the last year and a half about how we've been adding senior bankers not only in our Corporate Bank but also in a community bank and where we've been adding those bankers is where we're seeing that
componenttext: As far as where we're seeing the growth, we've talked for the last year and a half about how we've been adding senior bankers not only in our Corporate Bank but also in a community bank and where we've been adding those bankers is where we're seeing that incremental growth. And so, we're really seeing that from picking up new relationships and growing based on those investment we've been making. So we've been very pleased with that. As far as where we've been pulling back, we've talked in the past about certain markets where we are seeing multifamily housing and it's gotten a little overheated and therefore, we pulled back on that a little bit and we continue to reassess other areas of concern. But generally, that's been the area where we see the most adjustment.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: I guess I wanted drill down on the other areas of concern. Can you give a little more color there as to what parts of the portfolio you're referring to?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Bill Hartmann. So within the commercial portfolio, obviously, we've seen the impact on some of the manufacturing space with the strong dollar and some of the weakening economies. We don't see any problems occurring in it but the customers the
componenttext: Yes, this is Bill Hartmann. So within the commercial portfolio, obviously, we've seen the impact on some of the manufacturing space with the strong dollar and some of the weakening economies. We don't see any problems occurring in it but the customers themselves are not experiencing the kind of growth that would lead to lending opportunities for us to expand capacity. That's one area as an example of where we're seeing other weakness.

componenttext: I was hoping you could spend another moment or 2 just talking about the investment line. componenttext: We typically don't provide quarterly specific guidance but I would tell you that we would expect a meaningful increase from the first quarter levels to what we've seen in the next several quarters. And that's based on what you're seeing in the pipeline and based on overseeing in activity later in the quarter and continuing to the first part of this quarter. So I don't want to imply that it's going to be more than doubled from where it is in the current quarter. But we should see a meaningful increase their.

componenttext: Yes, Gerard. We are tracking, as you know, the approvals for the transaction will come  from Department of Justice who will be reviewing divestiture requirements for competitive purposes and then our 2 primary regulators, the Federal Reserves and the OCC, so we're working through the process very constructively and all that is on track and on the timeline that we would've anticipated to meet a third quarter closing for the transaction. And as it relates to other entities such as community groups, selected officials, we have been very present and had a lot of constructive dialogue. One important piece of this was the announcement of a community benefits plan that we were successful in entering into with the NCRC soon a national basis which is a significant milestone on the community group front and then across other constituents again dialogues have been constructive, proactive and against the parties who will approve that we are tracking against the expectations we set with the third quarter close.

componenttext: I just want to ask quickly about your asset sensitivity. I know you promised more swamps during the quarter and I know you have some running off at the end of the year. So if you can just comment on how you're planning on managing your asset sensitivity going at the back end of this year.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right now, we're right in that 2% to 3% kind of asset sensitive range, right around 2.5%. The swap increase reflects the increase in our LIBOR base loans and also the fact that we issued some CDs this quarter so we had increase in some of the fixed rate l
componenttext: Right now, we're right in that 2% to 3% kind of asset sensitive range, right around 2.5%. The swap increase reflects the increase in our LIBOR base loans and also the fact that we issued some CDs this quarter so we had increase in some of the fixed rate liabilities as well. And so, it was more just overall balance sheet management and making sure that we maintain in that general range and still believe it will probably continue to maintain somewhere in that 2% to 3% type of asset sensitive range for the rest of the year.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning and welcome to KeyCorp's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded.At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Beth Mooney, Chairman and CEO. Please go ahead, ma'am.
componenttext:
Good morning and welcome to KeyCorp's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded.
At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Beth Mooney, Chairman and CEO. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, and welcome to KeyCorp's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me for today's presentation is Don Kimble, our Chief Financial Officer; and available for our Q&A portion of the call is Bill Hartmann, our Ch
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning, and welcome to KeyCorp's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me for today's presentation is Don Kimble, our Chief Financial Officer; and available for our Q&A portion of the call is Bill Hartmann, our Chief Risk Officer.
Slide 2 is our statement on forward-looking disclosure and non-GAAP financial measures. It covers our presentation materials and comments as well as the question-and-answer segment of our call.
I'm now turning to Slide 3. Our first quarter results reflect momentum in our core businesses and continued progress on our strategic initiative despite a more challenging operating environment. Excluding merger-related expense, we generated positive operating leverage relative to the year-ago quarter and grew pre-provision net revenue by 6%. We also lowered our cash efficiency ratio for the first quarter to 64%. Revenue was up 3% from last year, driven by a 6% growth in net interest income. Average loans were up 5% from the year-ago period with a 12% increase in commercial, financial and agricultural loans.
In our noninterest income, we saw year-over-year improvement in areas such as corporate services and cards and payments, reflecting investments that we had made in these businesses. Market-sensitive businesses, such as investment banking and debt placement fees, were impacted by the weak capital market environment. Don will provide more detail and our outlook for our fee-based businesses in his comments.
Credit quality measures this quarter were impacted by migration in our oil and gas portfolio, reflecting current market conditions. The rest of the loan portfolio continue to perform well and within our expectations, with overall net charge-offs remaining below our targeted range. We maintained our strong capital position and subject to board approval, we've got an increase in our quarterly common stock dividend to $0.085 per share in May of this year.
Slide 4 is an update on our First Niagara acquisition. We were very pleased that the shareholders of both companies approved the merger last month. This was an important step in the process and we appreciate the support of our shareholders. We also announced our Community Benefits Plan, which is a comprehensive blueprint for the community investments that we will be making over the next 5 years. This underscores our commitment to the areas we serve across our footprint.
I have commented before about the cultural fit between Key and First Niagara, and that continues to be evident in the way our 2 teams are working together. We have made significant progress in developing detailed business plans and our target environment, including talent assessment and selection.
As we move forward, I'm even more confident in achieving our cost savings and revenue synergies and ultimately delivering on our commitment for value creation for our shareholders. We continue to expect the acquisition to be accretive to earnings in 2017 and add 5% to EPS upon the full realization of cost savings. We also expect to increase our return on tangible common equity by 200 basis points, improve our cash efficiency ratio by 300 basis points and produce a solid return on invested capital.
We look forward to completing the next stages of the approval process and continue to expect the acquisition to close in the third quarter of this year.
Now I'll turn the call over to Don to discuss the details of our first quarter results. Don?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and I'm on Slide 6.First quarter net income from continuing operations was $0.24 per common share after adjusting for $24 million or $0.02 per common share of expense related to the acquisition of First Niagara. This compared to $0.26 in the yea
componenttext:
Thanks, and I'm on Slide 6.
First quarter net income from continuing operations was $0.24 per common share after adjusting for $24 million or $0.02 per common share of expense related to the acquisition of First Niagara. This compared to $0.26 in the year-ago period and $0.27 in the fourth quarter. As Beth mentioned, this quarter's results were negatively impacted by the migration in our oil and gas portfolio. The rest of our loan portfolio continued to perform well.
Also worth noting is despite weak market conditions, our revenue was up 3% from the prior year. After excluding merger-related expense, pre-provision net revenue was up 6%, and we generated positive operating leverage compared to the first quarter of last year. I will cover the other line items in the rest of my presentation so now I'm turning to Slide 7.
Average loan balances were up $2.6 billion or 5% compared to the year-ago quarter and up $580 million from the fourth quarter. Our year-over-year growth was once again driven primarily by commercial, financial and agricultural loans and was broad-based across Key's business lending segments.
Average CF&A loans were up $3.3 billion or 12% compared to the prior year and were up $706 million or 2% on annualized compared to the fourth quarter.
Continuing on to Slide 8. On the liability side of the balance sheet, average deposits, excluding deposits in foreign office, totaled $71.6 billion for the first quarter of 2016, an increase of $2.8 billion compared to the year-ago quarter. The year-over-year increase reflects growth in our commercial mortgage servicing business, inflows from commercial and consumer clients and growth in time deposits. Compared to the fourth quarter of 2015, average deposits, excluding deposits in foreign office, increased by $131 million. Growth in time deposits was largely offset by decline in the seasonal and short-term deposit inflows from commercial clients that we experienced during the fourth quarter.
Turning to Slide 9. Taxable equivalent net interest income was $612 million for the first quarter of 2016 and the net interest margin was 2.89%. These results compare to the taxable equivalent net interest income of $577 million and a net interest margin of 2.91% for the first quarter of 2015. The 6% increase in net interest income reflects higher earning asset balances and yields. The net interest margin remained relatively stable, benefiting from higher earning asset yields, which were offset by higher levels of liquidity and various other items including lower loan fees.
Compared to the fourth quarter of 2015, net interest income was relatively stable and the net interest margin increased by 2 basis points. The increase in the net interest margin was attributed to the higher earning asset balances and an increase in earning asset yields, which was largely the result of loan portfolio repricing to the higher short-term rates that resulted from the December rate rise. The benefit of these items was partially offset by various other items, including lower loan fees and lower yield on our Fed stock.
Slide 10 shows the summary of noninterest income, which accounted for 41% of total revenue. Noninterest income in the first quarter was $431 million, down $6 million or 1% from the prior year and $54 million or 11% from the prior quarter. The slight decrease from the prior year was attributed to the lower net gains from principal investing of $29 million, which were offset by continued growth in several of our core fee-based businesses, reflecting our relationship strategy and the investments we have been making in our products and capabilities.
Relative to year-ago period, corporate services income was up 16%. Cards and payments was up 10% and service charges on deposit accounts increased by 7%. Compared to the last quarter, noninterest income was most notably impacted by weaker capital markets activity, which resulted in $56 million in lower investment banking and debt placement fees.
Turning to Slide 11. As you can see on the slide and as I mentioned earlier, reported noninterest expense of $703 million includes $24 million of expense related to our acquisition of First Niagara. Excluding these costs, noninterest expense was $679 million for the quarter. We provided a detailed break out of our merger-related expense in the appendix of the materials.
Compared to the first quarter of last year and after adjusting for the merger-related expense, noninterest expense was up $10 million or 1%. The increase was primarily attributed to slight increases across various nonpersonnel areas. Excluding merger-related expense, linked quarter expenses were down $51 million or 7%. The decrease largely reflected lower performance-based compensation, marketing and business services and professional fees.
Our cash efficiency ratio was 64% in the first quarter after adjusting for merger-related expense, with results showing improvement from both the year-ago period and the linked quarter.
Turning to Slide 12. As Beth mentioned earlier, credit quality measures were impacted by the migration in our oil and gas portfolio while the rest of the portfolio have continued to perform well. Our increased level of provision this quarter reflects the build in the reserves for oil and gas credit to 8% of outstanding.
Overall, net charge-offs were $46 million or 31 basis points of average loans in the first quarter, which continues to be below our targeted range. First quarter provision for credit losses was $89 million, an increase of $54 million from the year-ago period and $44 million from the linked quarter. Nonperforming loans and nonperforming assets both increased relative to the prior quarter and year-ago period as 90% of the change was related to our oil and gas portfolio.
At March 31, our reserve for loan losses represented 1.37% of period end loans and 122% coverage of our nonperforming loans. Despite this movement we saw in the first quarter, our outlook for credit quality remains consistent for the remainder of the year, with provision levels modestly exceeding net charge-offs which will support our continued loan growth. The allowance as a percentage of period end loans is anticipated to be relatively stable with our first quarter level.
I'm turning to Slide 13. Our common equity Tier 1 ratio was strong at March 31, 2016 at 11.11%. We submitted our capital plan during the current quarter which included both common share repurchases and increased dividends. We look forward to sharing the results with you.
As previously communicated, we plan to increase our common share dividend in the second quarter of this year by 13%, subject to board approval.
Moving on to Slide 14. Our 2016 outlook is for the stand-alone Key operations and does not reflect the impact of First Niagara nor the merger-related expense. We have updated our guidance to reflect the first quarter results. Importantly, we continue to expect to drive positive operating leverage and our outlook for the remainder of the year has not changed.
Average loans should grow in the mid-single digit range as we benefit from strength in our commercial businesses. We now anticipate net interest income growth in the low to mid-single digit percentage range compared to 2015 without any benefit from further rate increases. This increase in our outlook reflects the benefit from the December rate rise flowing through to the bottom line.
With the benefit of future rate increases, we would anticipate net interest income to be up in the mid-single digit range. It's important to note that we have assumed that deposit rates will increase with future rate increases.
Noninterest income is expected to be up in the low to mid-single digit percentage range for the year, which primarily reflects weaker revenue from our market-sensitive businesses in the first quarter. We continue to expect year-over-year growth in investment banking and debt placement fees as well as other core fee-based businesses where our investments are continuing to mature such as cards and payments. We are also assuming very modest levels of principal investing gains in 2016.
Full year reported expenses, excluding merger-related expense, should be relatively stable with 2015. We continue to expect net charge-offs to remain below our target range of 40 to 60 basis points. We also expect provision levels to modestly exceed net charge-offs which will support our continued loan growth. The allowance as a percentage of period end loans is anticipated to be relatively stable with our first quarter results.
With that, I'll close and turn the call back over to the operator for instructions for the Q&A portion of our call. Sean?

componenttext: Appreciate the full year commentary on the investment banking line and debt placement fees, but just maybe comment on what the pipeline is coming out of the quarter and the kind of near-term outlook for that business. And then I guess I always think about the corporate services line also being impacted by volume. So if you could talk to those 2 together, that might be best.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And thanks, Matt. As far as the outlook for investment banking, the pipelines are strong for us and would expect to see significant increases going forward from the level that we experienced in the first quarter. And we have seen markets start to re
componenttext: Sure. And thanks, Matt. As far as the outlook for investment banking, the pipelines are strong for us and would expect to see significant increases going forward from the level that we experienced in the first quarter. And we have seen markets start to return to more normal levels and saw activity pick up in March and continuing to April. So we're optimistic that we'll see some strength going forward from that. As far as the other corporate services, that includes FX, interest rate swaps, none -- loan fees that are not specific to the balance sheet, and we would expect to see continued good activity in that category as well.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: If I could just follow-up on the expense side, Don. You're still holding out that guide for the stable year-over-year and positive operating leverage. Does anything change with regards to the progression of expenses given the slight change in mix that you're expecting now in terms of kind of the base outlook for revenue growth in terms of your ability to keep that operating leverage gap?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you look at the change in our outlook for revenues. It really is more reflective of what happened in the first quarter as opposed to what we would see prospectively. And so we would expect to see the compensation-related expenses go up in future
componenttext: Well, if you look at the change in our outlook for revenues. It really is more reflective of what happened in the first quarter as opposed to what we would see prospectively. And so we would expect to see the compensation-related expenses go up in future quarters as we see those capital markets revenue start to return to the revenue generation for us, and so we would see increases there. We also typically would see marketing step up from the first quarter level in future periods as well. So we would think that we would see normal type of seasonal trends in expense levels will be consistent with the performance that we would be generating.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Pancari from Evercore.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Pancari from Evercore.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask a little bit more color around the margin. I appreciate the spread revenue guidance you gave us with and without rates. How would you think about the trajectory of the margin just given -- if you did not see any rate hikes and how we sh
componenttext: Just wanted to ask a little bit more color around the margin. I appreciate the spread revenue guidance you gave us with and without rates. How would you think about the trajectory of the margin just given -- if you did not see any rate hikes and how we should think about it through the year and going into '17?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just like last year, what we see as a major mover as far as our margin is our relative liquidity that we have on our balance sheet. And first quarter levels of liquidity were higher than what we would have expected going into it. And I'll tell you that ri
componenttext: Just like last year, what we see as a major mover as far as our margin is our relative liquidity that we have on our balance sheet. And first quarter levels of liquidity were higher than what we would have expected going into it. And I'll tell you that right now the second quarter is even higher than what we experienced in the first quarter. And so where we see pressure on the margin, it's more from the ballooning up of that liquidity position on the balance sheet that we're seeing core performance in the other categories maintained and loan prices have stabilized across our footprint. And so we would expect to have a relatively stable margin absent any changes in liquidity.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But is there a plan around that excess liquidity outside of just pure loan generation? Is there a plan around the loan book or anything?
componenttext: Okay. But is there a plan around that excess liquidity outside of just pure loan generation? Is there a plan around the loan book or anything?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, a lot of the excess liquidity comes from temporary funding from some of our commercial customers. And so we continue to want to support those customers and we'll work through that. But right now with interest rates being so low that it tends to be j
componenttext: Well, a lot of the excess liquidity comes from temporary funding from some of our commercial customers. And so we continue to want to support those customers and we'll work through that. But right now with interest rates being so low that it tends to be just more of a placement of that cash with us, and we'll work through that over time. But right now, we're allowing that to come through. And again, there really isn't much of a cost to us to maintain that, it's just that it does dilute the margin.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then one other question around the margin or really around spread revenue. Your expectation for mid-single digit growth if we do see higher interest rates, how would you define higher interest rates in that scenario?
componenttext: All right. And then one other question around the margin or really around spread revenue. Your expectation for mid-single digit growth if we do see higher interest rates, how would you define higher interest rates in that scenario?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That would include 2 rate increases throughout the rest of this year. So we're not expecting that to occur right now, but that's what the baseline assumption would be for that.
componenttext: That would include 2 rate increases throughout the rest of this year. So we're not expecting that to occur right now, but that's what the baseline assumption would be for that.

componenttextpreview: I guess the question is just in terms of the merger expenses. I see your guidance is excluding the merger expenses, but can you just give us an update in terms of both the timing throughout 2016 of merger cost and the potential magnitude of these expenses
componenttext: I guess the question is just in terms of the merger expenses. I see your guidance is excluding the merger expenses, but can you just give us an update in terms of both the timing throughout 2016 of merger cost and the potential magnitude of these expenses?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Back in October when we announced the transaction, we said that we expected to see about $550 million of merger-related expenses. That's still our current estimate. And we would expect that to accelerate between now and especially the systems conver
componenttext: Sure. Back in October when we announced the transaction, we said that we expected to see about $550 million of merger-related expenses. That's still our current estimate. And we would expect that to accelerate between now and especially the systems conversion and bank consolidations which would be -- we expect to occur later this calendar year. So some time in the fourth quarter. So we would expect you to see increases again in the second quarter and then again in the third and then again in the fourth. And so the majority of them would be handled through, say, middle of '17, but you will see an acceleration of those types of cost throughout the rest of the year.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question then will come from the line of Gerard Cassidy from RBC.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about the nonperforming assets? I understand the energy part that you referenced. Like other banks, everybody had the big increase in the energy nonperformers. Can you give us some color on the credit performance outside of energy because you
componenttext: Can you talk about the nonperforming assets? I understand the energy part that you referenced. Like other banks, everybody had the big increase in the energy nonperformers. Can you give us some color on the credit performance outside of energy because you indicated on Slide 12 that the nonperforming loan increase, 90% of it was due to energy and the remaining obviously was due to other. Can you give us some color on what the other was? I know relatively small at about $29 million, but what are you guys seeing outside of energy in delinquency trends?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Gerard. It's Bill Hartmann. So what we've seen is a few -- what we'll call situation-specific examples throughout the portfolio with no discernible trend in any area. So we've talked in the past about when you start from a low base, any number kind of
componenttext: Hi, Gerard. It's Bill Hartmann. So what we've seen is a few -- what we'll call situation-specific examples throughout the portfolio with no discernible trend in any area. So we've talked in the past about when you start from a low base, any number kind of begins to look large. And so there's nothing that's any discernible trend and it's spread out.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just as a follow-up to this. Obviously, the energy delinquency, the nonperformers were shared national credit-driven from what we're hearing from you and all your peers. Can you remind us how large is your traditional participation portfolio in S
componenttext: And then just as a follow-up to this. Obviously, the energy delinquency, the nonperformers were shared national credit-driven from what we're hearing from you and all your peers. Can you remind us how large is your traditional participation portfolio in SNCs with the regular SNC exam that's going on right now? How big of a portfolio of SNCs do you have about?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Gerard, I'll go ahead and take a first crack at this and then let Bill provide additional color. But keep in mind as far as oil and gas, we applied the standards that came out from the regulators at the end of the quarter across our entire oil and gas
componenttext: And Gerard, I'll go ahead and take a first crack at this and then let Bill provide additional color. But keep in mind as far as oil and gas, we applied the standards that came out from the regulators at the end of the quarter across our entire oil and gas portfolio. So even though our loans that we would agent haven't been subjected to the SNC review, we do believe that we have applied this across the entire portfolio. And as far as the oil and gas area that we do primarily just participate in facilities that are led by other agent banks, but we do have broader relationships with those clients and still is consistent with our overall relationship strategy.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Our next question then will come from the line of Bob Ramsey from FBR.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: This is actually Kyle Peterson speaking for Bob today. Kind of expanding on the energy a little bit, I notice that the provision kind of ticked up $89 million there to $89 million this quarter. Just to try to isolate what was kind of oil and gas versus the rest of the book, is a good way to think about that as kind of the same ratio as the NPA uptick with 90% being related to oil and gas or is kind of there another way we should kind of get a handle around it?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: One way to think about it would be is that we maintain about 6% reserves at the end of the fourth quarter for total oil and gas. That's increased to 8% at the end of this quarter. And we also had about $15 million worth of charge-off in oil and gas in the
componenttext: One way to think about it would be is that we maintain about 6% reserves at the end of the fourth quarter for total oil and gas. That's increased to 8% at the end of this quarter. And we also had about $15 million worth of charge-off in oil and gas in the current quarter. And so that essentially provides a little bit more of a walk forward as to what drove the change there.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question then will come from the line of Mike Mayo from CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question then will come from the line of Mike Mayo from CLSA.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure if Chris Gorman's there to give us an update on First Niagara. But on the downside, when you announced the acquisition, there is a forecast for more Fed rate hikes and First Niagara is asset sensitive, so I guess that's a negative. On the pos
componenttext: I'm not sure if Chris Gorman's there to give us an update on First Niagara. But on the downside, when you announced the acquisition, there is a forecast for more Fed rate hikes and First Niagara is asset sensitive, so I guess that's a negative. On the positive side, perhaps there's more than expected cost savings there since Upstate New York has lower employment costs. So if you can talk about those ins and outs, please.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. This is Don. And you're right, Chris is not with us in the room. And then he's busy working through the integration with First Niagara. But the rates have come down, you're absolutely right. And we would have assessed that First Niagara's bala
componenttext: Sure, Mike. This is Don. And you're right, Chris is not with us in the room. And then he's busy working through the integration with First Niagara. But the rates have come down, you're absolutely right. And we would have assessed that First Niagara's balance sheet position using our same assumptions and balance sheet mix will be very comparable to where we were from an asset sensitivity. So I don't know that it's disproportionate impact to First Niagara compared to what we would have thought before. As far as overall expense saves, as Beth mentioned earlier, we continue to be very confident in achieving our expense targets. And as we've talked before, our internal targets we've established are higher than what we've said externally, and that's what we're holding our teams accountable to and look to provide more color as we play through that.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: How can you better capitalize on the lower cost employment base in Upstate New York? I mean, can you move jobs there? What are some of your options?
componenttext: How can you better capitalize on the lower cost employment base in Upstate New York? I mean, can you move jobs there? What are some of your options?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike. This is Beth. And we are looking at the proximity of the 2 markets and how do we -- where and how we perform work. And so there are moves afoot to look at leveraging both lower cost space, a very attractive workforce in terms of skills and tenu
componenttext: Yes, Mike. This is Beth. And we are looking at the proximity of the 2 markets and how do we -- where and how we perform work. And so there are moves afoot to look at leveraging both lower cost space, a very attractive workforce in terms of skills and tenure as well as an attractive labor market from a cost point of view. So we are looking at balancing out where and how work is done as well as some of the efforts we had underway. For example, we were in the process of standing up our mortgage capabilities and given that First Niagara had a full-fledged mortgage operation from origination through servicing, we will be building upon that in Buffalo. So we're doing a variety of things where we look at how to optimize the portfolio of locations, workforces and skills in a way that I think will be beneficial to our cost synergy.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question then comes from the line of David Eads from UBS.
componenttext: And our next question then comes from the line of David Eads from UBS.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about what you're seeing in terms of deposit pricing and funding cost. We saw that tick up a little bit this quarter kind of across the board both on different deposit types and kind of how -- was that due to
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about what you're seeing in terms of deposit pricing and funding cost. We saw that tick up a little bit this quarter kind of across the board both on different deposit types and kind of how -- was that due to competition or how does that interplay with -- it does give you opportunities, I guess, to bring down funding cost given the strong deposit growth you guys are showing?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as our deposit funding cost, it really reflects from the mix change we saw in the current period. And I would say that, that mix change is really driven by our efforts to make sure that we can continue to grow our core retail deposit base. And
componenttext: Yes, as far as our deposit funding cost, it really reflects from the mix change we saw in the current period. And I would say that, that mix change is really driven by our efforts to make sure that we can continue to grow our core retail deposit base. And there's a lot of value for that, not only from the LCR perspective, but also from a core business perspective. And so during the past quarter to 2 quarters, we've been starting to implement some targeted programs to increase time deposits along with certain money market type of products and had a lot of success in growing and deepening the share of wallet for those retail customers and would expect to continue to do that. And so absent those types of efforts, we would expect the overall deposits remain relatively stable and haven't seen much in the way of increased aggressive deposit pricing.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you expect that deposit cost to be kind of stable from here assuming no more rate hike?
componenttext: Do you expect that deposit cost to be kind of stable from here assuming no more rate hike?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say relatively stable, and I think we were up 2 basis points linked quarter. And so I would categorize that as in that kind of almost relatively stable type of category.
componenttext: I would say relatively stable, and I think we were up 2 basis points linked quarter. And so I would categorize that as in that kind of almost relatively stable type of category.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the commercial loan growth, that's been a bit above some of your peers. I guess I'm curious where you're seeing the strongest growth and are there any areas where you might, within that portfolio, begin to think about pulling back over the course
componenttext: Just on the commercial loan growth, that's been a bit above some of your peers. I guess I'm curious where you're seeing the strongest growth and are there any areas where you might, within that portfolio, begin to think about pulling back over the course of this year?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as where we're seeing the growth, we've talked for the last 1.5 years about how we've been adding senior bankers not only in our corporate bank, but also in our community bank. And where we've been adding those bankers is where we're seeing that in
componenttext: As far as where we're seeing the growth, we've talked for the last 1.5 years about how we've been adding senior bankers not only in our corporate bank, but also in our community bank. And where we've been adding those bankers is where we're seeing that incremental growth. And so we're really seeing that from picking up new relationships and growing the book based on those investments we've been making. So we've been very pleased with that. As far as where we've been pulling back, we've talked in the past about certain markets where we see in the multifamily housing that it's gotten a little overheated and therefore, we pulled back on that a little bit and we continue to reassess other areas of concern. But generally, that's been the area where we've seen the most adjustment.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: I guess I want to drill down on the other areas of concern. Can you give a little more color there as to what parts of the portfolio are you referring to?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Bill Hartmann. So within the commercial portfolio, obviously, we've seen the impact in some of the manufacturing space with the strong dollar and some of the weakening economies. We don't see any problems occurring in it, but the customers th
componenttext: Yes, this is Bill Hartmann. So within the commercial portfolio, obviously, we've seen the impact in some of the manufacturing space with the strong dollar and some of the weakening economies. We don't see any problems occurring in it, but the customers themselves are not experiencing the kind of growth that would lead to lending opportunities for us to expand capacity. That's one area as an example of where we're seeing other weakness.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Our next question then will come from the line of Scott Siefers from Sandler O'Neill.

componenttext: Don, I was hoping you could spend another moment or 2 just talking about the IB and debt placement line. If I kind of correctly, it sounds like you still expect positive year-over-year growth from that line. So one, did I catch that correctly? And then I guess the crux of the question is, it implies that we're going to have, to have a really forceful snapback, obviously. I think you'd have to average somewhere around $125 million or so per quarter in revenues. Can you talk about sort of the pace of that build? In other words, do we nearly double here in the 2Q or is this going to be sort of a slow build throughout the course of the year?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We typically don't provide quarterly specific guidance, but I will tell you that we would expect a meaningful increase from the first quarter levels to what we would see in the next several quarters. And that's based on what we're seeing from our pipeline
componenttext: We typically don't provide quarterly specific guidance, but I will tell you that we would expect a meaningful increase from the first quarter levels to what we would see in the next several quarters. And that's based on what we're seeing from our pipeline and based on what we're seeing in activity later in the quarter and continuing in the first part of this quarter. So I don't want to imply that it's going to be more than doubled from where it is in the current quarter, but we should see a meaningful increase there.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a follow-up for you, Beth. Can you give us a flavor for the time line? Obviously, you guys plan to close the deal in the third quarter. I know there was some objections by the Governor of New York to the transaction. Can you give us any color on ho
componenttext: I have a follow-up for you, Beth. Can you give us a flavor for the time line? Obviously, you guys plan to close the deal in the third quarter. I know there was some objections by the Governor of New York to the transaction. Can you give us any color on how the progress is going to overcome these objections, particularly that one and to get that closing date in the third quarter?

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Gerard. We are tracking, as you know, the approval for the transaction will come from Department of Justice who would be reviewing divestiture requirements for competitive purposes and then our 2 primary regulators, the Federal Reserve and the OCC. S
componenttext: Yes, Gerard. We are tracking, as you know, the approval for the transaction will come from Department of Justice who would be reviewing divestiture requirements for competitive purposes and then our 2 primary regulators, the Federal Reserve and the OCC. So we are working through the process there very constructively and all that is on track and on the time line that we would have anticipated to meet a third quarter closing for the transaction. And as it relates to other entities such as community groups, elected officials, we have been very present and had a lot of constructive dialogue. One important piece of this was the announcement of our Community Benefits Plan that we were successful in entering into with the NCRC on a national basis, which is a significant milestone on the community group front. And then across other constituents, again, dialogues have been constructive, proactive. And against the parties who will approve it, we are tracking against the expectations we set with the third quarter close.

componenttext: Just want to ask quickly about your asset sensitivity. I noticed you put on some more swaps during the quarter and I know you have some rolling off at the end of the year. So if you could just comment on how you -- I guess, how you're planning on managing your asset sensitivity going into the back end of this year.

headline: KeyCorp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right now, we're right in that 2% to 3% kind of asset sensitive range, right around 2.5%. The swap increase reflects the increase in our LIBOR-based loans and also the fact that we issued some CDs this quarter so we had an increase in some of the fixed-ra
componenttext: Right now, we're right in that 2% to 3% kind of asset sensitive range, right around 2.5%. The swap increase reflects the increase in our LIBOR-based loans and also the fact that we issued some CDs this quarter so we had an increase in some of the fixed-rate liabilities as well. And so it was more just overall balance sheet management and making sure that we maintain in that general range and still believe that we'll probably continue to maintain somewhere in that 2% to 3% type of asset sensitive range for the rest of the year.
