headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The biggest impact there is really some growth that we've seen in some of our consumer retail CD growth rates. And so you're seeing that go from what was a portfolio that was shrinking to a portfolio that's been growing. We do believe that having a strong
componenttext: The biggest impact there is really some growth that we've seen in some of our consumer retail CD growth rates. And so you're seeing that go from what was a portfolio that was shrinking to a portfolio that's been growing. We do believe that having a strong retail of core funded bank is important for us. But we'll continue to reassess programs going forward in that area.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Matt O'Connor from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next question is from Matt O'Connor from Deutsche Bank.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you guys could elaborate a little bit on the drop in NIM outside of liquidity, and then what gives you the confidence in growing the stand-alone net interest income dollars in the back half of the year versus the first half? Obviously it's in
componenttext: I was hoping you guys could elaborate a little bit on the drop in NIM outside of liquidity, and then what gives you the confidence in growing the stand-alone net interest income dollars in the back half of the year versus the first half? Obviously it's in some ways a new point to be combining with First Niagara. But you did mention you expect dollars to increase on a stand-alone basis. So just any more visibility and clarity on what's driving that after bigger drop in NIM this quarter?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, as far as the net interest income and margin, there's a couple of factors that impacted outside the liquidity. So as we talked therefore, 7 basis points is the increased liquidity level, which really didn't drive any net interest income from it. So
componenttext: Matt, as far as the net interest income and margin, there's a couple of factors that impacted outside the liquidity. So as we talked therefore, 7 basis points is the increased liquidity level, which really didn't drive any net interest income from it. So that was purely a balance sheet component. The rest of it were up 5 basis points. Typically in the second quarter we would see an increase in loan fees. And this quarter, we actually saw a decline. And so that swing from what our original expectations would've been to what we actually realized cost us about 3 basis points or about $5 million in the quarter compared to what we would have expected going into the quarter. And then beyond that, we had 2 other components that impacted it, one was the full quarter impact of the nonaccrual loans related to oil and gas, and then a third piece really was the reinvestment in our investment portfolio. But the securities that we were buying had an average yield of about 1.9% compared to, say, 20 or 30 basis points higher than that. That would've been our expectation and that probably caused us an additional basis point during the quarter. And so those are the primary factors. As far as the growth going forward, while we're not counting on recouping the loan fees that we didn't realize in the current quarter, we would expect to see some normal trends as far as seasonal activity and continued strong loan growth that we've been able to produce so far this year.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just separately, with respect to the timing of the cost saves, you mentioned most of them or majority of them will come in 2017. Should we think about -- well, how should we think about the ramp in terms of throughout the ye
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just separately, with respect to the timing of the cost saves, you mentioned most of them or majority of them will come in 2017. Should we think about -- well, how should we think about the ramp in terms of throughout the year? I guess, there's a lot of them come after the systems conversion. But what will be the timing of say early versus lateral part of the year on the cost save recognition?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would suggest that we'll see some cost saves occur post the conversion, which we talked about being in the fourth quarter. But the majority of those cost saves would be phased in throughout 2017. So that in the second half of the year, we'd have th
componenttext: Yes, I would suggest that we'll see some cost saves occur post the conversion, which we talked about being in the fourth quarter. But the majority of those cost saves would be phased in throughout 2017. So that in the second half of the year, we'd have the majority of those cost saves in place and should be at a full run rate by the end of the year.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Scott Siefers with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question is from Scott Siefers with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the cost savings, obviously one of the higher profile disclosures recently was the agreement to keep more jobs in New York. I'm wondering if -- obviously, you've reiterated the cost-saving expectation. You have the higher internal target, but just
componenttext: Just on the cost savings, obviously one of the higher profile disclosures recently was the agreement to keep more jobs in New York. I'm wondering if -- obviously, you've reiterated the cost-saving expectation. You have the higher internal target, but just hoping you could provide a little color on -- if there are going to be more jobs than you would have anticipated, originally in New York for example, where do you make up the negative delta that you would've expected originally? And whether it's just sort of nature of FNFG cost base, certain switches you can turn off to make the cost go away? How does that work out in your guidance then?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, this is Beth. And I will tell you it is consistent with the way we have been planning for both our internal targets as well as you heard us discuss, our confidence about being able to meet the cost synergies. Some piece of how we have structured br
componenttext: Scott, this is Beth. And I will tell you it is consistent with the way we have been planning for both our internal targets as well as you heard us discuss, our confidence about being able to meet the cost synergies. Some piece of how we have structured bringing these 2 companies together is around the notion that we can leverage what is an attractive, well skilled, low-cost workforce in Buffalo and in Western New York. So we are looking at -- we indicated in sourcing some functions or work that is done elsewhere, not necessarily just within First Niagara but within broader KeyCorp, and that work could be moved to Buffalo and utilized, as I said, that low-cost talent base. We also looked at some of our operations network within, and we'll consolidate those into Western New York and bring down costs or jobs elsewhere within Key. And then the biggest driver over time for the job number is what we talked about was the fact that they have residential mortgage from originations through servicing as well as the indirect auto business, both of which, one was a business we were trying to stand up with Key and one that was new to Key. And that we will build on those businesses within Western New York as we scale on the cost of our broader franchise, which we expect will create opportunities for many folks in Western New York to support that and the corresponding revenue that we would expect again as we introduced that to the broader Key franchise and there will be some leverage on the call center capabilities. So as we look at it, again it is a portfolio of businesses between Key and First Niagara and there were some opportunities to really leverage Western New York. But consistent with how we've thought of our expense synergies, we get there in a very, very solid path through the ability to look at in sourcing growth. And as we look at the mix of the 400 [ph] and Don will have some thoughts to add to this as well, a big, big driver of that is vendor savings. There is the outsourced technology environment at First Niagara is a huge driver of the 400 [ph]. And then as we look at additional outsourcing to bring that work back in, we really are being able to get a huge piece of that pass through exiting third-party relationships.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I agree, Beth. The other thing I would add is part of difference of external target of $400 million and our internal target, a large portion of that is related to this third-party vendor cost that Beth talked about, and believe that should be a true savin
componenttext: I agree, Beth. The other thing I would add is part of difference of external target of $400 million and our internal target, a large portion of that is related to this third-party vendor cost that Beth talked about, and believe that should be a true savings for us.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to Ken Zerbe with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to Ken Zerbe with Morgan Stanley.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question, on Page 14, you mentioned the bond incremental amortization expense of $30 million related to First Niagara. Easy question, which is I assume that is annual amortization expense. And then the other question is, on a short-term basis, espec
componenttext: Quick question, on Page 14, you mentioned the bond incremental amortization expense of $30 million related to First Niagara. Easy question, which is I assume that is annual amortization expense. And then the other question is, on a short-term basis, especially over the next 5 months of this year, is it possible that the amortization -- higher amortization expense actually is sort of just an outright negative on earnings before you have the opportunity to really meaningfully start to reduce First Niagara's core expenses, or are there other expense savings you plan to do very, very short-term that might offset the $30 million of amortization?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, as far as the $30 million of amortization, we're assuming that it's going on an accelerated basis, and that's the first 5 months impact from that only. And so it will be incremental expense, and to your point, that will be a drag on the initial earni
componenttext: Ken, as far as the $30 million of amortization, we're assuming that it's going on an accelerated basis, and that's the first 5 months impact from that only. And so it will be incremental expense, and to your point, that will be a drag on the initial earnings compared to what we would expect after the benefit of the realization of the cost saves. And so that was one piece, I want to make sure that was clear.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Ken Usdin with Jefferies.
componenttext: And we'll go to Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could a little bit more on the expense side. This quarter, the other expense line at $104 million core was much higher than kind of historical run rates. Can you help us understand what the real estate side was and what you would ex
componenttext: I was wondering if you could a little bit more on the expense side. This quarter, the other expense line at $104 million core was much higher than kind of historical run rates. Can you help us understand what the real estate side was and what you would expect that to look like on a more normal basis?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, on that item, you're right, the majority of increase related to that. We had a $708 [ph] million increase in other expenses associated with what I would consider to be grossing up the revenue and expenses associated with certain partnerships we had
componenttext: Again, on that item, you're right, the majority of increase related to that. We had a $708 [ph] million increase in other expenses associated with what I would consider to be grossing up the revenue and expenses associated with certain partnerships we had in Light Tech investments. That was highly unusual and we would expect a normal recurring level to be in the $1 million to $2 million a quarter as opposed to $7 million to $8 million. And so that did inflate that expense category and that's why we're showing a significant increase there.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just as far as back half, you normally do have or you have the last couple of years the pension charges in the third and fourth quarter. Do you expect that to recur again, or is that now in the past?
componenttext: Just as far as back half, you normally do have or you have the last couple of years the pension charges in the third and fourth quarter. Do you expect that to recur again, or is that now in the past?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we do have that risk, that our outlook right now would suggest that there is an exposure for that maybe in the fourth quarter as opposed to the third quarter right now. But one of the other benefits we expect is that when you can merge the 2 pension
componenttext: Well, we do have that risk, that our outlook right now would suggest that there is an exposure for that maybe in the fourth quarter as opposed to the third quarter right now. But one of the other benefits we expect is that when you can merge the 2 pension plans from First Niagara and from Key, that would minimize that risk prospectively. And so we never want to say one and done, but hopefully this would be a period where we might have expense and see that not recur in the future periods.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I could, just one quick one on credit. You mentioned in the guidance that you expect the allowance to be stable with the last quarter. Did that allowance actually build up as a percentage of loans this quarter? It looks like you've moved from the
componenttext: Okay. If I could, just one quick one on credit. You mentioned in the guidance that you expect the allowance to be stable with the last quarter. Did that allowance actually build up as a percentage of loans this quarter? It looks like you've moved from the unfunded to the over provision. And I'm just wondering, the credit looks great underneath the surface. So from here is it more just about reserving a bit for loan growth? Or is there anything underneath the surface in credit that we should think about?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing underneath the surface. You're right, we did see migration out of the reserve for unfunded loans into the allowance, and those 2 kind of worked hand-in-hand as far as loans would fund up previously commitments. You might see transfer from the unfu
componenttext: Nothing underneath the surface. You're right, we did see migration out of the reserve for unfunded loans into the allowance, and those 2 kind of worked hand-in-hand as far as loans would fund up previously commitments. You might see transfer from the unfunded loan commitment over to the overall allowance. And I would also say that our judgmental portion of the reserve also increased this quarter. And so we feel very comfortable with a level of reserve we have and do believe that, respectively, the provision will slightly exceed the net charge-offs to make sure we continue to provide for loan growth.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Matt Burnell from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Your next question is from Matt Burnell from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, first a question for you. I wanted to follow-up on I guess Bill's earlier commentary about the construction numbers in the CRE portfolio. Overall CRE numbers were up about 10%, 11% annualized quarter-over-quarter, with 30% decline year-over-year in t
componenttext: Don, first a question for you. I wanted to follow-up on I guess Bill's earlier commentary about the construction numbers in the CRE portfolio. Overall CRE numbers were up about 10%, 11% annualized quarter-over-quarter, with 30% decline year-over-year in the construction portfolio. Has that kind of reached a bottom as to where you want that to be ex-FNFG? And how should we think about commercial real estate growth going forward?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: As Bill noted, where we're seeing that growth is more on income-producing properties as opposed to development type of lending. And so we did see some increase there and are very comfortable with that type of an exposure and risk profile for the credits w
componenttext: As Bill noted, where we're seeing that growth is more on income-producing properties as opposed to development type of lending. And so we did see some increase there and are very comfortable with that type of an exposure and risk profile for the credits we're putting on. And you're right, next quarter we'll see a change here because of the acquisition of First Niagara. Anything else you want to add, Bill?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think that covers it, Don.
componenttext: No. I think that covers it, Don.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just as a follow up. It looks like your exposure in terms of overall amounts in nonaccruals in oil and gas was stable and down a bit respectively. Can you provide any additional color in terms of how you're thinking about that portfolio and the
componenttext: Okay. And just as a follow up. It looks like your exposure in terms of overall amounts in nonaccruals in oil and gas was stable and down a bit respectively. Can you provide any additional color in terms of how you're thinking about that portfolio and the trajectory of nonaccruals going forward? I realize it's price dependent, but any additional color you could provide would be helpful.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Bill Hartmann. So what we've been seeing happen is a couple of things going on, the borrowing base redetermination was largely complete this quarter. And we saw a little bit of a reduction, obviously, as a result of adjustments to the borrow
componenttext: Sure. This is Bill Hartmann. So what we've been seeing happen is a couple of things going on, the borrowing base redetermination was largely complete this quarter. And we saw a little bit of a reduction, obviously, as a result of adjustments to the borrowing base as a result of the redetermination. The second thing that we're seeing is that there have been some bankruptcies in the space. The resolution of those bankruptcies are resulting in some reductions in exposure. We continue to see that as a positive, going forward. And then lastly, with prices up a little bit, we are seeing the cash flows improve at some of the borrowers. And as a result of that, they're reducing some of their outstandings.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just finally for me, Don, if I can. The merger-related expenses were higher than we were thinking about. I presume, however, that the overall timing of the merger-related charges will be concentrated in the second half of this year with a little
componenttext: And then just finally for me, Don, if I can. The merger-related expenses were higher than we were thinking about. I presume, however, that the overall timing of the merger-related charges will be concentrated in the second half of this year with a little bit in 2017 as you previously guided. Correct?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct. We had talked before about a total onetime charge of $550 million for merger-related costs. And we do believe that a significant portion of those will be in the second half of this year.
componenttext: That's correct. We had talked before about a total onetime charge of $550 million for merger-related costs. And we do believe that a significant portion of those will be in the second half of this year.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we go to Gerard Cassidy with RBC.
componenttext: Next, we go to Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you guys remind us, of the $400 million in cost savings, how does that break out by personnel, occupancy, outside vendors systems, et cetera? And is it different post the agreement with New York than what it was prior when you first announced the deal
componenttext: Can you guys remind us, of the $400 million in cost savings, how does that break out by personnel, occupancy, outside vendors systems, et cetera? And is it different post the agreement with New York than what it was prior when you first announced the deal?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as the $400 million, the largest piece that we did disclose is about 40% of that was related to third-party vendors or $160 million. But we also talked about was that we expected to see significant opportunities from branch consolidations. And
componenttext: Yes, as far as the $400 million, the largest piece that we did disclose is about 40% of that was related to third-party vendors or $160 million. But we also talked about was that we expected to see significant opportunities from branch consolidations. And as we announced here earlier this month that we expected to consolidate approximately 70 branches of First Niagara and a little over 30 of Key. So about 25% incremental consolidation related to that, and so that will also drive a significant portion. But beyond that, we really haven't provided a lot of color as far as how much is personnel related. I would say that with our discussions here and announcement as far as the New York staffing plans, I don't know that's changed what our initial plans have been significantly. But again, we're looking for a lot of opportunity from the third-party vendors saves. And it's just an issue to where the work is being performed as opposed to whether or not it's changed the overall plan.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, the third-party vendor, that did increase now versus the original $400 million when you guys first outlined those cost savings?
componenttext: I'm sorry, the third-party vendor, that did increase now versus the original $400 million when you guys first outlined those cost savings?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we talked about is our internal targets is higher than $400 million. And a big portion of that increase is related to third-party vendors as opposed to other categories.
componenttext: What we talked about is our internal targets is higher than $400 million. And a big portion of that increase is related to third-party vendors as opposed to other categories.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. And just to go back, Don, to your comment about liquidity, your margin obviously was impacted as you pointed out in the quarter by the increase in liquidity. But I thought you said that we should expect your liquidity levels to go back to where the
componenttext: I see. And just to go back, Don, to your comment about liquidity, your margin obviously was impacted as you pointed out in the quarter by the increase in liquidity. But I thought you said that we should expect your liquidity levels to go back to where they were prior to the first quarter. If that's true, should the margin then benefit from the lower liquidity levels that you expect going forward?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Margin should benefit from lower liquidity levels. Now at the same time, we are going to be adding First Niagara on top of our balance sheet and margin impact. So there will be some noise that we'll have to walk you through next quarter as to how they all
componenttext: Margin should benefit from lower liquidity levels. Now at the same time, we are going to be adding First Niagara on top of our balance sheet and margin impact. So there will be some noise that we'll have to walk you through next quarter as to how they all combine and what the impact is. But we should see a benefit to margin, not a huge change in net interest income, but a benefit to margin as liquidity levels return to more normal levels.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to Marlin Mosby with Vining Sparks.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to Marlin Mosby with Vining Sparks.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, I wanted to ask you a little bit about the compression on earning asset yields. When you look at the core portfolios of the loans and securities, they were only down a couple basis points. But if you look at the trading account and you look at the lo
componenttext: Don, I wanted to ask you a little bit about the compression on earning asset yields. When you look at the core portfolios of the loans and securities, they were only down a couple basis points. But if you look at the trading account and you look at the loans held for sale, trading account was down over 100 basis points and loans held for sale were down 80. So was there some noise or activity in those portfolios because that's what drove a lot of earning asset yield compression in those 2 smaller accounts?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, one, the loans held for sale were also were impacted by the fact there was a lower level of loans held for sale during the quarter than what we had in the previous quarter. So that was a bigger driver. The trading account dropped by about [ph] $1 mil
componenttext: Yes, one, the loans held for sale were also were impacted by the fact there was a lower level of loans held for sale during the quarter than what we had in the previous quarter. So that was a bigger driver. The trading account dropped by about [ph] $1 million [ph] as far as net interest income and that really wasn't huge driver to the overall net interest income, but there was a different mix of those assets in the first quarter than what we have in the second quarter. But the biggest driver there, Marty, really is if you look at the next line below that, which is our short-term investments, and it's up to $5.6 billion and that's primarily our account at the Fed. And that's up by $2.1 billion from the previous quarter and up by $2.3 billion over the previous year and that $2-plus billion equated to a 7 basis point reduction in our margin. And so it was just a ballooning up of the balance sheet related to that.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was excluding the extra liquidity. When you look at the quarter, there's a couple of things that you're doing in preparation for bringing First Niagara on. You suspended your share repurchase, which you get to start back. You raised debt and now you've
componenttext: I was excluding the extra liquidity. When you look at the quarter, there's a couple of things that you're doing in preparation for bringing First Niagara on. You suspended your share repurchase, which you get to start back. You raised debt and now you've increased liquidity. On my estimate, it's probably $0.01 or $0.02 in bottom line impact that's just kind of sitting there waiting to get utilized as you kind of move over into the next stage which is post the closing of the acquisition.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of things there. You're right, we did raise some debt and that will help with the funding cost. And our funding of First Niagara acquisition, that was anticipated as part of the cost of First Niagara. And so we didn't expect that to be incurred i
componenttext: A couple of things there. You're right, we did raise some debt and that will help with the funding cost. And our funding of First Niagara acquisition, that was anticipated as part of the cost of First Niagara. And so we didn't expect that to be incurred in our position for that. And then we're also glad to start our share buyback program, again, and that will be helpful to our earnings per share and to continue to support our shareholders from that perspective.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And consistent with our guidance all year, we have been positioning the company, the balance sheet, our plans for [indiscernible] first quarter close. And so right after CCAR results, shortly thereafter was our approval from the Federal Reserve. So yes, a
componenttext: And consistent with our guidance all year, we have been positioning the company, the balance sheet, our plans for [indiscernible] first quarter close. And so right after CCAR results, shortly thereafter was our approval from the Federal Reserve. So yes, a lot of these were conscious choices about timing to be positioned for First Niagara.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I'm really getting at is there was a temporary pressure on earnings the quarter before you actually didn't get the benefit. So there's kind of a timing here that you have to make all those choices knowing that you're going to get the benefit once the
componenttext: What I'm really getting at is there was a temporary pressure on earnings the quarter before you actually didn't get the benefit. So there's kind of a timing here that you have to make all those choices knowing that you're going to get the benefit once the acquisition comes in.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, you're absolutely right.
componenttext: No, you're absolutely right.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Mike Mayo with CLSA.
componenttext: And we'll go to Mike Mayo with CLSA.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on Slide 4, pretty straight forward. Your target, I think it's unchanged, right? The RTC 200 basis points higher and the cash efficiency ratio at 300 basis points higher. Is that correct, it's unchanged?
componenttext: Just a question on Slide 4, pretty straight forward. Your target, I think it's unchanged, right? The RTC 200 basis points higher and the cash efficiency ratio at 300 basis points higher. Is that correct, it's unchanged?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so what is the specific target? Higher than what? Higher than 2015? Higher than the first half of '16? Higher than the second quarter of '16? What's the comparison? And so what is the actual numerical target?
componenttext: And so what is the specific target? Higher than what? Higher than 2015? Higher than the first half of '16? Higher than the second quarter of '16? What's the comparison? And so what is the actual numerical target?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now for both those ratios, it's the incremental benefit from the First Niagara transaction compared to Key on a stand-alone basis. And so compared to where our projections would show us on a stand-alone basis versus where we would be with First Niagara. N
componenttext: Now for both those ratios, it's the incremental benefit from the First Niagara transaction compared to Key on a stand-alone basis. And so compared to where our projections would show us on a stand-alone basis versus where we would be with First Niagara. Now what we had talked about before was that if rates did not improve, Key on a stand-alone basis for the efficiency ratio would drive down to the low 60s. And with the impact of first Niagara, it will be in the high 50s. And so that again without interest rates, interest rates did come through, it would again have additional benefits beyond that.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the RTCE?
componenttext: And the RTCE?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't disclosed what our target levels are there. So in our ROTCE is right now in that 9% level. And so we would hope to continue to build that prospectively and show an incremental benefit from the First Niagara transaction of that 200 basis point r
componenttext: We haven't disclosed what our target levels are there. So in our ROTCE is right now in that 9% level. And so we would hope to continue to build that prospectively and show an incremental benefit from the First Niagara transaction of that 200 basis point range we talked about.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean for the investors in the outside, it's nice to have something to hold management accountable to. And so let's assume there's a bake going on, some people like the acquisition, some don't. In the end, we'll look at the results and it would be nice t
componenttext: I mean for the investors in the outside, it's nice to have something to hold management accountable to. And so let's assume there's a bake going on, some people like the acquisition, some don't. In the end, we'll look at the results and it would be nice to have some sort of bogey that we can all look at together. Is there any more specifics you can give us let's say on the ROTCE. We can't see what you Key is likely to do on a stand-alone basis based on your projections, but it would be helpful. Any other color you could give would be great.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's go ahead and reflect on that and see what kind of additional detail we provided. I think we did provide detail as it relates to the efficiency ratio, but part of that return on Tangible Common Equity 2 will be impacted by some of those mark-to-marke
componenttext: Let's go ahead and reflect on that and see what kind of additional detail we provided. I think we did provide detail as it relates to the efficiency ratio, but part of that return on Tangible Common Equity 2 will be impacted by some of those mark-to-market on the balance sheet and other purchase accounting adjustments and we want to make sure we can clarify what component relates to each of those pieces. So let's do that for you, Mike, and we'll get back to you.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a related question. So there's no change to your targets, we hear you saying that the Cost savings feel good, the revenue synergies feel good. But since October 30 of last year when you announced the deal, the expectation for rate increases reall
componenttext: And then a related question. So there's no change to your targets, we hear you saying that the Cost savings feel good, the revenue synergies feel good. But since October 30 of last year when you announced the deal, the expectation for rate increases really has come down and that would hurt First Niagara, which was somewhat asset sensitive. So why do you still feel okay about your targets the same feeling about your targets even though the outlook for First Niagara wouldn't be as good?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well one, First Niagara was asset-sensitive. But as we look at what running their information through our models, the asset sensitivity wasn't much outside of where we are today and where we were back in October. We also took a look at this transaction fo
componenttext: Well one, First Niagara was asset-sensitive. But as we look at what running their information through our models, the asset sensitivity wasn't much outside of where we are today and where we were back in October. We also took a look at this transaction for, if rate increases did occur and also if rate increases did not occur, and we still saw that kind of incremental lift for what we saw for the combined company compared to Key on a stand-alone basis. And so that's why we think there truly is a benefit from this. And we're very confident in our ability to achieve those incremental improvements we talked about. Beth, anything you want to add?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike. Those thing I would tell you in a lower and slower environment, which I think is the consensus of the macro environment that we find ourselves in, I do think it's an attractive proposition to be able to extract cost synergies and then the confi
componenttext: Yes, Mike. Those thing I would tell you in a lower and slower environment, which I think is the consensus of the macro environment that we find ourselves in, I do think it's an attractive proposition to be able to extract cost synergies and then the confidence for building new clients, the resulting revenue opportunities, I believe that it is a value proposition of both, the merger is solid and it creates  a lever in an environment where headwinds and levers are hard to come by.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go to David Long with Raymond James.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go to David Long with Raymond James.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys mentioned that short-term inflows from commercial clients impacted your deposit growth in the quarter, maybe had an impact on the NIM. So related to that, what are you expecting on the run off there, the duration? And maybe more importantly, what
componenttext: You guys mentioned that short-term inflows from commercial clients impacted your deposit growth in the quarter, maybe had an impact on the NIM. So related to that, what are you expecting on the run off there, the duration? And maybe more importantly, what are you hearing from clients and your commercial clients? And what drove that short-term inflow in deposits?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: A big chunk of that really was coming from some of our escrow deposits we had with our commercial servicing business, and also some other escrow-related deposits we've had for other commercial clients. Some of that is seasonally related, as you would see
componenttext: A big chunk of that really was coming from some of our escrow deposits we had with our commercial servicing business, and also some other escrow-related deposits we've had for other commercial clients. Some of that is seasonally related, as you would see some of the real estate taxes and other things that we build up throughout the first half of the year and paid down. So we would expect to see some of those go down. But we also had several situations where there would be prepayments in the commercial mortgage servicing area that had cash idle for weeks at a time, and that resulted in some over or outsized increases in those deposit balances. As far as our commercial customers, we're still seeing and hearing from them that they continue to be fairly cautious. And so we believe they continue to part liquidity with the expectation that they will be using that at some point in time, but really not in a mode to significantly change their overall position as far as investment. So we are seeing a little bit of additional build there as well.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we go to David Eads with UBS.
componenttext: Next, we go to David Eads with UBS.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up on some of the commentary about preparing for First Niagara to come over. Has there been any change in the strategy in the securities book? Also on the legacy Key book and expectations for restructuring the First Niagara book once it com
componenttext: Just following up on some of the commentary about preparing for First Niagara to come over. Has there been any change in the strategy in the securities book? Also on the legacy Key book and expectations for restructuring the First Niagara book once it comes over given the lower rate?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we talked before at the time of the acquisition was that First Niagara has $3.5 billion worth of credit-oriented securities in different asset classes. And First Niagara has not been required to maintain the LCR compliance. And so in order to make su
componenttext: What we talked before at the time of the acquisition was that First Niagara has $3.5 billion worth of credit-oriented securities in different asset classes. And First Niagara has not been required to maintain the LCR compliance. And so in order to make sure that they are LCR compliant as part of Key, our plans are to shift out that $3.5 billion of credit-oriented securities and have their investment portfolio look more like legacy Key. And so that process would take place throughout the third quarter, and we believe we'll be in a good position at that point in time. As far as Key, we have been continuing to reassess our overall strategy as far as the duration of the portfolio given these low rates and the timing of certain purchases. But the composition and nature of that portfolio really hasn't changed over the last couple of quarters.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And with the reinvestment of the First Niagara, the credit oriented ones, you still look to reinvest that kind of similar duration to the current portfolio?
componenttext: And with the reinvestment of the First Niagara, the credit oriented ones, you still look to reinvest that kind of similar duration to the current portfolio?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Kevin Barker with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: And we'll go to Kevin Barker with Piper Jaffray.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we transition into the back -- into 4Q and then into first half of next year, do you expect loan growth to slow down on a consolidated basis as you let some of the First Niagara portfolios run off that do not fit the profile that you would like for Key
componenttext: As we transition into the back -- into 4Q and then into first half of next year, do you expect loan growth to slow down on a consolidated basis as you let some of the First Niagara portfolios run off that do not fit the profile that you would like for Key? And would you continue to expect interest-bearing deposits to increase to meet LCR requirements post First Niagara acquisition?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kevin, maybe first as far as LCR and the deposit shift, we are in very good position from an LCR perspective for both Key and combination with First Niagara. And so we do not believe that we're going to see an ongoing shift as far as the overall deposits
componenttext: Kevin, maybe first as far as LCR and the deposit shift, we are in very good position from an LCR perspective for both Key and combination with First Niagara. And so we do not believe that we're going to see an ongoing shift as far as the overall deposits category. We do believe over time, especially as rates start to pick up, that we'll see some continued growth in time deposits compared to money market deposits, but we don't believe that will be meaningful. As far as the loan growth, we've been very pleased with the portfolio that First Niagara has. And we're continuing to work with their teams in making sure that we are in position post our conversion time period and do not see any significant change in the overall mix composition or any cycle change in the overall growth rates related to that. Bill, anything else you want to add to that?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just add that as part of my due diligence process, we spent a significant amount of time looking at FFO portfolios, looking at their underwriting standards and looking at their mix of clients. And that was part of the attractiveness that we found
componenttext: I would just add that as part of my due diligence process, we spent a significant amount of time looking at FFO portfolios, looking at their underwriting standards and looking at their mix of clients. And that was part of the attractiveness that we found in First Niagara. So I would not expect, to use your phrase, a run off in the portfolio due to a change in strategy.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our final question will be from Geoffrey Elliott with Autonomous Research.
componenttext: Our final question will be from Geoffrey Elliott with Autonomous Research.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you give a bit more color on the change in the outlook on noninterest income? What's behind that?
componenttext: Could you give a bit more color on the change in the outlook on noninterest income? What's behind that?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only change we really have there is that the second quarter's fee income reflected a lower level of capital markets related revenue than what we would expect coming into the quarter as a result of that and the year-to-date results, we've adjusted the
componenttext: The only change we really have there is that the second quarter's fee income reflected a lower level of capital markets related revenue than what we would expect coming into the quarter as a result of that and the year-to-date results, we've adjusted the outlook to reflect that. headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to KeyCorp Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Beth Mooney, Chairman and CEO. Please go ahead, ma'am.
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to KeyCorp Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded. 
At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Beth Mooney, Chairman and CEO. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, and welcome to the KeyCorp's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me for today's presentation is Don Kimble, our Chief Financial Officer; and available for our Q&A portion of the call is Bill Hartmann, o
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning, and welcome to the KeyCorp's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me for today's presentation is Don Kimble, our Chief Financial Officer; and available for our Q&A portion of the call is Bill Hartmann, our Chief Risk Officer. 
Slide 2 is our statement on forward-looking disclosure and non-GAAP financial measures. It covers our presentation materials and comments as well as the question-and-answer segment of our call. 
I'm now turning to Slide 3. Our second quarter results reflect continued momentum in our core businesses and the progress we have made to complete the acquisition of First Niagara on August 1. Excluding merger-related charges, we generated positive operating leverage and improved pre-provision net revenue relative to the year-ago period. Revenue was stable with the same period last year and up 3% from the last quarter despite low interest rates and challenging market conditions. Loan growth was solid again this quarter, driven by a 12% increase in average commercial, financial and agricultural loans. Our core fee-based businesses continued to perform well, with corporate services and cards and payment both posting double-digit year-over-year gain. Market-sensitive businesses, including investment banking and debt placement fees, improved from last quarter but are below the record pace of the year-ago period. Commercial mortgage banking continues to generate strong growth while other areas are being impacted by challenging market conditions. Don will provide more detail in our outlook for our fee-based businesses in his comments.
Expenses have remained well controlled and our ongoing efficiency efforts have allowed us to continue to invest to drive growth. Credit quality was a good story once again, with our net charge-offs to average loans remaining below our targeted level. And capital management remains an area of focus. We increased our quarterly common dividend to $0.085 per share or 13% during the quarter and we were pleased to receive no objection from the Federal Reserve on our 2016 capital plan. We expect to resume common share repurchases after we complete our acquisition, and subject to board approval, we plan to increase our common share dividend to $0.095 per share next year. 
Now I'm turning to Slide 4. We're very excited to be on a path to close our First Niagara acquisition, which is expected on August 1. The merger of KeyBank and First Niagara Bank is planned for the fourth quarter, subject to the approval by the OCC. We would also expect systems and client conversions to take place during the fourth quarter. Additionally, we recently announced the plans for our combined branch network, including the consolidation of over 100 existing First Niagara and Key branches. We also plan to continue to invest and grow in New York, which will include in-sourcing some functions and our build-out of the First Niagara's residential mortgage and auto lending businesses to support our broader franchise. I've been extremely pleased with the way our 2 companies have worked together to position us to be successful in meeting our commitments to clients, communities, employees and shareholders. And I remain confident in, and committed to, achieving our financial targets and creating value for our shareholders in this slow growth, low rate environment. The combination of Key and First Niagara accelerates our performance beyond what either company could have otherwise achieved. We continue to expect the acquisition to be accretive to earnings in 2017 and add 5% to EPS upon the full realization of cost savings. We also expect to increase our return on tangible common equity by 200 basis points, improve our cash efficiency ratio by 300 basis points and produce a solid return on invested capital. 
And as I've said before, our internal target for cost savings is higher than our external target of $400 million, and developments this quarter have only reinforced our confidence in achieving our commitments. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Don to discuss the details of our second quarter results. Don?

headline: KeyCorp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Beth. I'm on Slide 6. Second quarter net income from continuing operations was $0.27 per common share after excluding $0.04 of merger-related expense. This compares to $0.27 per share in the year-ago period and $0.24 in the first quarter, which
componenttext:
Thanks, Beth. I'm on Slide 6. 
Second quarter net income from continuing operations was $0.27 per common share after excluding $0.04 of merger-related expense. This compares to $0.27 per share in the year-ago period and $0.24 in the first quarter, which excluded $0.02 of merger-related expense. As Beth mentioned, excluding merger expense, we grew pre-provision net revenue and generated positive operating leverage relative to the year-ago quarter. Revenue was stable from the same period last year and up 3% from the first quarter despite the headwinds from low interest rates and the challenging market conditions. Core expenses were well managed. Our efficiency ratio, adjusted for merger expense, was 64.8%. I'll cover many of these items on this slide and the rest of my presentation, so I'm now turning to Slide 7. 
Average loan balances were up $3.2 billion or 5% compared to the year-ago quarter and up $1 billion or 2% from the first quarter. Our year-over-year growth was once again driven primarily by commercial, financial and agricultural loans and was broad-based across Key's business lending segments. Average CF&A loans were up $3.6 billion or 12% compared to the prior year and were up $1 billion or 3% on annualized for the first quarter. 
Continuing to Slide 8. Average deposits, excluding deposits in foreign office, totaled $73.9  billion for the second quarter of 2016, an increase of $3.6 billion compared to the year-ago period. The year-over-year increase primarily reflects core deposit growth in our retail banking franchise, higher escrow deposits from our commercial mortgage servicing business and commercial deposit inflows. Compared to the first quarter of 2016, average deposits increased by $2.3 billion. Higher escrow balances, short-term inflows from our commercial clients and core deposit growth in our retail banking franchise contributed to the linked-quarter increase.
Turning to Slide 9. Taxable-equivalent net interest income was $605 million for the second quarter of 2016, and net interest margin was 2.76%. These results compare to a taxable equivalent net interest income of $591 million and a net interest margin of 2.88% for the second quarter of 2015. The 2% increase in net interest income reflects higher earning asset balances and yields, partially offset by lower reinvestment yields from the securities and derivatives portfolio. Compared to the first quarter of 2016, net interest income was down 1% and net interest margin decreased 13 basis points. The net interest margin reduction in the second quarter was driven by excess liquidity, which was a function of 3 things, the first two of which related to our upcoming First Niagara acquisition. First, we retained higher cash balances needed for funding the First Niagara purchase price and branch divestiture. Second, liquidity was held to position our balance sheet to put LCR compliance following the close of the acquisition. And third, during the quarter, we had elevated levels of short-term escrow deposits, some of which are seasonal. Higher levels of liquidity translated into a $2.1 billion linked-quarter increase in our account at the Federal Reserve, which resulted in a 7 basis point decline in our net interest margin. The average balances for the quarter of $5.6 billion was well above the historic levels of approximately $1 billion. 
Slide 10 shows the summary of noninterest income, which accounted for 44% of total revenue. Noninterest income in the second quarter was $473 million, down $15 million or 3% from the prior year and up $42 million or 10% from the prior quarter. The decrease from the prior year was largely attributed to lower investment banking and debt placement fees. Although we saw growth in commercial mortgage banking fees, it was more than offset by weaker market conditions resulting in lower revenue compared to the prior year -- excuse me, year-ago record quarter. In the second half of the year, we expect good overall growth in investment banking and debt placement fees, more in line with our original outlook for the business. We saw continued growth and momentum in a number of our core fee-based businesses, reflecting investments we made over the last few years. Corporate services income was up 23% and cards and payments income was up 11% from the year-ago period. We've also seen a positive trend in service charges on deposit accounts. The growth in other income reflected a number of items, including higher gains from real estate investment -- real estate-related investments. Compared to the first quarter, noninterest income was most notably impacted by $27 million in higher investment banking and debt placement fees. We also saw growth across various other line items, including cards and payments, corporate services, service charge on deposit accounts and net gains from principal investing.
Turning to Slide 11. As you can see in this slide, reported noninterest expense of $751 million includes $45 million of expense related to our acquisition of First Niagara. Excluding these costs, noninterest expense was $706 million for the quarter. We have provided a detailed break out of our merger-related expense in the appendix of our materials. Compared to the second quarter of last year and after adjusting for merger-related expense, noninterest expense was down $5 million or 1%. The decline reflects lower performance-based compensation, occupancy and business services and professional fees, which were partially offset by higher expense related to certain real estate investments and increased nonmerger-related marketing. Excluding the merger-related expense, linked-quarter expenses were up $27 million or 4%. The increase is primarily in nonpersonnel, including other expense and nonmerger-related marketing. The quarter also reflected an increase in personnel expense related to higher performance-based compensation. 
Turning to Slide 12. Overall net charge-offs were $43 million or 28 basis points of the average total loans in the second quarter, which continues to be below our targeted range. Second quarter provision for credit losses was $52 million, an increase of $11 million in the year-ago period and a decrease of $37 million from a linked-quarter. Nonperforming loans and nonperforming assets both increased relative to the year-ago period but decreased from the prior quarter. At June 30, 2016, our total reserve for loan losses represented 1.38% of period-end loans and a 138% coverage of nonperforming loans. Our outlook for credit quality remains consistent for the remainder of the year, with provision levels modestly exceeding net charge-offs which will support our continued loan growth. We continue to anticipate the allowance as a percentage of period-end loans to be relatively stable with our second quarter level.
Turning to Slide 13. Our Common Equity Tier 1 ratio at the end of the second quarter was 11.1%, up from 10.7% in the year-ago period. As Beth highlighted, disciplined capital management remains a priority for us. Last month, we announced a 13% increase on our quarterly common share dividend. We were also pleased to receive no objection from the Federal Reserve on our 2016 capital plan, which included up to $350 million in share purchases and an additional increase to our common share dividend next year subject to board approval.
Moving on to Slide 14. The top portion of the slide provides our 2016 outlook for standalone Key, excluding merger-related expense. We have updated our guidance to reflect the second quarter results. Despite continued headwinds from our lower interest rates and more challenging market conditions, we continue to expect to drive positive operating leverage. Consistent with our prior outlook, we expect average loans to grow in the mid-single digit range driven by continued strength in our commercial businesses. Net interest income growth should be in the low to mid-single digit range compared to 2015 without any benefit from higher interest rates. We expect net interest income to be higher in the second half of the year compared to both the first half of this year and a year-ago period. Our guidance now reflects the weaker capital markets conditions experienced in the first half of this year. Importantly, our expectations for the second half of this year remain in line with our original outlook. Based on this, we expect noninterest income to be relatively stable to up low single digits for the year. 
Full year reported expenses, excluding merger-related expense, should be relatively stable with 2015. We continue to expect net charge-offs to be below our targeted range of 40 to 60 basis points. We also expect provision levels to be modestly -- to modestly exceed net charge-offs which will support our continued loan growth. The allowance as a percentage of period-end loans is anticipated to be relatively stable with our second quarter level. 
We've also included some guidance for the expected impact of First Niagara, which is scheduled to close next week on August 1. Branch and systems conversions are anticipated for the fourth quarter, after which we expect to begin to see the cost savings. We expect majority of the benefit to be realized in 2017. Revenue and expense should be generally consistent with the First Niagara's first quarter operating results, included in their 10-Q adjusted for the 5-month period they would be part of Key. Expenses will also reflect approximately $30 million of incremental amortization expense in 2016. 
Key's share count will also increase by about 240 million shares from the acquisition. 
As Beth said, we are excited about the opportunity to bring these 2 companies together and our confidence in delivering our financial commitments remain strong. 
With that, I'll close and turn the call back over to the operator for instructions for the Q&A portion of the call. John?
