headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to KeyCorp.'s Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Beth Mooney, Chairman and CEO. Please go ahead, ma'am.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to KeyCorp.'s Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Beth Mooney, Chairman and CEO. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning and welcome to KeyCorp's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me for today's presentation is Don Kimble, our Chief Financial Officer; and available for the Q&A portion of the call is Bill Hartmann, our Chi
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning and welcome to KeyCorp's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me for today's presentation is Don Kimble, our Chief Financial Officer; and available for the Q&A portion of the call is Bill Hartmann, our Chief Risk Officer. 
Slide 2 is our statement on forward-looking statements and non-GAAP financial measure, and covers our presentation materials and comments as well as the question-and-answer segment of our call. I'm now turning to Slide 3. Third quarter was pivotal for our company in terms of both financial results and executing our strategy. We successfully closed our acquisition of First Niagara, adding over $35 billion in assets, 300 new branches and $1 million new customers to Key and while a lot of time and resources have been devoted to making sure our acquisition and conversion went smoothly, we've also stayed focus on maintaining the momentum in our core businesses. Importantly, both our community back and Corporate Bank delivered strong results this quarter. And Don will cover our outlook in his remarks, but let me just say, we remain confident in meeting our commitments, including the achieving the financial targets for our acquisition. 
I am now moving to Slide 4. Before I provide highlights of our quarter, I do want to share that throughout our presentation, we have provided important details and transparency for key stand-alone operations and the impact of our acquisitions. As we move forward, we will be reporting consolidated results with Key and First Niagara combined. But this quarter, we thought it would be useful to provide additional detail. Slide 4 provides some highlights for stand-alone Key and the strong performance we saw this quarter. Our Community Bank and Corporate Bank are performing well and we are realizing benefit from the investments we have made in recent years. As shown in our recent earnings release, we reported EPS of $0.16 and it is $0.30, excluding the impact of merger-related charges. First Niagara operations were relatively neutral to our EPS this quarter. 
Compared to the year-ago period, stand-alone Key delivered positive operating leverage and we are well-positioned as we move forward as a combined company, having generated positive operating leverage for 9 of the past 11 quarters on a stand-alone basis. Revenue grew 6% from the prior year as we benefited from another quarter of solid loan and deposit growth and an 8% increase in noninterest income. 
Standouts for the quarter include a record level of investment banking and debt placement fees along with double-digit growth in cards and payments income. Expenses continue to be well managed and reflected higher performance-based compensation this quarter along with an increased FDIC assessments. Not on this slide but worth noting, we had another solid quarter in terms of credit quality with our net charge-off ratio remaining below our targeted range. And although this slide focuses on the stand-alone results, the performance of First Niagara since our acquisition announcement has exceeded our initial projection, and we remain very excited about the opportunity to grow this new part of our company. 
Moving now to Slide 5. As I've said, this has been a pivotal time for our company and I'm extremely proud of the dedication and hard work of our teams from both Key and First Niagara. During the last 3 months, we completed our regulatory approval process and closed our acquisition. We also completed the divestiture of 18 branches on September 9, and we executed our client outreach plan which were comprehensive in scale and scope. We mailed out 4 million pieces of mail to our new customers and our bankers have personally touched tens of thousands of clients in every business to welcome them to the new Key bank. 
I am now on Slide 6. Over Columbus Day weekend, we completed the branch and conversion which included moving data and account information for over 1 million new clients onto the Key platform. We converted over 300 branches which reopened at Key and consolidated 70 former First Niagara branches, and additional Key branches are targeted for consolidated for the fourth quarter. The conversion went well. Our detailed plans were well executed and we were open for business across our franchise as planned, on Tuesday morning. Our 3 million customers, including  the 1 million from First Niagara to bank with Key throughout our 1,300 branches, 1,500 ATMs and across our digital channels from consumer online banking to our sophisticated treasury management portal. For our new customers, the systems converted as planned, their account information was transferred and products and services like credit card, debit cards and bill pay capabilities all remain fully functional. During the conversion, as issues surfaced that impacted a very small percentage of our client base, our teams worked hard to quickly resolve them and make it right for our customers. Our planning and hard work over the past 12 months paid off and execution was solid.  Although we are still in early stages, the overall feedback from legacy First Niagara customers have been positive. 
Turning to Slide 7. As I said, we continue to be confident in our ability to deliver on our financial target. More specifically, I want to affirm our prior commitment that we have a high degree of confidence in achieving our cost savings target of $400 million. As I've said before, our internal target is higher and has remained consistent. We expect to achieve our full run rate savings by the back half of 2017, which means that will be fully reflected in our 2018 results. 
Most of the outsourced technology and operation, which are a significant part of the overall cost savings should be terminated by early next year with associated savings realized by that time. Benefits from occupancy, the remaining 36 branch consolidation and corporate function will be realized throughout 2017. As we look forward, we continue to believe that Key and First Niagara are a powerful combination that accelerates our performance beyond what either company could have otherwise achieved, improving our cash efficiency ratio by 300 basis points and our return on tangible common equity by 200 basis points. And not included in our target but something that continues to provide real opportunity is the $300 million in revenue synergies that we have identified. But leveraging our products and capabilities in areas like payment, treasury management and commercial mortgage banking, we have the opportunity to better serve First Niagara's client base, and we've already seen some early wins and are confident that continues to grow in achieving our revenue plan. That will conclude my remarks by recognizing the hard work and dedication of our teams over the past year. I'm incredibly proud that we were able to successfully close and integrate our acquisition while at the same time, accelerate our momentum and team reflected in our Community Bank and Corporate Bank performed. And as we move forward as 1 company, I'm even more excited for the opportunity. We have to accelerates our performance, drive growth and create long-term value for our clients, community, employees and most importantly, our shareholders. Now I'll turn the call over to Don to drive more detail on our quarterly results. Don?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks Beth, and I'm on Slide 9. Third quarter net income from continuing operations was $0.30 per common share after excluding $0.14 of merger-related charges. This compared to $0.26 per share in the year-ago period and $0.27 in the second quarter, which
componenttext:
Thanks Beth, and I'm on Slide 9. Third quarter net income from continuing operations was $0.30 per common share after excluding $0.14 of merger-related charges. This compared to $0.26 per share in the year-ago period and $0.27 in the second quarter, which excluded $0.04 of merger-related charges. As Beth mentioned, after adjusting for the impact of First Niagara and merger charges, we generated positive operating leverages relative to the year-ago quarter. On a stand-alone basis, Key revenue were up 6% from the prior year and up 5% [ph] from the second quarter. The EPS impact of First Niagara was relatively neutral to our third quarter results. Results not only reflect the impact of First Niagara's operations 2 months, but also the accounting adjustments and the impact from divestiture of 18 branches on September 9. I'll cover many of these atoms in this slide the rest of my presentation, so I'm now turning to Slide 10. 
Average loan balances were up $18 billion or 31% compared to a year ago quarter and up $17 billion or 27% compared from the second quarter. First Niagara contributed $15 billion of loans for the third quarter results on an average basis or $23 billion on a period end basis. Excluding the impact of First Niagara, average loans grew 5% year-over-year driven by commercial, financial and agricultural loans up 11%. We've seen double-digit year-over-year growth and 18 [ph] over the past 20 quarters for CF&A loans, reflecting our investment from senior banks, and we've also maintained our moderate risk profile. 
Average loans were up $1 billion or 2% on annualized from the second quarter excluding the impact of First Niagara, driven primarily from growth in commercial loan. Our estimated fair value adjustments on acquired First Niagara loans was 2.8% or $686 million. Importantly, this adjustment is an estimate and we expect additional refinement in the fourth quarter of this year as we work to finalize our purchase accounting. Also during the quarter, our branch divestiture resulted in a reduction of $439 million in loans. 
Continuing on to Slide 11. Average deposits excluding deposits in foreign office totaled $95 billion for the third quarter 2016, an increase of $25 billion compared to the year-ago period, and $21 billion compared to the second quarter. First Niagara contributed $19 billion of deposits to the third quarter results on an average basis or a $27 million on a period end basis. In our appendix materials, you will see that we recorded an estimated $356 million of core deposit and tangible assets associated with the acquisition. 
Excluding First Niagara, the I% year-over-year increase in deposit balances primary reflects core growth in our retail banking franchise and higher escrow deposits from our commercial mortgage servicing business. Compared to the second quarter 2016, our average deposits growth of 3% excluding First Niagara reflects higher escrow balances from our commercial mortgage servicing business, core deposit growth and retail banking franchise and inflows from our commercial clients. 
During the quarter, the branch divestiture resulted in a reduction $1.6 billion in deposits. 
Slide 12 shows our investment portfolio and the highlights changes that occurred over the quarter. Average total investment securities were $24 billion for the third quarter, which is up $5 billion from both the third quarter of last year and the second quarter of this year. Growth compared to the prior year in the prior quarter reflects the acquisition of First Niagara's portfolio, which added $4.7 billion on average fifth [ph] balance basis and $9 billion on a period end basis. During the quarter, we completed planned sales and the repositioning of First Niagara's portfolio to more closely align with KEy's portfolio and investment philosophy. Proceeds of the portfolio sales are primarily used to pay down FHLB advances. 
The average yield on our investment portfolio decreased 13 basis points from the prior year and 12 basis points from the prior quarter which reflect\s the impact of First Niagara portfolio and the continued pressure from lower reinvestment yields. 
Turning to Slide 13.  Taxable equivalent net interest income of $788 million for the third quarter 2016. The net interest margin was 2.85%. These results compare to taxable equivalent net interest income of $598 million and a net interest margin of 2.87% for the third quarter of 2015. First Niagara contributed $175 million for the third quarter net interest income. Included in this figure is $19 million from purchase accounting accretion. The purchase accounting accretion on the loans in the third quarter was estimated which is not reflecting any loan payment. In the fourth quarter, we will finalize purchase accounting marks which we expect will result in increase in net interest income. 
Reported results for the quarter also includes $6 million of merger-related charges. Excluding First Niagara and the merger-related charges, net interest income increased 4% from the prior year and 2% from the prior quarter, with both increases driven primarily by higher earning asset balances. 
The third quarter net interest margin up 2.85% was 9 basis points higher than the prior quarter. Purchase accounting contributed 6 basis points of the growth with all other items providing the benefit of 3 basis points on a combined basis. 
Slide 14 shows a summary of noninterest income which accounted for 41% of our total revenue. Noninterest income in the third quarter was $549 million, up $79 million or 17% from the prior year, and up $76 million or 16% from the prior quarter. Our results this quarter included $53 million from First Niagara, which reflected 2 months worth of impact. Additionally within noninterest income, we incurred $12 million of merger-related charges, including  losses realized from repositioning of the investment portfolio. Excluding the impact of the acquisition and merger-related charges, noninterest income was up 8% from the prior year and up 7% from the prior quarter. We saw a continued growth and momentum in a number of our core fee-based businesses, reflecting investments we've been, we have made over the past few years. As Beth mentioned, investment banking and debt placement fees at a record quarter. We saw strength across our platform, and including  commercial mortgage banking, equity capital markets and M&A advisory fees, reflecting the strength of the Key relationship model. And while not a material growth driver, trading income did increase but included elsewhere in the income statement. 
Charge and payment income also contributed to our strong results are double-digit growth, excluding the impact of the acquisition compared to both the year-ago and prior quarters. In service charges on deposit accounts continue to move higher as our number of customers and related activities grow. 
During the third quarter, operating lease income and other leasing gains reflecting $12 million of lease residual losses. 
And turning to Slide 15. As you can see on this slide, reported noninterest expense of $1.1 billion includes $189 million of merger charges and $140 million of expense related to 2 months of First Niagara operation. Excluding these costs, noninterest expense was $753 million for the quarter. We provided a detailed breakdown of our merger-related charges i of the apprentice of our materials. Compared to the third quarter of last year and after adjusting for the impact of First Niagara and merger-related charges, noninterest expense was up $29 million or 4%. Linked quarter expenses also adjusted for the acquisition were up $47 million or 7%. Both comparisons reflect higher performance-based compensation and an increased FDIC assessment. 
Expenses related to the First Niagara operations were lower than previous guidance provided. This improvement reflects some acceleration and merger cost savings and lower-than-expected core deposit intangible amortization. 
Turning to Slide 16. Overall net charge-offs of $44 million or 23 basis points of average total loans in the third quarter which continues to be below our targeted range. Third quarter provision for credit losses was $59 million, an increase of $14 million from the year-ago period and $7 million from the linked-quarter. Impact from First Niagara resulted in an $18 million of provision expense for the third quarter, $12 million of which related to the purchase credit card portfolio, which was initially recorded at a premium.
Nonperforming loans and nonperforming assets both increased relative to year-ago period in the prior quarter, reflecting $150 million of nonperforming loans and $167 million of nonperforming assets from the First Niagara acquisition. At September 30, 2016, our total reserves for loan losses represented a 1.01% of period end loan, and 120% coverage of our nonperforming loans, and reflects the acquisition of First Niagara loans at fair value. 
And turning to Slide 17, our Common Tier 1 ratio at the end of the third quarter was 9.55% which reflects the impact of First Niagara. With the completion of the acquisition, we did resume our common share repurchase program, and we repurchased $65 million in common shares during the quarter. This linked capital management will remain a priority for us. 
Moving on to Slide 18. This quarter, we have provided you with our outlook and expectations for the fourth quarter on a combined company basis. Importantly, our 2016 full year outlook for stand-alone Key remains consistent with what we have provided earlier in the year. We expect average loans to benefit from a full quarter impact of First Niagara and continued core portfolio loan growth driven by strength in our commercial businesses. 
Net interest income is also expected to benefit from one additional month of the impact of First Niagara, along with normal growth in NII. Further, as we noted earlier, we anticipate of having an adjustment to purchase accounting accretion in the fourth quarter resulting in an increase to net income. Noninterest income will also reflect Q additional month benefit from the acquisition, and we expect the investment banking and debt placement fees for the full year of 2016 to be equal to or slightly higher than our full year 2015 results. 
In addition to a full quarter impact of noninterest expense from First Niagara, we're also anticipating a limited merger-related charges to continue in the fourth quarter. To date, we've recognized about half of our expected $550 million in merger charges. We continue to expect net charge-offs to be relatively stable with our  third quarter reported results and below our targeted range of 40 to 50 [ph] basis points. Provision is to expected to be -- to slightly exceed our level of net charge-offs. 
As Beth said, we remain committed to meeting or exceeding the financial targets we have laid out for the acquisition. We continue to expect to exceed our $400 million of cost savings targets by the back half of 2017, which would then be reflected in our full year 2018 run rate. With the conversion complete, we expect to show meaningful progress towards cost savings targets as well as savings from consolidated branches, third-party and technology cost and redundancies across the franchise. With that, I'll close and turn the call back over to the operator for instructions for Q&A portion of our call. Operator?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of John Pancari of Evercore.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of John Pancari of Evercore.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to see if you can elaborate a little bit on the timing of the cost saves. I know you indicated that you expect it to be fully realized by year end 2017, and Beth, I know you also alluded to where the bulk of the realization would be. I'm just try
componenttext: I wanted to see if you can elaborate a little bit on the timing of the cost saves. I know you indicated that you expect it to be fully realized by year end 2017, and Beth, I know you also alluded to where the bulk of the realization would be. I'm just trying to get an idea of the timing through the year. Is it fair to assume that over half of the cost saves could be in the run rate before midyear because that does impact where full year '17 and '18 projections?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Don. And I would start off by saying run rate for expenses First Niagara that was included in our third quarter results, it shows an average monthly run rate of about $70 million a month. That compares with the run rate before acquisition of below
componenttext: This is Don. And I would start off by saying run rate for expenses First Niagara that was included in our third quarter results, it shows an average monthly run rate of about $70 million a month. That compares with the run rate before acquisition of below over $80 million. And so I would say that in the current run rate, we were already reflecting about $100 million of that $400 million targeted level. As we have said before that the fourth quarter won't show a meaningful increase as far as the level of cost saves, we would expect to see many of those occur in the first half of next year, with the realization of the systems conversion, the branch consolidations [indiscernible] will occur in the fourth quarter and some of the other steps we start to realize in the first half of next year. And so I would say by the end of the first half, we would be well past the 50% of attainment of that value from the cost savings.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And then separately, I know you had indicated that, in your prepared comments that the First Niagara deal is performing better-than-expected since the close of the transaction. Can you elaborate on what you're referring to? Is it mainly a
componenttext: Okay. All right. And then separately, I know you had indicated that, in your prepared comments that the First Niagara deal is performing better-than-expected since the close of the transaction. Can you elaborate on what you're referring to? Is it mainly around the timing or the account attrition or cost saves? Can you just give us some more detail?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take another crack at that as well. If you look at the growth of the experience from the time of acquisition to the time of closing, it was in excess of what we would have expected. They showed growth in customers, in households. They showed growth i
componenttext: I'll take another crack at that as well. If you look at the growth of the experience from the time of acquisition to the time of closing, it was in excess of what we would have expected. They showed growth in customers, in households. They showed growth in deposit balances and loan balances, and so they were able to continue to grow that franchise despite the fact that this merger was going on. And then if you combine that with the expense days that we realized here in the third quarter, that was in -- earlier than what we would have expected as well. And so it will feel like and it shows that they're exceeding in all fronts.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Nash from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Nash from Goldman Sachs.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just following up a little bit on Jon's question. Beth, you talked about your internal targets being higher than your external targets, and you sound like you're getting increased confidence now you've had a couple of months looking at it. Can you g
componenttext: Maybe just following up a little bit on Jon's question. Beth, you talked about your internal targets being higher than your external targets, and you sound like you're getting increased confidence now you've had a couple of months looking at it. Can you give us a sense of how you think -- what you think the incremental cost savings could be and will those be beyond the 2018 period -- beyond the 2017 period or do you expect those to be phased in concurrently with the rest of the cost savings?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ryan. This is Beth and then if appropriate, Don may have some more color. Yes, we do have confidence that as we've said, our internal target has exceeded to $400 million in the past. However, at this time, I would say that we're still early days of m
componenttext: Yes, Ryan. This is Beth and then if appropriate, Don may have some more color. Yes, we do have confidence that as we've said, our internal target has exceeded to $400 million in the past. However, at this time, I would say that we're still early days of making sure we realize the $400 million that we outlined and the amount and the timing we have suggested. We will defer until we get into 2017 before we outline with those additional possibilities of the timing will be. But I will tell you that we do see a path for outperforming what had been our initial projections of $400 million we committed to a year ago.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I agree, Beth. And we've talked about the realization of that $400 million, primarily in the first half of next year. And as we wrap up 2017, we would expect to see the full benefit of that run rate in our 2018 outlook.
componenttext: No, I agree, Beth. And we've talked about the realization of that $400 million, primarily in the first half of next year. And as we wrap up 2017, we would expect to see the full benefit of that run rate in our 2018 outlook.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Maybe I could just ask 1 other question, the 200 basis point ROTC uplift, is that a fully phased in run rate in 2018? And how do we think about the base for that? Is that current hedge of book value of that pro forma for 2018? And what -- can you
componenttext: Got it. Maybe I could just ask 1 other question, the 200 basis point ROTC uplift, is that a fully phased in run rate in 2018? And how do we think about the base for that? Is that current hedge of book value of that pro forma for 2018? And what -- can you just remind us what you were using for legacy Key as part of your expectations?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We were operating at around 8% return on tangible Common Equity before the transaction. I would say in the third quarter, adjusted for the merger-related charges are, return on tangible common would be about 11%. And if you would just add on top of that t
componenttext: We were operating at around 8% return on tangible Common Equity before the transaction. I would say in the third quarter, adjusted for the merger-related charges are, return on tangible common would be about 11%. And if you would just add on top of that the additional benefit from the expense savings, we would be in that 12% to 13%. So it would be equal to or exceeding that 200-basis-point improvement we talked about.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Alexapoulos from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Alexapoulos from JPMorgan.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to make sure I understand did you say there are $100 million of cost saves now in the run rate this quarter?
componenttext: I just want to make sure I understand did you say there are $100 million of cost saves now in the run rate this quarter?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I've shown to calculate that, was basically the run rate of expenses for First Niagara was $70 million a month. If you take the $140 million divided by the 2 month they reported, and compare that with the $80 million a month they were running at befo
componenttext: What I've shown to calculate that, was basically the run rate of expenses for First Niagara was $70 million a month. If you take the $140 million divided by the 2 month they reported, and compare that with the $80 million a month they were running at before the acquisition. And so that gives us about $100 million of cost savings realized on a run-rate basis.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And Don, I know you're running parallel on the systems with First Niagara, what's the target date right now were you expected to turn off their systems and get the $160 million of cost saves from the vendor contracts?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Many of those should be shut off by the end of this calendar year. There would be few that will still linger into 2017, but the vast majority of the benefit there should be in the early half of 2017, benefit for those contract terminations.
componenttext: Many of those should be shut off by the end of this calendar year. There would be few that will still linger into 2017, but the vast majority of the benefit there should be in the early half of 2017, benefit for those contract terminations.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And could I ask you on the margin, obviously, a lot of moving pieces for this quarter. Can you help us think through the trajectory for NIM for in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And could I ask you on the margin, obviously, a lot of moving pieces for this quarter. Can you help us think through the trajectory for NIM for in the fourth quarter?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think our NIM in the third quarter but the month of September we had a margin of right around 290. And I would use that as a baseline for the fourth quarter, but keep in mind that we've talked about the fourth quarter will include some additional net in
componenttext: I think our NIM in the third quarter but the month of September we had a margin of right around 290. And I would use that as a baseline for the fourth quarter, but keep in mind that we've talked about the fourth quarter will include some additional net interest income related to our purchase accounting accretion and so it should be a little stronger than that 290.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could squeeze in one more in, Don. Can you help us think about the tax rate going forward?
componenttext: And if I could squeeze in one more in, Don. Can you help us think about the tax rate going forward?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We had some earlier comments about the low tax rate in the quarter. And if you take a look at our reported earnings and back out their related merger charges and assume a 35% tax rate on those merger charges, the effective tax rate for the current q
componenttext: Sure. We had some earlier comments about the low tax rate in the quarter. And if you take a look at our reported earnings and back out their related merger charges and assume a 35% tax rate on those merger charges, the effective tax rate for the current quarter was 22.4% for core operations. On a year-to-date basis, that's 24.4%, and so we've benefited in the third quarter from some higher credits associated with some equipment leasing activities. We also had a slight charge in the second quarter, and so we would expect those credits to continue, and so we would expect our tax rate for the full year to be in that 24% to 25% range, so it would be very consistent with our year-to-date effective tax rate

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we have from the line of Erika Najarian of Bank of America.
componenttext: And next, we have from the line of Erika Najarian of Bank of America.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, my question is, as we look forward to 2017, how should we think about the $753 million legacy KeyCorp expense base? The year-over-year growth rate is about 4%? Is that the kind of growth rate we should think about for 2017, or should we really think
componenttext: Look, my question is, as we look forward to 2017, how should we think about the $753 million legacy KeyCorp expense base? The year-over-year growth rate is about 4%? Is that the kind of growth rate we should think about for 2017, or should we really think about it in context of the 65% efficiency ratio legacy?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, first, Erika, that the $753 million reflects the performance-based compensation associated with our record high quarter for investment banking and debt placement fees of $156 million. So we did have higher levels of expenses than what we woul
componenttext: I would say, first, Erika, that the $753 million reflects the performance-based compensation associated with our record high quarter for investment banking and debt placement fees of $156 million. So we did have higher levels of expenses than what we would expect for our normal run rate, and so we will expect the quarter to come down based on not being able to sustain that level of investment banking debt placement fees. Core Key is currently operating around a 65% efficiency ratio, and so I think that is a good benchmark for legacy Key, but again, as we start to realize the cost savings from combined organization that we should see that efficiency ratio drop meaningfully.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also as we think about next year, how should we think about average balance sheet growth in context of some of the assets that may be rolling off of from First Niagara that you don't think as core to you? And if I could slip one more here, in terms of
componenttext: And also as we think about next year, how should we think about average balance sheet growth in context of some of the assets that may be rolling off of from First Niagara that you don't think as core to you? And if I could slip one more here, in terms of comments on purchase accounting, are you expecting just a refinement in that? We'll have one more month of purchase accounting accretion, or is that 686 [ph] potentially going higher?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of things there, Erika. As far as the growth rate, we'll provide guidance when we get into the January earnings call that provide guidance for 2017. I would say right now, our pipeline is remaining strong and the core franchise is growing and we
componenttext: A couple of things there, Erika. As far as the growth rate, we'll provide guidance when we get into the January earnings call that provide guidance for 2017. I would say right now, our pipeline is remaining strong and the core franchise is growing and we saw growth across the Key footprint. And we said 5% on a linked -- on a year-over-year basis. We're also seeing growth in the First Niagara so we'll continue to work through that. We're not seeing material portfolios where we would consider them to be an exit mode as far as the First Niagara franchise, so don't think that would dilute the growth from that perspective. But again we'll provide more guidance there later. As far as the purchase accounting adjustment, you're right, the accretion for the quarter was $90 [ph] million. We would expect to see another month of accretion in the fourth quarter. And so on top of that, we would also have some additional accretion impacting our earnings because we did not assume any prepayments in the third quarter. And as those loans with prepay, it would also accelerate the recognition of some purchase accounting discounts. And so we think the benefit from the purchase accounting will exceed just a quarter and of the $90 million the experienced in the third quarter.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to be clear, the 686 [ph] of a shorter duration than what I calculated to be about a 6-year duration that you assume for this quarter?
componenttext: So just to be clear, the 686 [ph] of a shorter duration than what I calculated to be about a 6-year duration that you assume for this quarter?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And essentially, what we're required to do is assume that those -- that accretion would occur over the contractual life of the loan and so we would assume a faster than contractual life type of assumption as far as the realization of those reflecting the
componenttext: And essentially, what we're required to do is assume that those -- that accretion would occur over the contractual life of the loan and so we would assume a faster than contractual life type of assumption as far as the realization of those reflecting the impact of prepayments.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Zerby with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Zerby with Morgan Stanley.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is a more a broader question. You guys have frequently referred to potentially saving more than $400 million. If you did achieve, and pick your number and say another $100 million of expense savings, how would that fault of the bottom line?
componenttext: First question is a more a broader question. You guys have frequently referred to potentially saving more than $400 million. If you did achieve, and pick your number and say another $100 million of expense savings, how would that fault of the bottom line?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, I don't want to set your sights for another $100 million, that would be another meaningful step up.
componenttext: Ken, I don't want to set your sights for another $100 million, that would be another meaningful step up.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hypothetical number, of course.
componenttext: Hypothetical number, of course.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That would assume that we would be reducing over half of the legacy First Niagara franchise expense base. But that being said, we do believe that the cost saves will drop the bottom line and offsetting that. We've also talked about revenue synergies and w
componenttext: That would assume that we would be reducing over half of the legacy First Niagara franchise expense base. But that being said, we do believe that the cost saves will drop the bottom line and offsetting that. We've also talked about revenue synergies and we're starting to see some activities that are reinforcing our confidence in achieving those. We've talked about a $300 million run rate of revenue synergies. And with that, we would have incremental costs associated with achieving that. And so it would realize about another $100 million or so of additional expense for that. And so again, we do believe that those cost saves will drop the bottom line. They won't be offset by add-ons but we will have some additional cost to achieve those revenue synergies.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Perfect. And then just the other question I had, in terms of provision expense, can you just explain the $80 [ph] million First Niagara, and obviously the $12 million to the credit card higher provision. I just want to make sure I understand th
componenttext: All right. Perfect. And then just the other question I had, in terms of provision expense, can you just explain the $80 [ph] million First Niagara, and obviously the $12 million to the credit card higher provision. I just want to make sure I understand that. I guess I would've thought all the loans were marked to market. What am I missing in terms of why now there's a provision expense in the First Niagara loans?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, what you're missing is you're trying to apply a logic to accounting rules, and that doesn't always follow suit. But essentially, what happens here, as we look at the nonPCI, nonpurchase credit impaired portfolios, those loans are recorded at a discou
componenttext: Ken, what you're missing is you're trying to apply a logic to accounting rules, and that doesn't always follow suit. But essentially, what happens here, as we look at the nonPCI, nonpurchase credit impaired portfolios, those loans are recorded at a discount, there will be a pre-net discount back in the income over time, but you would always look at the remaining discount to see if it's adequate to cover the required reserves associated with those loans. What's unique about those credit card portfolios is that we recorded at a premium, and so the value of that portfolio was higher than par. And so we had no discount compared to -- for the recognition of allowance associated with that credit card portfolio. So effectively, on day 1 after the acquisition, we had to record the entire allowance of $12 million associated with that $300 million portfolio. And so that's what triggered that and that's why we had a higher level of provision associated with the First Niagara transaction.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then really quickly on the preferred dividends on a go forward basis?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then really quickly on the preferred dividends on a go forward basis?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The preferred dividends will increase next quarter but the First Niagara preferred -- declared their dividend in July, and so it did had an impact on the third quarter results. So you'll see almost a doubling of the preferred dividends compared to what th
componenttext: The preferred dividends will increase next quarter but the First Niagara preferred -- declared their dividend in July, and so it did had an impact on the third quarter results. So you'll see almost a doubling of the preferred dividends compared to what the current quarter was.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doubling versus this quarter, okay.
componenttext: Doubling versus this quarter, okay.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Eads with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Eads with UBS.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, there's been a lot of commentary about the C&I demand across the industry. I'm just kind of curious what you guys are seeing, if you're seeing anything kind of unique related to the merger closing?
componenttext: Obviously, there's been a lot of commentary about the C&I demand across the industry. I'm just kind of curious what you guys are seeing, if you're seeing anything kind of unique related to the merger closing?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Bill Hartmann, David. Well, one of the things that Don mentioned earlier was that continued momentum that was going on at First Niagara during that time between the announcement and the merger closing and I think that, that from a growth standpoin
componenttext: This is Bill Hartmann, David. Well, one of the things that Don mentioned earlier was that continued momentum that was going on at First Niagara during that time between the announcement and the merger closing and I think that, that from a growth standpoint could be viewed as something that's a bit unique because in many cases, people would expect to see our business momentum drop off. We have experienced continued growth across our portfolio as a result of the investments of that we made in bankers over time, and we continue to see benefits from that investment in the -- certainly in the current quarter.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, this is Beth. I would just add that this is an area that Key has outperformed the industry. One of the statistics we quoted earlier was 18 over the last 20 quarters, we have seen double-digit C&I growth in our portfolio, and I think it's import
componenttext: And David, this is Beth. I would just add that this is an area that Key has outperformed the industry. One of the statistics we quoted earlier was 18 over the last 20 quarters, we have seen double-digit C&I growth in our portfolio, and I think it's important to underline that it does reflect investments from senior bankers, so growth being driven by our client-facing personnel being increased our bankers. Second, we have also been investing in capabilities to differentiate Key, both on our KeyBanc Capital Markets platform but also in markets like treasury. This has enabled us to compete differently and post higher level of C&I growth in the industry has been seeing, yet maintain our risk profile and loss content. So I think this is that strategy coming through for '14[ph]

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And obviously, you guys will give formal guidance for the end of the year, but this sounds like there's no real change for near-term outlook there.
componenttext: And obviously, you guys will give formal guidance for the end of the year, but this sounds like there's no real change for near-term outlook there.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: No changes there for the near-term outlook, that's correct.

Is that the narrative that we should be thinking about?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our pipeline remains strong. And in order for us to hit our guidance, we'll have to have something in the $120 million plus as far as the quarter for investment banking debt placement fees, so down from the record level but still strong compared to a year
componenttext: Our pipeline remains strong. And in order for us to hit our guidance, we'll have to have something in the $120 million plus as far as the quarter for investment banking debt placement fees, so down from the record level but still strong compared to a year ago and reflective of what we see as new business coming on. One other indicator there really is taking a look at our loans held for sale. And you can see a nice pop-up in the commercial on mortgage loans held for sale to about $1 billion level and so that's just 1 indicator as far as the strength of the pipeline.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have from the line of Gerard Cassidy with RBC.
componenttext: Next, we have from the line of Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, can you share with us talking about the accounting for the provision on the loans that came over, could you also talk about the nonperforming assets, or the nonperforming loans, I should say, that came from First Niagara because once again, normally
componenttext: Don, can you share with us talking about the accounting for the provision on the loans that came over, could you also talk about the nonperforming assets, or the nonperforming loans, I should say, that came from First Niagara because once again, normally those are mark-to-market. What caused those loans to come over as nonperforming loans?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And as far as the accounting treatment, we took a look at the $23 billion portfolio, and divided it into 2 primary pieces; one is purchase credit impaired which is just shy of $1 billion, and the other piece is the nonpurchase credit impaired. So th
componenttext: Sure. And as far as the accounting treatment, we took a look at the $23 billion portfolio, and divided it into 2 primary pieces; one is purchase credit impaired which is just shy of $1 billion, and the other piece is the nonpurchase credit impaired. So the purchase credit impaired $1 billion, they're primarily commercial loans, and those are loans where we don't think that people will be able to live up to the commitments required and the loan agreements and they're included in that category and their marked net of reserves and net of interest rate mark. And so they don't bring over any allowance associated with that and that interest rate mark will be accretive back in the income over time. Because they are recognized as purchase credit impaired, they're excluded from the nonperforming assets and nonperforming loans. Now the rest of the $22 billion in loan portfolio, we did also record a mark on that portfolio, and it includes both credit and interest rates. We did not have any additional allows related to that. But since it's not purchase credit impaired, we did carry over the status as far as the nonperforming loans and nonperforming assets. And so that's why we show $150 million coming over in NPLs from the First Niagara acquisition because many of those loans included in that nonpurchase credit impaired are reviewed on a portfolio basis as opposed to an individual loan bases. And so on a portfolio basis, we believe that the portfolio will be able to perform in line with expectations.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Would that imply they're mostly consumer, the loans then in the nonimpaired versus the other portfolio being the commercial loans?
componenttext: Would that imply they're mostly consumer, the loans then in the nonimpaired versus the other portfolio being the commercial loans?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there are commercial loans that are not PCI impaired and that then so -- and are also in the commercial portfolios, some business banking loans that are looked out on a portfolio basis as opposed to an individual loan basis. And so it's a mixture of
componenttext: Well, there are commercial loans that are not PCI impaired and that then so -- and are also in the commercial portfolios, some business banking loans that are looked out on a portfolio basis as opposed to an individual loan basis. And so it's a mixture of both, Gerard, but I would say that most of the consumer loans are in the non-purchase credit impaired category.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: I would say our sales levels are to be consistent with what we've experienced in the past. But I think we would talk about for the capital raise but we would retain somewhere in around the 20% level and I don't know that that changed dramatically for the fourth quarter.

componenttext: Yes. The bulk of those shares issued are related to the First Niagara. So as we issued new restricted shares or others in connection with employee change of control contracts as we contracted some of those agreements, is how those shares were issued for the most part. And so they have been granted as of, or around the August 1 time line when the acquisition was finalized.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just the last question on the card provision which you explained. Is that entirely a onetime sort of catch-up true-up, or are there any lingering sort of impacts to be aware of in the future periods?
componenttext: Okay. And then just the last question on the card provision which you explained. Is that entirely a onetime sort of catch-up true-up, or are there any lingering sort of impacts to be aware of in the future periods?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: As it relates to the card, that's a onetime impact. And so going forward, we just had normal provision to cover charge-offs and loan growth in that portfolio. Keep in mind, down the road, we will have to make sure that we're adding provision for our new l
componenttext: As it relates to the card, that's a onetime impact. And so going forward, we just had normal provision to cover charge-offs and loan growth in that portfolio. Keep in mind, down the road, we will have to make sure that we're adding provision for our new loan growth, and so we will have provision to cover that loan growth. And also as the accretion of that discount occurs for the non-purchase credit card impaired, we will start to replenishes the reserves associated with some of those portfolios over time as well.

componenttext: Combined, I'm sorry. If you look at combined sensitivity, we're about 2% asset sensitive. headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: One, we didn't start buying back any shares until after the merger was completed. So there was some timing to that. But more importantly, our employee stock issuance typically occurs, the most part in the first quarter of each calendar year. And so we wou
componenttext: One, we didn't start buying back any shares until after the merger was completed. So there was some timing to that. But more importantly, our employee stock issuance typically occurs, the most part in the first quarter of each calendar year. And so we would typically see acceleration as far as some of the share buybacks during that quarter, and so you would see us queueing or heavy weighing of the share buyback for that quarter and so -- but that's consistent with what we've done in the prior year's as well.

componenttext: Okay. And if I can ask, just a follow-up on the capital markets. You didn't mention capital markets as a potential revenue synergy within the FNFG franchise. headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Matt, this is Beth. I would tell you that we do see opportunities within our corporate bank platforms, particularly in mortgage banking, as an area where real opportunity, particularly given the book of business in First Niagara that they have within real estate growth on the balance sheet as well as more broadly, some of what those clients own. And we cited that there have already been a handful of those wins, many of them are related to the capability that we have in commercial mortgage banking. We also see obviously very, very good opportunities against some of our core payments, treasury management, FX and derivative products and then, obviously, within that client base, our advisory of capabilities will probably also owned time great opportunities. But near-term and early wins, I think will be in the commercial mortgage banking.

componenttext: So I would underscore that the core momentum you're seeing in Key is what I think has been the rigor that we have given to our expenses to also create capacity to invest in bankers products capabilities that have created some of the minimum [ph] that were showing. And again, importantly as we look at it 8 out of the last 11 quarter, Key has generated positive operating leverage. So the investment showing our revenue but the discipline in our expenses to create those investments, and then part of the momentum and performance that we're experiencing.

componenttext: We're very comfortable that capital ratio being in that level, and so we will consider that as we look forward to future CCARs. Also, we're taking the and any changes in the guidance as the NPR is finalized and additional comments we've heard are put in the rule.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far as the $100 million that I cited, there were a number of expenses associated with some of the systems development that First Niagara was doing before the announcement, and we also had some executives, and former executives of First Niagara le
componenttext: Sure. As far as the $100 million that I cited, there were a number of expenses associated with some of the systems development that First Niagara was doing before the announcement, and we also had some executives, and former executives of First Niagara leave and some staffing leave as well post legal day 1. And so those are really the sources of much of that $100 million of cost savings. We would expect to continue to see some ramping up later this year and as we said earlier, we would expect to realize majority of those cost saves in the first half of '17 and be at a full run rate finishing out throughout '17.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Well, one, on the headcount reduction, I would say that we haven't seen any meaningful headcount reduction yet. It has been helpful but not a meaningful source of total savings as far as the branches. We consolidated 70 branches of First Niagara over the conversion day weekend, and we would expect of 36 branches of Key consolidate here in the fourth quarter. And so we should be there for our targeted branch consolidations which will represent about 25%. The other piece that occurred year in the third quarter, in the middle of September, would it close on the divestiture of the branches required for the acquisition of that reduced our branch count by about 18.

componenttext: Okay. And so you just -- so you shut those 70 branches, they're gone? I mean. . .

componenttext: In the fourth quarter, they're no longer operational, that's correct. So they got shot down, and we'll be realizing the expense savings associated with those branch consolidations in the fourth quarter, and then we'll have another 36 [ph] from legacy Key that will be consolidated in the fourth quarter as well.

componenttext: The biggest driver would be the loan growth, I should say that investment portfolio should be relatively stable overall. You could see a remixing as well, because we still have, in the third quarter, a very high level of short-term earning asset, mainly the Fed account and we would expect that to come down over time.

componenttext: Okay. componenttextpreview: Yes. As far as LCR, on a combined basis, we're north of 120% on the LCR, so we're good on that perspective. On the go-to investment rates, the current quarter, we've bought about $4 billion in securities, about $1 billion of that were in floaters, so agen
componenttext: Yes. As far as LCR, on a combined basis, we're north of 120% on the LCR, so we're good on that perspective. On the go-to investment rates, the current quarter, we've bought about $4 billion in securities, about $1 billion of that were in floaters, so agency floaters, and so it only had about the 90 basis points yield. The remaining securities that we are purchasing during the quarter had an average yield of up somewhere in the 18 to 19 range, and we're seeing that come up a little bit as rates move up here late in the quarter.

componenttext: We are now all operating on the same origination platform and so that is a positive event. And so we've been pleased with the rollout of the First Niagara mortgage loan officers converted over to our new origination platform as well and feel that was a success. Beth, anything else?

componenttext: And Terry, I would add that we now have, as we talked about some of the benefits of First Niagara, one was the acceleration of standing up for a mortgage firm for Key for originations and servicing, and our plans in 2017 and forward to include us adding to our mortgage origination staff and more robustly offering mortgage across our entire Key footprint, so that is one of the sources I revenue synergy that we see in the transaction.

componenttext: Just on the revenue enhancements, can you talk a little bit about maybe the timing that you see, some of that coming through in '17? And then in addition to residential mortgage, what are some of the big contributors will be?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. When we talk about the $3 million of incremental synergies, we said that that would typically be in a 3- to 5-year type of time period. And so we'll continue to monitor that, but that's our initial assumption going in. In addition to the residential
componenttext: Sure. When we talk about the $3 million of incremental synergies, we said that that would typically be in a 3- to 5-year type of time period. And so we'll continue to monitor that, but that's our initial assumption going in. In addition to the residential mortgage, one of the big areas for us is our cash management services, treasury management services for the commercial side. And as we take a look at the activity level that we're seeing right now, we're seeing a nice increase as far as potential referrals and pipeline associated with that. I think we've got over 200 First Niagara customers that are at least talking to us about adding additional treasury management services. And so that would be another category but we also have potential growth and a number of other products and services, some of which came from First Niagara and some of which are for legacy Key. Beth, anything else you want to add there?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: In the product capabilities, again, a robust offering for our customers will also include what we put in corporate services income of FX and derivatives and a broad suite there. We also look at wealth management and private banking and within that, we have investment management and other services that I think will be a good fit, again, for their consumer as well as business customer within Key.

componenttext: Really, again, it falls back so we think it's a 3- to 5-year time period, so you can think about that ramping up over that time period. So I would say that we'll provide a little more guidance as we get into the fourth quarter call in January and provide as clarity as the timing and the level of recognition associated with those synergies.
