componenttext: Okay. Got it. And could I ask you on the margin, obviously, a lot of moving pieces to this quarter. Could you help us think through the trajectory for NIM in the fourth quarter?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you take a look at our NIM in the third quarter, for the month of September we had a margin of right around 290. And I would use that as a baseline for the fourth quarter. But keep in mind, we've talked about the fourth quarter will include some additi
componenttext: If you take a look at our NIM in the third quarter, for the month of September we had a margin of right around 290. And I would use that as a baseline for the fourth quarter. But keep in mind, we've talked about the fourth quarter will include some additional net interest income related to our purchase accounting accretion and so it should be a little stronger than that 290.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could squeeze in one more in, Don. Could you help us think about the tax rate going forward?
componenttext: And if I could squeeze in one more in, Don. Could you help us think about the tax rate going forward?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We've had some early comments about the low tax rate for the quarter. And if you take a look at our reported earnings and backout the related merger charges and assume a 35% tax rate on those merger charges, the effective tax rate for the current qu
componenttext: Sure. We've had some early comments about the low tax rate for the quarter. And if you take a look at our reported earnings and backout the related merger charges and assume a 35% tax rate on those merger charges, the effective tax rate for the current quarter was 22.4% for core operations. On a year-to-date basis, that's 24.4%. And so we benefited in the third quarter from some higher credits associated with some equipment leasing activities. We also had a slight charge in the second quarter, and so we would expect those credits to continue. And so we would expect our tax rate for the full year to be in that 24% to 25% range, so it will be very consistent with our year-to-date effective tax rate.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we have from the line of Erika Najarian from Bank of America.
componenttext: And next, we have from the line of Erika Najarian from Bank of America.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I echo Steve's sentiments on the clarity of the First Niagara impact. Look, my question is, as we look forward to 2017, how should we think about the $753 million legacy KeyCorp expense base? The year-over-year growth rate is about 4%. Is that the kind of
componenttext: I echo Steve's sentiments on the clarity of the First Niagara impact. Look, my question is, as we look forward to 2017, how should we think about the $753 million legacy KeyCorp expense base? The year-over-year growth rate is about 4%. Is that the kind of growth rate we should think about for 2017? Or should we really think about it in context of the 65% efficiency ratio legacy?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, first, Erika, that the $753 million reflects the performance-based compensation associated with our record high quarter for investment banking and debt placement fees of $156 million. So we did have higher levels of some expenses than what we
componenttext: I would say, first, Erika, that the $753 million reflects the performance-based compensation associated with our record high quarter for investment banking and debt placement fees of $156 million. So we did have higher levels of some expenses than what we would expect to be for our normal run rate. And so we expect the core to come down based on not being able to sustain that level of investment banking debt placement fees. Core Key is currently operating around a 65% efficiency ratio, and so I think that is a good benchmark for legacy Key. But again, as we start to realize the cost savings from the combined organization, we should see that efficiency ratio drop meaningfully.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also as we think about next year, how should we think about average balance sheet growth in context of some of the assets that may be rolling off from First Niagara that you don't think is as core to you today. And if I could just slip one more here i
componenttext: And also as we think about next year, how should we think about average balance sheet growth in context of some of the assets that may be rolling off from First Niagara that you don't think is as core to you today. And if I could just slip one more here in, in terms of your comments on purchase accounting, are you expecting just a refinement in that? We'll have one more month of purchase accounting accretion or is that 686 [ph] potentially going higher?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of things there, Erika. As far as the growth rate, we'll provide more guidance when we get in the January earnings call that provides guidance for 2017. I would say right now, our pipelines remain strong and the core franchise is growing, and we
componenttext: A couple of things there, Erika. As far as the growth rate, we'll provide more guidance when we get in the January earnings call that provides guidance for 2017. I would say right now, our pipelines remain strong and the core franchise is growing, and we saw growth across the Key footprint. And we said 5% on a linked -- on a year-over-year basis. We're also seeing growth in the First Niagara, so we'll continue to work through that. We're not seeing material portfolios where we would consider them to be in exit mode as far as the First Niagara franchise, so we don't think that will dilute the growth from that perspective. But again, we'll provide more guidance there later. As far as the purchase accounting adjustments, you're right. The accretion for this quarter was $19 million. We would expect to see another month of accretion in the fourth quarter. And so on top of that, we would also have some additional accretion impacting our earnings because we did not assume any prepayments in the third quarter. And as those loans would prepay, it would also accelerate the recognition of some additional purchase accounting discounts. And so we think the benefit from the purchase accounting will exceed just quarteralization [ph] of the $19 million number that we experienced in the third quarter.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to be clear, the 686 [ph] over a shorter duration that when I calculate to be about a 6-year duration that you assume for this quarter?
componenttext: So just to be clear, the 686 [ph] over a shorter duration that when I calculate to be about a 6-year duration that you assume for this quarter?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And essentially, what we're required to do is assume that those -- that accretion would occur over the contractual life of the loans. And so we would assume a faster than contractual life type of assumption as far as the realization of those reflecting th
componenttext: And essentially, what we're required to do is assume that those -- that accretion would occur over the contractual life of the loans. And so we would assume a faster than contractual life type of assumption as far as the realization of those reflecting the impact of prepayments.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Zerbe with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Zerbe with Morgan Stanley.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: My First question is a little more of a broader question. You guys have frequently referred to potentially saving more than $400 million. If you did achieve -- and pick your number and say another $100 million of expense savings, how much of that would ac
componenttext: My First question is a little more of a broader question. You guys have frequently referred to potentially saving more than $400 million. If you did achieve -- and pick your number and say another $100 million of expense savings, how much of that would actually fall to the bottom line?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, I don't know if I want to set your sights for another $100 million, that would be a meaningful step.
componenttext: Ken, I don't know if I want to set your sights for another $100 million, that would be a meaningful step.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hypothetical number, of course.
componenttext: Hypothetical number, of course.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That would assume that we would be reducing over half of the legacy First Niagara franchise expense base. But that being said, we do believe that the cost saves will drop the bottom line now offsetting that. And we've also talked about revenue synergies,
componenttext: That would assume that we would be reducing over half of the legacy First Niagara franchise expense base. But that being said, we do believe that the cost saves will drop the bottom line now offsetting that. And we've also talked about revenue synergies, and we're starting to see some activities that are reinforcing our confidence in achieving those. We've talked about a $300 million run rate of revenue synergies. And with that, we would have incremental costs associated with achieving that. And so it would realize about another $100 million or so of additional expense for that. And so again, we do believe that those cost saves will drop to the bottom line, they won't be offset by other add-ons, but that we will have some additional cost to achieve those revenue synergies.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Perfect. And then just the other question I had, in terms of provision expense, could you just explain the $18 million First Niagara and, obviously, the $12 million related to the credit card higher provision. I just want to make sure I underst
componenttext: All right. Perfect. And then just the other question I had, in terms of provision expense, could you just explain the $18 million First Niagara and, obviously, the $12 million related to the credit card higher provision. I just want to make sure I understand that. I guess, I would've thought all the loans were marked to market. What am I missing in terms of why there's now a provision expense on the First Niagara loans?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, what you're missing is you're trying to apply a logic to accounting rules, and that doesn't always follow the case. But essentially, what's happened here is that, as we look at the nonPCI, nonpurchase credit impaired portfolio, those loans are record
componenttext: Ken, what you're missing is you're trying to apply a logic to accounting rules, and that doesn't always follow the case. But essentially, what's happened here is that, as we look at the nonPCI, nonpurchase credit impaired portfolio, those loans are recorded at a discount, and there will be a pre-net discount back in the income over time, but you would always look at the remaining discount to see if it's adequate to cover the required reserve associated with those loans. What's unique about those credit card portfolios is that we recorded at our premium, and so the value of that portfolio was higher than par. And so we had no discounts compared to for the recognition of allowance associated with that credit card portfolio. So effectively, on day 1 after the acquisition, we had to record the entire allowance or $12 million associated with that $300 million portfolio. And so that's what triggered that and that's why we had a higher level of provision associated with the First Niagara transaction.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, great. And then really quickly on the preferred dividends on a go-forward basis?
componenttext: All right, great. And then really quickly on the preferred dividends on a go-forward basis?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The preferred dividends will increase next quarter that the First Niagara preferred declared their dividend in July, and so it didn't have an impact on the third quarter results. So you'll see almost a doubling of the preferred dividends compared to what
componenttext: The preferred dividends will increase next quarter that the First Niagara preferred declared their dividend in July, and so it didn't have an impact on the third quarter results. So you'll see almost a doubling of the preferred dividends compared to what the current quarter was.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doubling versus this quarter, okay.
componenttext: Doubling versus this quarter, okay.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Eads with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Eads with UBS.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, there's been a lot of commentary about the outlook for C&I demand across the industry. And I'm just kind of curious what you guys are seeing. If you're seeing anything kind of unique related to the merger closing?
componenttext: Obviously, there's been a lot of commentary about the outlook for C&I demand across the industry. And I'm just kind of curious what you guys are seeing. If you're seeing anything kind of unique related to the merger closing?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Bill Hartmann, David. Well, one of the things that Don mentioned earlier was the continued momentum that was going on at First Niagara during the time between the announcement and the merger closing. And I think that, that from a growth standpoint
componenttext: This is Bill Hartmann, David. Well, one of the things that Don mentioned earlier was the continued momentum that was going on at First Niagara during the time between the announcement and the merger closing. And I think that, that from a growth standpoint, could be viewed as something that's a bit unique, because in many cases, people would expect to see a business momentum drop off. We have experienced continued growth across our portfolio as a result of the investments that we made in bankers over time, and we continue to see benefits from that investment in the -- certainly, in the current quarter.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, this is Beth. I would just add that this is an area that where, I believe, Key has outperformed the industry. One of the statistics we've quoted early was 18 of the last 20 quarters, we have seen double-digit C&I growth in our portfolio. And I
componenttext: And David, this is Beth. I would just add that this is an area that where, I believe, Key has outperformed the industry. One of the statistics we've quoted early was 18 of the last 20 quarters, we have seen double-digit C&I growth in our portfolio. And I think it's important to underline that it does reflect investments in senior bankers, so growth being driven by our client-facing personnel being increased our bankers. Second, we have also been investing in capabilities to differentiate Key, both on our KeyBanc Capital Markets platform, but also in products such as payments and treasury. So as I look at it, this has enabled us to compete differently and post a higher level of C&I growth that the industry has been seeing, yet maintain our risk profile and loss content. So I think this is that strategy coming through.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And obviously, you guys will give formal guidance at the end of the year, but it sounds like, no real change to the near-term outlook there.
componenttext: And obviously, you guys will give formal guidance at the end of the year, but it sounds like, no real change to the near-term outlook there.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No changes there within the near-term outlook, that's correct.
componenttext: No changes there within the near-term outlook, that's correct.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then on the IB business, you obviously had a great quarter there. Could you talk a little bit about the pipeline of the quarter. And your kind of implied level for 4Q is potentially moving down a little bit, but still at a pretty attractive level
componenttext: Yes. And then on the IB business, you obviously had a great quarter there. Could you talk a little bit about the pipeline of the quarter. And your kind of implied level for 4Q is potentially moving down a little bit, but still at a pretty attractive level. Is that the narrative that we should be thinking about?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our pipelines remain strong. And in order for us to hit our guidance, we'll have to have something in the $120 million plus as far as the quarter for investment banking debt placement fees. So down from the record level, but still strong compared to a yea
componenttext: Our pipelines remain strong. And in order for us to hit our guidance, we'll have to have something in the $120 million plus as far as the quarter for investment banking debt placement fees. So down from the record level, but still strong compared to a year ago and reflective of what we see as new business coming on. One other indicator there really is taking a look at our loans held for sale. And you can see a nice pop-up in the commercial mortgage loans held for sale to about $1 billion level, and so that's just 1 indicator as far as the strength of the pipeline.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have from the line of Gerard Cassidy with RBC.
componenttext: Next, we have from the line of Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, can you share with us talking about the accounting for the provision on the loans that came over. Could you also talk about the nonperforming assets or the nonperforming loans, I should say, that came from First Niagara, because once again, normally,
componenttext: Don, can you share with us talking about the accounting for the provision on the loans that came over. Could you also talk about the nonperforming assets or the nonperforming loans, I should say, that came from First Niagara, because once again, normally, those are mark-to-market. What caused those loans to come over as nonperforming loans?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And as far as the accounting treatment, we took a look at the $23 billion portfolio, and divided it into 2 primary pieces; one is purchase credit impaired, which was just shy of $1 billion, and the other piece is the nonpurchase credit impaired. For
componenttext: Sure. And as far as the accounting treatment, we took a look at the $23 billion portfolio, and divided it into 2 primary pieces; one is purchase credit impaired, which was just shy of $1 billion, and the other piece is the nonpurchase credit impaired. For the purchase credit impaired $1 billion portfolio, they're primarily commercial loans, and those are loans where we don't think they're going to be able to live up to the commitments required in the loan agreements and they're included in that category and their marked net of reserves and net of interest rate mark. And so they don't bring over any allowance associated with that and that interest rate mark will be accretive back into income over time. Because they are recognized as purchase credit impaired, they're excluded from the nonperforming assets and nonperforming loans. Now the rest of the $22 billion in loan portfolio, we did also record a mark on that portfolio, and it includes both credit and interest rates. We did not have any additional allowance related to that. But since it's not purchase credit impaired, we did carry over the status as far as the nonperforming loans and nonperforming assets. And so that's why we show $150 million coming over in NPLs from the First Niagara acquisition because many of those loans included in that nonpurchase credit impaired are reviewed on a portfolio basis as opposed to an individual loan basis. And so on a portfolio basis, we believe that the portfolio will be able to perform in line with expectations.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Would that imply they're mostly consumer loans than in the nonimpaired versus the other portfolio being the commercial loans?
componenttext: Would that imply they're mostly consumer loans than in the nonimpaired versus the other portfolio being the commercial loans?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there are commercial loans that are not PCI impaired and so -- there are also in the commercial portfolios, some business banking loans that are looked at on a portfolio basis as opposed to an individual loan basis. And so it's a mixture of both, Ge
componenttext: Well, there are commercial loans that are not PCI impaired and so -- there are also in the commercial portfolios, some business banking loans that are looked at on a portfolio basis as opposed to an individual loan basis. And so it's a mixture of both, Gerard. But I would say that most of the consumer loans are in the nonpurchase credit impaired category.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. And the second question, obviously, you guys had a blockbuster investment banking quarter. Traditionally, or historically, if I recall, you typically sell most of the production that you produce in the quarter. Was that the case this quarter o
componenttext: Okay, good. And the second question, obviously, you guys had a blockbuster investment banking quarter. Traditionally, or historically, if I recall, you typically sell most of the production that you produce in the quarter. Was that the case this quarter or did you retain more than normal? How did that work?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say our sales level to be consistent with what we'd experienced in the past. But I think we talk about for the capital raise, we will retain somewhere in around the 20% level, and I don't know that, that's changed dramatically for the current quar
componenttext: I would say our sales level to be consistent with what we'd experienced in the past. But I think we talk about for the capital raise, we will retain somewhere in around the 20% level, and I don't know that, that's changed dramatically for the current quarter.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And next, we go to the line of Bob Ramsey with FBR.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And next, we go to the line of Bob Ramsey with FBR.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The 5 million shares issued under the employee comp plan, could you just remind me sort of what the triggers are around that issue? Is it related to share price or business line performance sort of, what drove that this quarter?
componenttext: The 5 million shares issued under the employee comp plan, could you just remind me sort of what the triggers are around that issue? Is it related to share price or business line performance sort of, what drove that this quarter?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The bulk of those shares issued are related to the First Niagara acquisition. And so as we issued new restricted shares or others in connection with employee change of control contracts that we restructured some of those agreements, is how those shar
componenttext: Yes. The bulk of those shares issued are related to the First Niagara acquisition. And so as we issued new restricted shares or others in connection with employee change of control contracts that we restructured some of those agreements, is how those shares were issued for the most part. And so they would have been granted as of, or around, the August 1 time line when the acquisition was finalized.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just the last question on the card provision, which you explained. Is that entirely a onetime sort of catch-up true-up or are there any lingering sort of impacts to be aware of in the future periods?
componenttext: Okay. And then just the last question on the card provision, which you explained. Is that entirely a onetime sort of catch-up true-up or are there any lingering sort of impacts to be aware of in the future periods?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: As it relates to the card, that's a onetime impact. And so going forward, we just had normal provision to cover charge-offs and loan growth in that portfolio. Keep in mind that down the road, we will have to make sure that we're adding provisions for our
componenttext: As it relates to the card, that's a onetime impact. And so going forward, we just had normal provision to cover charge-offs and loan growth in that portfolio. Keep in mind that down the road, we will have to make sure that we're adding provisions for our new loan growth, and so we will have provision to cover that loan growth. And also as the accretion of that discount occurs for the nonpurchase credit card impaired, we will start to replenish the reserves associated with some of those portfolios over time as well.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we go to the line of Scott Siefers of Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And next, we go to the line of Scott Siefers of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think most of my questions have been answered. But maybe just one on sort of margin and rate sensitivity. I think, if I heard correctly here, you're pretty much done with restructuring the FNFG securities portfolio. So just curious if you can give a lit
componenttext: I think most of my questions have been answered. But maybe just one on sort of margin and rate sensitivity. I think, if I heard correctly here, you're pretty much done with restructuring the FNFG securities portfolio. So just curious if you can give a little color on how the combined companies rate sensitivity compares to what Key looks like stand-alone before the deal?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're absolutely right, that the restructuring of the First Niagara portfolio is done, it was done really quickly in the quarter, and so we really experienced the impact in those 2 months from having the change in that mix to the investment portfolio. As
componenttext: You're absolutely right, that the restructuring of the First Niagara portfolio is done, it was done really quickly in the quarter, and so we really experienced the impact in those 2 months from having the change in that mix to the investment portfolio. As far as the -- and I'm sorry, the second part of the question?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Combined sensitivity.
componenttext: Combined sensitivity.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Combined sensitivity, I'm sorry. If you look at combined sensitivity, we're about 2% asset sensitive. And so as we redid the portfolio from First Niagara and combined that with our overall balance sheet, it kept it fairly consistent with where we were bef
componenttext: Combined sensitivity, I'm sorry. If you look at combined sensitivity, we're about 2% asset sensitive. And so as we redid the portfolio from First Niagara and combined that with our overall balance sheet, it kept it fairly consistent with where we were before. So we didn't see a real change there. And so we're pleased with our position overall. We'll continue to reassess that. But right now, we're about 2% asset sensitive.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Burnell with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Burnell with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a little housekeeping here. The buyback was about $65 million. That's a little bit less than 20% of what you mentioned in June you were planning to repurchase over the fourth quarter capital planning cycle. How should we think about buybacks ov
componenttext: Maybe just a little housekeeping here. The buyback was about $65 million. That's a little bit less than 20% of what you mentioned in June you were planning to repurchase over the fourth quarter capital planning cycle. How should we think about buybacks over the next 3 quarters? Would they be -- should we consider that in sort of a prorated level? Or is there any sense of doing it sooner rather than later?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: One, we didn't start buying back any shares until after the merger was completed. So there was some timing to that. But more importantly, our employee stock issuance typically occurs for the most part in the first quarter of each calendar year. And so we
componenttext: One, we didn't start buying back any shares until after the merger was completed. So there was some timing to that. But more importantly, our employee stock issuance typically occurs for the most part in the first quarter of each calendar year. And so we would typically see acceleration as far as some of the share buybacks during that quarter, and so you would see a skewing or a heavier weighting of the share buybacks for that quarter and so -- but that's consistent with what we've done in the prior years as well.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I can ask, just a follow-up on the capital markets. You didn't mention capital markets as a potential revenue synergy within the FNFG franchise. Can you give us a little more color as to where you think the opportunities in capital markets in
componenttext: Okay. And if I can ask, just a follow-up on the capital markets. You didn't mention capital markets as a potential revenue synergy within the FNFG franchise. Can you give us a little more color as to where you think the opportunities in capital markets in the future, beyond the fourth quarter, may lie within the FNFG franchise?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, this is Beth. I would tell you that we do see opportunities within our corporate bank platforms, particularly in commercial mortgage banking as an area where we see real opportunity, particularly given the book of business in First Niagara that they
componenttext: Matt, this is Beth. I would tell you that we do see opportunities within our corporate bank platforms, particularly in commercial mortgage banking as an area where we see real opportunity, particularly given the book of business in First Niagara that they have within real estate, both on their balance sheet as well as more broadly, some of what those clients own. And we cited that there have already been a handful of early wins, many of them are related to the capability that we have in commercial mortgage banking. We also see, obviously, very, very good opportunities against some of our core payments, treasury management, FX and derivative products. And then, obviously, within that client base, our advisory of capabilities will probably also over time create opportunities. But near-term and early wins, I think it will be in commercial mortgage banking.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we go to the line of Bill Carcache from Nomura.
componenttext: Next, we go to the line of Bill Carcache from Nomura.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Beth, I, actually, remember you mentioning early on that at times there -- you need to take some criticism upfront before ultimately being congratulated and you kind of referenced to this transaction. And certainly, it seems as though the execution is com
componenttext: Beth, I, actually, remember you mentioning early on that at times there -- you need to take some criticism upfront before ultimately being congratulated and you kind of referenced to this transaction. And certainly, it seems as though the execution is coming through. Along those lines, a number of your peers are engaged in programs in driving return higher, but you guys seem to have what looks to us like a more tangible opportunity before you to the extent that you continue to execute on First Niagara on the integration. It sounded from your earlier comments, Don, that your pro forma return on tangible would go from 11% this quarter, x merger-related charges to 12% to 13% once you run rate the $400 million in anticipated cost savings. Did I get that right?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You are right, yes.
componenttext: You are right, yes.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So then, there's upside to the 12% to 13% number to the extent that there is further cost savings above the $400 million baseline that you mentioned, and then as well if you layer in the revenue synergies?
componenttext: Okay. So then, there's upside to the 12% to 13% number to the extent that there is further cost savings above the $400 million baseline that you mentioned, and then as well if you layer in the revenue synergies?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct. And we're always looking to continue to improve our returns on an organic basis and don't believe that this transaction just stops it. So there'll be something we continue to be focused on.
componenttext: That's correct. And we're always looking to continue to improve our returns on an organic basis and don't believe that this transaction just stops it. So there'll be something we continue to be focused on.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so what could that return number look like, if you start to factor in some of the revenue synergies as well?
componenttext: And so what could that return number look like, if you start to factor in some of the revenue synergies as well?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll provide some more guidance later as far as what our targets are for return of tangible common. But I would say going from a 10% to 12% to 13% range is a meaningful step up. And so we'll again provide more color on that later.
componenttext: We'll provide some more guidance later as far as what our targets are for return of tangible common. But I would say going from a 10% to 12% to 13% range is a meaningful step up. And so we'll again provide more color on that later.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, I would underscore that the core momentum that you're seeing in Key is what I think has been the rigor that we have given to our expenses to also create capacity to invest in bankers' products capabilities that have created some of the revenue momen
componenttext: Bill, I would underscore that the core momentum that you're seeing in Key is what I think has been the rigor that we have given to our expenses to also create capacity to invest in bankers' products capabilities that have created some of the revenue momentum that we're showing. And again, importantly, as we kind of look at it, 8 out of the last 11 quarters, Key has generated positive operating leverage. So the investments show on our revenue, but the discipline in our expenses to create those investments has been part of the momentum and performance that we're experiencing.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And lastly, if I may. Going forward, is it reasonable to expect that you'll adjust your CCAR such that CET-1 stays in the 9.5% range?
componenttext: And lastly, if I may. Going forward, is it reasonable to expect that you'll adjust your CCAR such that CET-1 stays in the 9.5% range?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're very comfortable with our capital ratio being in that level, and so we will consider that as we look forward as to future CCARs. And also, we're taking consideration for any changes in the guidance as the NPR is finalized and additional comments we'
componenttext: We're very comfortable with our capital ratio being in that level, and so we will consider that as we look forward as to future CCARs. And also, we're taking consideration for any changes in the guidance as the NPR is finalized and additional comments we've heard are put in the rule.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our next question is from the line of Geoffrey Elliott, Autonomous Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our next question is from the line of Geoffrey Elliott, Autonomous Research.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Last quarter, you talked about $30 million of incremental intangible amortization coming from the transaction, and it looks like the step-up in intangible amortization this time was a lot smaller than that, it was about $6 million. So realizing you only h
componenttext: Last quarter, you talked about $30 million of incremental intangible amortization coming from the transaction, and it looks like the step-up in intangible amortization this time was a lot smaller than that, it was about $6 million. So realizing you only had 2 quarters and 2 months of FNFG in there, I just wonder whether that steps up further in 4Q or whether the $30 million shakes out -- the number shakes out to be lower than the $30 million.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're right, the current run rate in the third quarter was below that $30 million target but we are finalizing some of the purchase accounting adjustments and could see some adjustment to that core deposit in tangible in the fourth quarter. But I still b
componenttext: You're right, the current run rate in the third quarter was below that $30 million target but we are finalizing some of the purchase accounting adjustments and could see some adjustment to that core deposit in tangible in the fourth quarter. But I still believe that it should be a slight opportunity from what we have initially estimated.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we go to the line of Mike Mayo with CLSA.
componenttext: Next, we go to the line of Mike Mayo with CLSA.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it sounds like your Columbus Day weekend conversion went well, but that was the fourth quarter. So how is it that, that you got 1/4 of your targeted expense savings in only 2 months? And if you could just give an update on how many branch closings y
componenttext: Well, it sounds like your Columbus Day weekend conversion went well, but that was the fourth quarter. So how is it that, that you got 1/4 of your targeted expense savings in only 2 months? And if you could just give an update on how many branch closings you had versus the ultimate total and headcount reductions versus the ultimate total?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far as the $100 million that I cited, there were a number of expenses associated with some of the systems development work that First Niagara was doing before the announcement. And we also had some executives -- former executives of First Niagara
componenttext: Sure. As far as the $100 million that I cited, there were a number of expenses associated with some of the systems development work that First Niagara was doing before the announcement. And we also had some executives -- former executives of First Niagara leave and some staffing leave as well post legal day 1. And so those are really the sources of much of that $100 million of cost savings. We would expect to continue to see some ramping up later this year. And as we said earlier, we would expect to realize majority of those cost saves in the first half of '17, and be at a full run rate finishing out throughout '17.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I mean in terms of headcount reductions already versus your target and branch reduction that you've achieved versus a target?
componenttext: So I mean in terms of headcount reductions already versus your target and branch reduction that you've achieved versus a target?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one, on the headcount reduction, I would say that we haven't seen any meaningful headcount reduction yet. It has been helpful, but not a meaningful source of total savings. As far as the branches, we consolidated 70 branches of First Niagara over th
componenttext: Well, one, on the headcount reduction, I would say that we haven't seen any meaningful headcount reduction yet. It has been helpful, but not a meaningful source of total savings. As far as the branches, we consolidated 70 branches of First Niagara over the conversion day weekend. And we would expect to have 36 branches of Key consolidate here in the fourth quarter. And so we should be there for our targeted branch consolidations, which were roughly about 25%. The other piece that occurred here in the third quarter is, in the middle of September, we did close on the divestiture of the branches required for the acquisition and that reduced our branch count by about 18.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So that -- so you just shut those 70 branches, they're gone? I mean. . .
componenttext: Okay. So that -- so you just shut those 70 branches, they're gone? I mean. . .

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the fourth quarter, they are no longer operational, that's correct. So they had to shut down, and we'll be realizing the expense savings associated with those branch consolidations in the fourth quarter. And then we'll have another 36 from legacy Key t
componenttext: In the fourth quarter, they are no longer operational, that's correct. So they had to shut down, and we'll be realizing the expense savings associated with those branch consolidations in the fourth quarter. And then we'll have another 36 from legacy Key that will be consolidated later in the quarter as well.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Usdin with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, I just have a question on the balance sheet. You did the securities portfolio repositioning as you mentioned, and you mentioned that the outlook for the book to stay relatively stable. Could you just help us understand the mix of earning assets going
componenttext: Don, I just have a question on the balance sheet. You did the securities portfolio repositioning as you mentioned, and you mentioned that the outlook for the book to stay relatively stable. Could you just help us understand the mix of earning assets going forward and would you expect to see earning assets move forward just in line with loan growth? Or would you expect also to see portfolio builds as you move forward as well on the security side?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The biggest driver will be the loan growth. I would say that investment portfolio should be relatively stable overall. We'll continue to make sure we're meeting our expectations requirements for LCR. But you could see a remixing as well, because we still
componenttext: The biggest driver will be the loan growth. I would say that investment portfolio should be relatively stable overall. We'll continue to make sure we're meeting our expectations requirements for LCR. But you could see a remixing as well, because we still had, in the third quarter, a very high level of short-term earning assets, mainly the Fed account, and we would expect that to come down over time.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as far as your reinvestments at this point, you mentioned the cash flows in the slide deck, so could you give an update now on a pro forma basis? Or where are you now relative to LCR? And how much -- like what your go-to investment rates ar
componenttext: Okay. And then as far as your reinvestments at this point, you mentioned the cash flows in the slide deck, so could you give an update now on a pro forma basis? Or where are you now relative to LCR? And how much -- like what your go-to investment rates are versus the 194, I guess, is what we saw on the book for the quarter?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As far as LCR, on a combined basis, we're north of 120% on the LCR, and so we're good in position from that perspective. On the go-to investment rates, the current quarter, we've bought about $4 billion in securities, about $1 billion of that were in
componenttext: Yes. As far as LCR, on a combined basis, we're north of 120% on the LCR, and so we're good in position from that perspective. On the go-to investment rates, the current quarter, we've bought about $4 billion in securities, about $1 billion of that were in floaters, so agency floaters, and so it only had about 94 basis points yield. The remaining securities that we're purchasing during the quarter had an average yield of somewhere in the 1.8 to 1.9 range, and we're seeing that come up a little bit as rates have moved up here late in the quarter.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we go to the line of Terry McEvoy from Stephens.
componenttext: And next, we go to the line of Terry McEvoy from Stephens.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you just talk about the rollout of the residential mortgage product that came over from First Niagara? Is that out in all of the markets now? I know, it's a relatively small revenue number this quarter, but going forward, do you see that growing?
componenttext: Could you just talk about the rollout of the residential mortgage product that came over from First Niagara? Is that out in all of the markets now? I know, it's a relatively small revenue number this quarter, but going forward, do you see that growing?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we are now all operating on the same origination platform and so that is a positive event. I would say that, that didn't occur with legacy Key until late in the third quarter, early fourth quarter as far as the rollout, and so you wouldn't have seen
componenttext: Well, we are now all operating on the same origination platform and so that is a positive event. I would say that, that didn't occur with legacy Key until late in the third quarter, early fourth quarter as far as the rollout, and so you wouldn't have seen much lift from that. But we would expect to start to see some of the benefits as we go into later '17 -- later '16 and into '17. And so we've been pleased with the rollout. The First Niagara mortgage loan officers converted over to our new origination platform as well and feel that was a success. Beth, anything else?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Terry, I would add that we now have, as we talked about some of the benefits of First Niagara, one was the acceleration of standing up a mortgage platform for Key from originations to servicing, and our plans in 2017 and forward to include us adding t
componenttext: And Terry, I would add that we now have, as we talked about some of the benefits of First Niagara, one was the acceleration of standing up a mortgage platform for Key from originations to servicing, and our plans in 2017 and forward to include us adding to our mortgage origination staff and more robustly offering mortgage across our entire Key footprint. So that is one of the sources of the revenue synergy that we see in the transaction.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we go to the line of Matt O'Connor from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next, we go to the line of Matt O'Connor from Deutsche Bank.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the net interest margin percent, the 3 basis points expansion versus last quarter ex the purchase accounting accretion. What drove that?
componenttext: Just following up on the net interest margin percent, the 3 basis points expansion versus last quarter ex the purchase accounting accretion. What drove that?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, purchase accounting accretion was clearly related to First Niagara. Also, First Niagara had a stronger margin than Key going into the transaction, and so that was also a benefit. I would say legacy Key was relatively stable in quarters as far as the
componenttext: Well, purchase accounting accretion was clearly related to First Niagara. Also, First Niagara had a stronger margin than Key going into the transaction, and so that was also a benefit. I would say legacy Key was relatively stable in quarters as far as the overall margins.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just separately, the tax rate expected for this year of 24% to 25%. Is that a good range to use for 2017 as well?
componenttext: Okay. And then just separately, the tax rate expected for this year of 24% to 25%. Is that a good range to use for 2017 as well?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Depends on the tax credits we have available. I would say that a more appropriate range would probably be in the 25% to 27% range as opposed to 24% to 25%.
componenttext: Depends on the tax credits we have available. I would say that a more appropriate range would probably be in the 25% to 27% range as opposed to 24% to 25%.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is there a related decline in expenses associated with the higher tax rate?
componenttext: And is there a related decline in expenses associated with the higher tax rate?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say the decline in expenses as the merger-related charges will be lower, which will have an impact on the overall tax rate, and that's why you're seeing a step-up there.
componenttext: I would say the decline in expenses as the merger-related charges will be lower, which will have an impact on the overall tax rate, and that's why you're seeing a step-up there.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we go to the line of Peter Winter with Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: And next, we go to the line of Peter Winter with Wedbush Securities.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the revenue enhancements, could you talk a little bit about, maybe, the timing that you see, some of that coming through in '17? And then in addition to residential mortgage, what some of the big contributors will be?
componenttext: Just on the revenue enhancements, could you talk a little bit about, maybe, the timing that you see, some of that coming through in '17? And then in addition to residential mortgage, what some of the big contributors will be?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. When we talked about the $3 million of incremental revenue synergies, we said that, that would typically be in a 3- to 5-year type of time period. And so we'll have to continue to monitor that, but that's our initial assumption going in. In addition
componenttext: Sure. When we talked about the $3 million of incremental revenue synergies, we said that, that would typically be in a 3- to 5-year type of time period. And so we'll have to continue to monitor that, but that's our initial assumption going in. In addition to the residential mortgage, one of the big areas for us, is our cash management services, treasury management services for the commercial side. And as we take a look at the activity levels that we're seeing right now, we're seeing a nice increase as far as potential referrals and pipeline associated with that. I think we've got over 200 First Niagara customers that are at least talking to us about adding additional treasury management services. And so that would be another category, but we also have potential growth in a number of other products and services, some of which came from First Niagara and some of which are for legacy Key. Beth, anything else you want to add there?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the product capabilities, again, a robust offering for the commercial customers would also include what we put in our corporate services income of FX and derivatives and a broad suite there. We also look at wealth management and private banking and wit
componenttext: In the product capabilities, again, a robust offering for the commercial customers would also include what we put in our corporate services income of FX and derivatives and a broad suite there. We also look at wealth management and private banking and within that, we have investment management and other services that, I think, will be a good fit, again, for their consumer as well as business customers within Key.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just quickly, anything you'd want to comment on '17 with regards to some of that revenue enhancement that you're seeing?
componenttext: Okay. And just quickly, anything you'd want to comment on '17 with regards to some of that revenue enhancement that you're seeing?

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really, again, I think, it gets all back to we think it's a 3- to 5-year time period, so you can think about that ramping up over that time period. So I would say that we'll provide a little more guidance as we get into the fourth quarter call in January
componenttext: Really, again, I think, it gets all back to we think it's a 3- to 5-year time period, so you can think about that ramping up over that time period. So I would say that we'll provide a little more guidance as we get into the fourth quarter call in January and provide more clarity as far as the timing and the level of recognition associated with those revenue synergies.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that was our last question. I would now like to turn the conference back over to Beth Mooney for final or closing remarks. Thank you.
componenttext: And that was our last question. I would now like to turn the conference back over to Beth Mooney for final or closing remarks. Thank you.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, we thank you for taking time from your schedule to participate in our call today. If you have any follow-up questions, you can direct them to our Investor Relations team at (216) 689-4221. And with that, concludes our remarks and our conference. Th
componenttext: Again, we thank you for taking time from your schedule to participate in our call today. If you have any follow-up questions, you can direct them to our Investor Relations team at (216) 689-4221. And with that, concludes our remarks and our conference. Thank you very much and have a great day.

headline: KeyCorp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude our conference for today. Thank you for your participation and for using AT&T executive teleconference service. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude our conference for today. Thank you for your participation and for using AT&T executive teleconference service. You may now disconnect.
